<ul>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_benefits><field_benefit_type/><field_business_activity_change_><value>0</value></field_business_activity_change_><field_contact>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>f703a0f6-0d0a-464a-9816-f876ccb3bee1</value></uuid><vid><value>111</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>user_story</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8a429ea9-ca86-434c-a2bd-c2da0d4ba77e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Condamine-Balonne Flood Inundation Modelling</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493865499</value></created><changed><value>1493865653</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493865653</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_additional_changes/><field_benefits><value><![CDATA[<p>The AGDC contributed to identifying breakout of inundation at various flows. It provided the most comprehensive study of historical flood inundation in the Northern Basin undertaken by the MDBA.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_benefits><field_benefit_type/><field_business_activity_change_><value>0</value></field_business_activity_change_><field_contact>
attempting match on: %!7%!
No match node contents append: %!7%!
attempting match on: </field_contact><field_data_collection/><field_date_range><value>2015-12-31T13:00:00</value><end_value>2016-07-31T14:00:00</end_value></field_date_range><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues><value><![CDATA[<p>Pilot 1 indicated concern that the algorithm used to classify water observations in the WOfS data underestimates observed water, especially when compared to the CSIRO algorithm. This creates a significant risk that the flood boundaries generated from the WOfS data fall short from where they should really be. Although some detail of the algorithms used to detect water are included in the WOfS Product Description , additional detail needs to be provided by GA, especially to enable peer review and test the sensitivity of the algorithms.</p>

<p>There is a logical argument for the CSIRO and GA to discuss their respective algorithms so that there is an authoritative one, or at least one more suited for MDBA's purposes.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_issues><field_links/><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong><br />
To better understand the behaviour of flows in the Lower Balonne landscape for every 1,000 megalitres/day flows across the floodplain. This additional information is a major input into the Northern Basin Review (NBR), especially regarding specific flow indicators.</p>

<p>This pilot was an MDBA in-house developed satellite imagery-based study of flow inundation based on historical flow events. It was undertaken following the failure of the first version of the CSIRO floodplain inundation model for the Lower Balonne. The CSIRO model was to improve the understanding of the behaviour of flows in the Lower Balonne for the NBR. However, due to its failure and that delivery of the second version was to be too late for the NBR, the MDBA in-house model (i.e. this pilot) was delivered as an interim version.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong><br />
The bulk of the effort was filtering the Landsat tiles through:</p>

<ul>
	<li>a hydrograph analysis to remove tiles associated with insignificant flow and antecedent conditions</li>
	<li>an image attribute analysis to ensure that &gt;50% of the tile contains data and &lt;50% of tile is impacted by terrain shadow, high slope, cloud, or cloud shadow.</li>
</ul>

<p>Individual flood zones were developed from analysing gauges with sufficient observed flow data and visually assessing the presence of vegetation in the landscape. The resulting tiles from filtering were then clipped to the extent of the flood zone of interest for further analysis.</p>

<p>In-house scripts were used to prepare the image packages for flood inundation analysis. This included projecting them to a suitable geographic coordinate system and calculating attributes such as area and date taken. They were then married to the flow at the appropriate gauge for that day to create a flow inundation relationship for each flood zone. By looking at the relationship of zones and the attenuation of flows between the various gauges of the zones, it was possible to provide a total inundation for that flow for the whole reach. The workflow was then repeated for vegetation so that total inundation on catchment scale could also be produced.</p>

<p>Plots were generated for the relationship between river flow and total inundation for the flood zone of interest, and also plots were generated for the relationship between flow and vegetation inundation for various vegetation types.</p>

<p>The pilot team used the water classification results for each individual pixel of the WOfS images to generate flood inundation which could then be correlated to river flow rates.</p>

<p>There was considerable effort put into planning and developing the extensive computational analysis suite to produce the inundation results from the WOfS data. This included development of Python scripts to automate processes and to filter WOfS images for further analysis.</p>

<p>The pilot demonstrated the importance of having a good understanding of the WOfS data, clear requirements, and appropriate planning. The pilot team?s existing skills in ArcGIS and Python scripting was a major contributor to the methodology, but were also important in developing the appropriate tools to undertake the pilot. This was all undertaken with no dependencies with other areas of the MDBA.</p>

<p><strong>Outcomes</strong><br />
The results of the pilot enabled the identification of breakout of inundation at various flows. It provided very good results for the Middle Darling and quite good results for the Culgoa River making it possible to help set Specific Flow Indicators (flow rates designed to lead to particular ecological outcomes) for those regions</p>

<p>The pilot is the most comprehensive study of historical flood inundation in the Northern Basin undertaken by the MDBA. However, its true success is that the workflow developed can be fully automated and applied to the whole Basin.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story>
No match node contents append: </field_contact><field_data_collection/><field_date_range><value>2015-12-31T13:00:00</value><end_value>2016-07-31T14:00:00</end_value></field_date_range><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues><value><![CDATA[<p>Pilot 1 indicated concern that the algorithm used to classify water observations in the WOfS data underestimates observed water, especially when compared to the CSIRO algorithm. This creates a significant risk that the flood boundaries generated from the WOfS data fall short from where they should really be. Although some detail of the algorithms used to detect water are included in the WOfS Product Description , additional detail needs to be provided by GA, especially to enable peer review and test the sensitivity of the algorithms.</p>

<p>There is a logical argument for the CSIRO and GA to discuss their respective algorithms so that there is an authoritative one, or at least one more suited for MDBA's purposes.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_issues><field_links/><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong><br />

<p>In-house scripts were used to prepare the image packages for flood inundation analysis. This included projecting them to a suitable geographic coordinate system and calculating attributes such as area and date taken. They were then married to the flow at the appropriate gauge for that day to create a flow inundation relationship for each flood zone. By looking at the relationship of zones and the attenuation of flows between the various gauges of the zones, it was possible to provide a total inundation for that flow for the whole reach. The workflow was then repeated for vegetation so that total inundation on catchment scale could also be produced.</p>

<p>Plots were generated for the relationship between river flow and total inundation for the flood zone of interest, and also plots were generated for the relationship between flow and vegetation inundation for various vegetation types.</p>

<p>The pilot team used the water classification results for each individual pixel of the WOfS images to generate flood inundation which could then be correlated to river flow rates.</p>

<p>There was considerable effort put into planning and developing the extensive computational analysis suite to produce the inundation results from the WOfS data. This included development of Python scripts to automate processes and to filter WOfS images for further analysis.</p>

<p>The pilot demonstrated the importance of having a good understanding of the WOfS data, clear requirements, and appropriate planning. The pilot team?s existing skills in ArcGIS and Python scripting was a major contributor to the methodology, but were also important in developing the appropriate tools to undertake the pilot. This was all undertaken with no dependencies with other areas of the MDBA.</p>

<p><strong>Outcomes</strong><br />
The results of the pilot enabled the identification of breakout of inundation at various flows. It provided very good results for the Middle Darling and quite good results for the Culgoa River making it possible to help set Specific Flow Indicators (flow rates designed to lead to particular ecological outcomes) for those regions</p>

<p>The pilot is the most comprehensive study of historical flood inundation in the Northern Basin undertaken by the MDBA. However, its true success is that the workflow developed can be fully automated and applied to the whole Basin.</p>

The merging of orbit data results in a considerable reduction in both the number of unknown orientation parameters and the number of control points required in the sensor orientation adjustment.</p>

match node contents append: <nid><value>103</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>ffbef4a9-441a-4544-af7f-97be9e260d97</value></uuid><vid><value>121</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Fractional Cover Processing</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493874839</value></created><changed><value>1493874887</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493874887</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent for any point in time in the Landsat archive since 1987. FC can potentially provide insight into areas of dry/dying vegetation and/or bare soil as well as allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code><uri>http://github.com/geoscienceaustralia/fc </uri><title></title><options/></field_source_code><field_version_number/>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>ffbef4a9-441a-4544-af7f-97be9e260d97</value></uuid><vid><value>121</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Fractional Cover Processing</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493874839</value></created><changed><value>1493874887</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493874887</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent for any point in time in the Landsat archive since 1987. FC can potentially provide insight into areas of dry/dying vegetation and/or bare soil as well as allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code><uri>http://github.com/geoscienceaustralia/fc </uri><title></title><options/></field_source_code><field_version_number/>

FC can potentially provide insight into areas of dry/dying vegetation and/or bare soil as well as allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code><uri>http://github.com/geoscienceaustralia/fc </uri><title></title><options/></field_source_code><field_version_number/>
matches: [0] = <nid><value>104 [1] = nid [2] = 104
match node contents append: <nid><value>104</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>ffda822d-7ee8-465f-b362-398af7e94345</value></uuid><vid><value>122</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>NDVI Function</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493874916</value></created><changed><value>1493874937</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493874937</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>Live green plants absorb solar radiation in the photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) spectral region, which they use as a source of energy in the process of photosynthesis. Leaf cells have also evolved to reflect, scatter and re-emit solar radiation in the near-infrared spectral region. The pigment in plant leaves, chlorophyll, strongly absorbs visible light (from 0.4 to 0.7 micrometres) for use in photosynthesis. The cell structure of the leaves, on the other hand, strongly reflects near-infrared light (from 0.7 to 1.1 micrometres). Hence, live green plants appear relatively dark in the PAR and relatively bright in the near-infrared.<br />
By contrast, clouds and snow tend to be rather bright in the red (as well as other visible wavelengths) and quite dark in the near-infrared.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p>The Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is calculated as follows:</p>

<p>(NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED)</p>

<p>where RED and NIR stand for the spectral reflectance measurements acquired in the red and near-infrared regions, respectively.</p>

<p>NDVI values range between -1 and +1, and have been scaled by 10000 to be stored as integers between -10000 and +10000.</p>

<p>Negative values of NDVI (values between 0 and -1) usually correspond to non vegetation targets such as water. Values close to zero (-0.1 to 0.1) generally correspond to barren areas of rock, sand, or snow. Low, positive values usually represent shrub and grassland (approximately 0.2 to 0.4), while high values are indicative of healthy crops or dense vegetation such as temperate and tropical rainforests (values approaching 1).</p>

<p>First described in Tucker (1979) the NDVI has been widely used as a vegetation index to characterise the amount of vegetation on the Earths surface. The study by Carlson and Ripley (1997) is widely cited and describes the relationship between NDVI, fractional vegetation cover and leaf area index.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>

The cell structure of the leaves, on the other hand, strongly reflects near-infrared light (from 0.7 to 1.1 micrometres). Hence, live green plants appear relatively dark in the PAR and relatively bright in the near-infrared.<br />

<p>(NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED)</p>

<p>where RED and NIR stand for the spectral reflectance measurements acquired in the red and near-infrared regions, respectively.</p>

<p>NDVI values range between -1 and +1, and have been scaled by 10000 to be stored as integers between -10000 and +10000.</p>

<p>Negative values of NDVI (values between 0 and -1) usually correspond to non vegetation targets such as water. Values close to zero (-0.1 to 0.1) generally correspond to barren areas of rock, sand, or snow. Low, positive values usually represent shrub and grassland (approximately 0.2 to 0.4), while high values are indicative of healthy crops or dense vegetation such as temperate and tropical rainforests (values approaching 1).</p>

<p>First described in Tucker (1979) the NDVI has been widely used as a vegetation index to characterise the amount of vegetation on the Earths surface. The study by Carlson and Ripley (1997) is widely cited and describes the relationship between NDVI, fractional vegetation cover and leaf area index.</p>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>1862cc6d-5fb6-49c4-ac86-904dd60a5c89</value></uuid><vid><value>126</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Determine values for six base atmospheric parameters across each image scene</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493875031</value></created><changed><value>1493875047</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493875047</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose/><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<ol>
	<li>Divide scene into quarters and select the nine unique points which form the corners of these quadrants</li>
	<li>Compute the six parameters across optical spectrum at each of the nine points using a Radiative Transfer Model (Modtran 5) and atmospheric state data</li>
	<li>Accumulate values for the six parameters at each of the nine points to correspond to Landsat bands using Landsat spectral response function</li>
	<li>Interpolate accumulated values for the six parameters across image scene using the bilinear method.</li>
</ol>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>

	<li>Divide scene into quarters and select the nine unique points which form the corners of these quadrants</li>
	<li>Compute the six parameters across optical spectrum at each of the nine points using a Radiative Transfer Model (Modtran 5) and atmospheric state data</li>
	<li>Accumulate values for the six parameters at each of the nine points to correspond to Landsat bands using Landsat spectral response function</li>
	<li>Interpolate accumulated values for the six parameters across image scene using the bilinear method.</li>

Adding node contents to map with id: 108
	-<nid><value>108</value></nid>
	-<uuid><value>1862cc6d-5fb6-49c4-ac86-904dd60a5c89</value></uuid><vid><value>126</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Determine values for six base atmospheric parameters across each image scene</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493875031</value></created><changed><value>1493875047</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493875047</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose/><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<ol>
	<li>Divide scene into quarters and select the nine unique points which form the corners of these quadrants</li>
	<li>Compute the six parameters across optical spectrum at each of the nine points using a Radiative Transfer Model (Modtran 5) and atmospheric state data</li>
	<li>Accumulate values for the six parameters at each of the nine points to correspond to Landsat bands using Landsat spectral response function</li>
	<li>Interpolate accumulated values for the six parameters across image scene using the bilinear method.</li>
</ol>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>

match node contents append: <nid><value>148</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>b16af9af-9e9e-458e-9557-0545eb911f56</value></uuid><vid><value>179</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>user_story</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8a429ea9-ca86-434c-a2bd-c2da0d4ba77e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Gwydir to Barwon-Darling Environmental Water Release </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494370434</value></created><changed><value>1494370547</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1494370547</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_additional_changes/><field_benefits><value><![CDATA[<p>The pilot demonstrated AGDCs usefulness in supporting the units work, but in association with other information. It demonstrated a non-technical spatial data user can use the AGDC, but with significant support from GIS experienced staff.</p>

<p>The AGDC helped identify private storages where water may have been extracted. The WOfS data was not helpful on its own, but it told a compelling story in association with NDVI and other data. It was also vital in helping endorse anecdotal evidence.</p>

<p>The WOfS data did not provide information on storage volumes, and ultimately was relied on less than the NDVI data. The NDVI quarterly composites were not only useful in observing the likeliness of crops such as cotton crops, but provided sound confirmation of the presence of water. As a broader use, reconciliation of annual composites would be useful for SDL compliance.</p>

<p>The pilot confirmed that the AGDC is an important part of the puzzle, especially in providing evidence and eliminating unknowns in understanding the water balance. From a policy perspective, the pilot provided compelling evidence through its earth observations. It contributed to developing a monitoring process for future work and as an important visual tool in communicating findings to others.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_benefits><field_benefit_type/><field_business_activity_change_><value>1</value></field_business_activity_change_><field_contact>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>b16af9af-9e9e-458e-9557-0545eb911f56</value></uuid><vid><value>179</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>user_story</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8a429ea9-ca86-434c-a2bd-c2da0d4ba77e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Gwydir to Barwon-Darling Environmental Water Release </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494370434</value></created><changed><value>1494370547</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1494370547</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_additional_changes/><field_benefits><value><![CDATA[<p>The pilot demonstrated AGDCs usefulness in supporting the units work, but in association with other information. It demonstrated a non-technical spatial data user can use the AGDC, but with significant support from GIS experienced staff.</p>

<p>The AGDC helped identify private storages where water may have been extracted. The WOfS data was not helpful on its own, but it told a compelling story in association with NDVI and other data. It was also vital in helping endorse anecdotal evidence.</p>

<p>The WOfS data did not provide information on storage volumes, and ultimately was relied on less than the NDVI data. The NDVI quarterly composites were not only useful in observing the likeliness of crops such as cotton crops, but provided sound confirmation of the presence of water. As a broader use, reconciliation of annual composites would be useful for SDL compliance.</p>

<p>The pilot confirmed that the AGDC is an important part of the puzzle, especially in providing evidence and eliminating unknowns in understanding the water balance. From a policy perspective, the pilot provided compelling evidence through its earth observations. It contributed to developing a monitoring process for future work and as an important visual tool in communicating findings to others.</p>

No match node contents append: </field_contact><field_data_collection>
attempting match on: %!142%!
No match node contents append: %!142%!
attempting match on: </field_data_collection><field_date_range/><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues><value><![CDATA[<p>Prior to the pilot, MDBA staff had limited knowledge of ArcGIS or Python scripting. Plans to spend time at GA to learn to use the AGDC's data querying interface were of limited benefit due to lack of knowledge of the AGDC API and limited training available from GA.</p>

<p>IT security and compatibility issues also prevented MDBA staff from using an MDBA laptop at GA as planned. This was further compounded by NCI access issues experienced at MDBA.</p>

<p>More guidance and organised support earlier in the pilot would have provided a more fruitful experience.</p>

<p>The main issue with the WOfS and NDVI data was the limited explanation of how to use them. The interpretation of the WOfS tile data, especially in relation to the WOfS Pixel Drill, had a significant potential to misinform. It was easy to assume observations impacted by cloud and relief were not wet, thus creating a perceived discrepancy between the WOfS tiles and WOfS Pixel Drill. There was also limited explanation of how GA had processed the quarterly data. However, in most instances the pilot team was able to easily get clarification from GA.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_issues><field_links/><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong><br />
To better understand the risks associated with held environmental water flows under current water management arrangements, particularly in the Barwon-Darling. This was also driven by the Northern Basin Advisory Committee (NBAC), especially as it was identified as an emerging risk in the NBR.</p>

<p>It was intended to undertake a water balance through the pilot to deal with water shepherding issues in the north by identifying the:</p>

<ul>
	<li>volume of held environmental water entered into the Barwon-Darling</li>
	<li>location, area and volume of private storages in the pilot area</li>
	<li>private storages that have filled due to environmental flows</li>
	<li>downstream flow of held environmental water in the Barwon-Darling</li>
	<li>volume and length of time taken for held environmental water to reach Bourke.</li>
</ul>

<p>Although determining depth of water was a would like part of the pilot, it was acknowledged that it was not currently possible with the AGDC.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong><br />
The original intent of the pilot was for MBDA staff to spend up to a week at GA to learn how to use the AGDCs data querying interface (i.e. API) and develop the capability to extract the required WOfS tiles from the HPC environment. Once extracted, the tiles would be filtered to remove tiles impacted by cloud, terrain, and high slope to create maps of observed water. These maps would then be used to identify whether private storages have filled as a result of an environmental water release.<br />
Following the first few hours at GA, the approach was revised to improve the likelihood of identifying private storages of interest. The revised two-step approach included:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Generation of quarterly WOfS composites by GA to compare and identify the general fill behaviour of private storages prior and post the water release to identify private storages of interest.</li>
	<li>Interrogation of pixel drill to identify extracted water behaviour over time for the private storages of interest. Pixel drill is a beta online tool developed by GA which gives the water classification results for each individual pixel when selected.</li>
</ol>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story>
No match node contents append: </field_data_collection><field_date_range/><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues><value><![CDATA[<p>Prior to the pilot, MDBA staff had limited knowledge of ArcGIS or Python scripting. Plans to spend time at GA to learn to use the AGDC's data querying interface were of limited benefit due to lack of knowledge of the AGDC API and limited training available from GA.</p>

<p>IT security and compatibility issues also prevented MDBA staff from using an MDBA laptop at GA as planned. This was further compounded by NCI access issues experienced at MDBA.</p>

<p>More guidance and organised support earlier in the pilot would have provided a more fruitful experience.</p>

<p>The main issue with the WOfS and NDVI data was the limited explanation of how to use them. The interpretation of the WOfS tile data, especially in relation to the WOfS Pixel Drill, had a significant potential to misinform. It was easy to assume observations impacted by cloud and relief were not wet, thus creating a perceived discrepancy between the WOfS tiles and WOfS Pixel Drill. There was also limited explanation of how GA had processed the quarterly data. However, in most instances the pilot team was able to easily get clarification from GA.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_issues><field_links/><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong><br />
To better understand the risks associated with held environmental water flows under current water management arrangements, particularly in the Barwon-Darling. This was also driven by the Northern Basin Advisory Committee (NBAC), especially as it was identified as an emerging risk in the NBR.</p>

<p>It was intended to undertake a water balance through the pilot to deal with water shepherding issues in the north by identifying the:</p>

<ul>
	<li>volume of held environmental water entered into the Barwon-Darling</li>
	<li>location, area and volume of private storages in the pilot area</li>
	<li>private storages that have filled due to environmental flows</li>
	<li>downstream flow of held environmental water in the Barwon-Darling</li>
	<li>volume and length of time taken for held environmental water to reach Bourke.</li>
</ul>

<p>Although determining depth of water was a would like part of the pilot, it was acknowledged that it was not currently possible with the AGDC.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong><br />
The original intent of the pilot was for MBDA staff to spend up to a week at GA to learn how to use the AGDCs data querying interface (i.e. API) and develop the capability to extract the required WOfS tiles from the HPC environment. Once extracted, the tiles would be filtered to remove tiles impacted by cloud, terrain, and high slope to create maps of observed water. These maps would then be used to identify whether private storages have filled as a result of an environmental water release.<br />
Following the first few hours at GA, the approach was revised to improve the likelihood of identifying private storages of interest. The revised two-step approach included:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Generation of quarterly WOfS composites by GA to compare and identify the general fill behaviour of private storages prior and post the water release to identify private storages of interest.</li>
	<li>Interrogation of pixel drill to identify extracted water behaviour over time for the private storages of interest. Pixel drill is a beta online tool developed by GA which gives the water classification results for each individual pixel when selected.</li>
</ol>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story>

Adding node contents to map with id: 148
	-<nid><value>148</value></nid>
	-<uuid><value>b16af9af-9e9e-458e-9557-0545eb911f56</value></uuid><vid><value>179</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>user_story</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8a429ea9-ca86-434c-a2bd-c2da0d4ba77e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Gwydir to Barwon-Darling Environmental Water Release </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494370434</value></created><changed><value>1494370547</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1494370547</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_additional_changes/><field_benefits><value><![CDATA[<p>The pilot demonstrated AGDCs usefulness in supporting the units work, but in association with other information. It demonstrated a non-technical spatial data user can use the AGDC, but with significant support from GIS experienced staff.</p>

<p>The AGDC helped identify private storages where water may have been extracted. The WOfS data was not helpful on its own, but it told a compelling story in association with NDVI and other data. It was also vital in helping endorse anecdotal evidence.</p>

<p>The WOfS data did not provide information on storage volumes, and ultimately was relied on less than the NDVI data. The NDVI quarterly composites were not only useful in observing the likeliness of crops such as cotton crops, but provided sound confirmation of the presence of water. As a broader use, reconciliation of annual composites would be useful for SDL compliance.</p>

<p>The pilot confirmed that the AGDC is an important part of the puzzle, especially in providing evidence and eliminating unknowns in understanding the water balance. From a policy perspective, the pilot provided compelling evidence through its earth observations. It contributed to developing a monitoring process for future work and as an important visual tool in communicating findings to others.</p>

	-%!7%!
	-</field_contact><field_data_collection>
	-%!142%!
	-</field_data_collection><field_date_range/><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues><value><![CDATA[<p>Prior to the pilot, MDBA staff had limited knowledge of ArcGIS or Python scripting. Plans to spend time at GA to learn to use the AGDC's data querying interface were of limited benefit due to lack of knowledge of the AGDC API and limited training available from GA.</p>

<p>IT security and compatibility issues also prevented MDBA staff from using an MDBA laptop at GA as planned. This was further compounded by NCI access issues experienced at MDBA.</p>

<p>More guidance and organised support earlier in the pilot would have provided a more fruitful experience.</p>

<p>The main issue with the WOfS and NDVI data was the limited explanation of how to use them. The interpretation of the WOfS tile data, especially in relation to the WOfS Pixel Drill, had a significant potential to misinform. It was easy to assume observations impacted by cloud and relief were not wet, thus creating a perceived discrepancy between the WOfS tiles and WOfS Pixel Drill. There was also limited explanation of how GA had processed the quarterly data. However, in most instances the pilot team was able to easily get clarification from GA.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_issues><field_links/><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong><br />
To better understand the risks associated with held environmental water flows under current water management arrangements, particularly in the Barwon-Darling. This was also driven by the Northern Basin Advisory Committee (NBAC), especially as it was identified as an emerging risk in the NBR.</p>

<p>It was intended to undertake a water balance through the pilot to deal with water shepherding issues in the north by identifying the:</p>

<ul>
	<li>volume of held environmental water entered into the Barwon-Darling</li>
	<li>location, area and volume of private storages in the pilot area</li>
	<li>private storages that have filled due to environmental flows</li>
	<li>downstream flow of held environmental water in the Barwon-Darling</li>
	<li>volume and length of time taken for held environmental water to reach Bourke.</li>
</ul>

<p>Although determining depth of water was a would like part of the pilot, it was acknowledged that it was not currently possible with the AGDC.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong><br />
The original intent of the pilot was for MBDA staff to spend up to a week at GA to learn how to use the AGDCs data querying interface (i.e. API) and develop the capability to extract the required WOfS tiles from the HPC environment. Once extracted, the tiles would be filtered to remove tiles impacted by cloud, terrain, and high slope to create maps of observed water. These maps would then be used to identify whether private storages have filled as a result of an environmental water release.<br />
Following the first few hours at GA, the approach was revised to improve the likelihood of identifying private storages of interest. The revised two-step approach included:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Generation of quarterly WOfS composites by GA to compare and identify the general fill behaviour of private storages prior and post the water release to identify private storages of interest.</li>
	<li>Interrogation of pixel drill to identify extracted water behaviour over time for the private storages of interest. Pixel drill is a beta online tool developed by GA which gives the water classification results for each individual pixel when selected.</li>
</ol>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>cda16375-780f-401d-a8f1-4d34a4755a28</value></uuid><vid><value>180</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>user_story</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8a429ea9-ca86-434c-a2bd-c2da0d4ba77e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Lake Victoria Salinity and Destocking Response </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494374943</value></created><changed><value>1494375407</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1494375407</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_additional_changes/><field_benefits><value><![CDATA[<p>Pilot&#160;provided a way forward to assess changes around Lake Victoria and provided some understanding of what is and is not possible with the AGDC.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_benefits><field_benefit_type/><field_business_activity_change_><value>1</value></field_business_activity_change_><field_contact>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>cda16375-780f-401d-a8f1-4d34a4755a28</value></uuid><vid><value>180</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>user_story</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8a429ea9-ca86-434c-a2bd-c2da0d4ba77e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Lake Victoria Salinity and Destocking Response </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494374943</value></created><changed><value>1494375407</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1494375407</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_additional_changes/><field_benefits><value><![CDATA[<p>Pilot&#160;provided a way forward to assess changes around Lake Victoria and provided some understanding of what is and is not possible with the AGDC.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_benefits><field_benefit_type/><field_business_activity_change_><value>1</value></field_business_activity_change_><field_contact>

No match node contents append: %!135%!
attempting match on: </field_data_collection><field_date_range/><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues><value><![CDATA[<p>The NDVI data supplied by GA had limited documentation which made it difficult to understand how it was prepared.</p>

<p>The data format supplied was unfamiliar to the MDBA so the project team had to seek advice on how best to use the data.</p>

<p>The AGDC did not enable a broad scale indication of the effect of salinity or destocking. It only identified the severe components and picking out areas affected was difficult. Although a trend was detectable, there was no detail on the trend.with some of the pre-processing of the Lake Victoria NDVI tiles including joining and clipping the tiles and analysing the NDVI in different ways.</p>

<p>The greenness from NDVI annual composite statistics was used to filter out annual variations in the plots to improve interpretations, however comparing two years was difficult. In the case of the salinity, there was some indication of bare ground which coincided with existing salinity maps, but there was also the potential for confusing sandy soil with salinity.</p>

<p>GA supplied the numerical outputs (as spreadsheets) for two of the Hovmller plots. They were used to select sample areas and time spans from the plot and look at the data in more detail. However, this was difficult to do as the data did not completely correlate with the transect line in the plot. It also created an overestimation of greenness, possibly due to how a transect line cuts across a cell and the value assigned to it.</p>

<p>Although it was initially planned to use Surface Reflectance data (i.e. ARG25) as opposed to NDVI, ARG25 could have provided false results due to the landscape and soil types around Lake Victoria. The limited organic matter in the soils may have also shown up as high reflectance and be mistaken for salinity. Although an attempt was made to download the ARG25 data from the NCI National Research Data Collection, it was quite cumbersome to use therefore not compared.</p>

<p>The Hovmller plots were a good tool, especially for communication, as it can show benefits of environmental watering. But the question is how is the tool best delivered to help determine plot transects? The Vegetation Typing Tool, from the Vegetation Monitoring in the MDB project, although potentially useful was a missing part of the puzzle. However it was acknowledged that it was not useful in its current form.</p>

<p>It needs to be noted that after the pilot additional data on vegetation communities became available. This would have assisted with more effectively defining the transects for the Hovmller plots.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_issues><field_links/><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong></p>

<p>To assess:</p>

<ul>
	<li>changes to salinity over time and</li>
	<li>environmental response to destocking.</li>
</ul>

<p>For salinity, it included assessing changes in the spatial extent of salinity to the south and east of Lake Victoria from the 1980s to present as a result of land clearing, increased agricultural activity, and lake regulation. Previous studies of the area had shown an increase.</p>

<p>For destocking, it included determining if removal of cattle has led to changes in vegetation coverage and vegetation communities on Noola and Nulla, properties purchased by MDBA in 2003 and 2008 respectively.</p>

<p>The operational purpose was to also try and indicate impacts of climate change and drought, therefore it was important that the time-slices selected for analysing the Landsat archive could also be used as controls.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong></p>

<p>GA suggested using Hovmller plots as an initial change detection exercise for the areas of interest. A Hovmller plot depicts changes in data values over time along a single line of latitude/longitude. The line is generally depicted on the x-axis, whilst time is along the y-axis. For the Hovmller plots prepared for the pilot, the x-axis represented the length of the transect from its start to finish, whilst the data values represented NDVI.&#160;</p>

<p>MDBA provided GA with 500 meter transects, appropriately spaced for similar conditions and vegetation, which GA used to drill through the AGDC to generate Hovmller plots of NDVI. In total they prepared Hovmller plots for 9 transects (2 for destocking and 7 for salinity).</p>

<p>Change detection maps were also generated from annual NDVI statistics by comparing greenest to driest years. This was to assess the landscape before and after the pilot activity, i.e. salinity and destocking. Time series NDVI graphs for point locations were also analysed so existing vegetation monitoring points and soil surveys could be used to validate AGDC observations.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story>

The final NDVI data over Gunbower was supplied as floating points and also 1,000 bands for each image. This needed to be pre-processed and reformatted so it could be made useable and analysed as per the planned methodology.</p>

The final NDVI data over Gunbower was supplied as floating points and also 1,000 bands for each image. This needed to be pre-processed and reformatted so it could be made useable and analysed as per the planned methodology.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_issues><field_links/><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area>
attempting match on: %!12547%!
No match node contents append: %!12547%!
attempting match on: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_societal_benefit_area>
No match node contents append: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_societal_benefit_area>
attempting match on: %!12550%!
No match node contents append: %!12550%!
attempting match on: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong></p>

<p>To determine how vegetation responds to flow events, specifically to identify correlations between the average NDVI time series values for:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Gunbower and the flow at the Torrumbarry gauge</li>
	<li>particular vegetation types at Gunbower and the flow at the Torrumbarry gauge.</li>
</ul>

<p>Such correlations could be used to inform vegetation response models, and hence predict outcomes from environmental watering events.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong></p>

<p>GA generated the NDVI values for each 25 meter cell in all the Landsat passes over Gunbower. In-house developed Python scripts were then used to filter out the suitable tiles which were then clipped to the spatial extent of interest.</p>

<p>So that NDVI values could be compared to flow and rainfall data, the NDVI data was processed to generate a time series of average NDVI values. This applied an average NDVI value for the date the image was taken. The data was then able to be analysed for trends in association with the flow and rainfall data to identify correlations between NDVI and flow events.</p>

<p>Analysis included investigating the flow events preceding significant changes in NDVI values to determine any correlations. These were then compared to environmental water requirements flow thresholds for the area.&#160; &#160;</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story>
No match node contents append: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong></p>

<p>To determine how vegetation responds to flow events, specifically to identify correlations between the average NDVI time series values for:</p>

	<li>Gunbower and the flow at the Torrumbarry gauge</li>
	<li>particular vegetation types at Gunbower and the flow at the Torrumbarry gauge.</li>

This applied an average NDVI value for the date the image was taken. The data was then able to be analysed for trends in association with the flow and rainfall data to identify correlations between NDVI and flow events.</p>

<p>To determine how vegetation responds to flow events, specifically to identify correlations between the average NDVI time series values for:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Gunbower and the flow at the Torrumbarry gauge</li>
	<li>particular vegetation types at Gunbower and the flow at the Torrumbarry gauge.</li>

<p>Such correlations could be used to inform vegetation response models, and hence predict outcomes from environmental watering events.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong></p>

<p>GA generated the NDVI values for each 25 meter cell in all the Landsat passes over Gunbower. In-house developed Python scripts were then used to filter out the suitable tiles which were then clipped to the spatial extent of interest.</p>

This applied an average NDVI value for the date the image was taken. The data was then able to be analysed for trends in association with the flow and rainfall data to identify correlations between NDVI and flow events.</p>

attempting match on: %!12550%!
No match node contents append: %!12550%!
attempting match on: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>James Cook University researchers have used the Water Observations from Space (WOfS) data set along with elevation models&#160;to determine the least-cost pathways between permanent water sources as a means to map human dispersal and occupation in Australia during the Pleistocene (<a href="http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2016/09/21/1608470113.full.pdf">http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2016/09/21/1608470113.full.pdf</a>).&#160;</p>

<p>Australia is the driest inhabited continent on earth, but humans dispersed rapidly through much of the arid continental interior after their arrival more than 47,000 y ago. The distribution and connectedness of water across the continent, and particularly in its arid core, played a pivotal role in facilitating and focusing early human dispersal throughout the continent. We analyze the distribution and connectedness of modern permanent water across Australia. The modelled least-cost pathways between permanent water sources indicate that the observed rapid occupation of the continental interior was possible along multiple, well-watered routes and likely was driven by the depletion of high-ranked resources in each newly occupied area over time.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong></p>

<p>The Water Observations from Space (WOfS) dataset allows an assessment of the spatial distribution and permanency of standing&#160;water in the modern Australian landscape. Here we use this information, coupled with the distribution of small natural permanent water bodies (springs, gnammas, native wells, waterholes, and rockholes) compiled from the 1:250,000 topographic sheets (nationalmap.gov.au) to provide a spatially explicit assessment of the opportunities for Pleistocene human occupation of, and dispersal throughout, Australia. A connected network was produced representing the least-cost distance between water bodies and graded according to terrain cost.</p>

<p><strong>Outcomes</strong></p>

<p>The analysis suggests that permanent water, connected during periodic inundation events, providedand provideseffective conduits for human movement over thousands of kilometers through much, but not all, of the continental interior. The WOfS dataset only currently covers the Australian continent. However, it is based on satellite imagery with global coverage. The imagery can be used to derive similar products elsewhere, in turn enabling progression beyond the identification of drainage networks and basins as potential dispersal routes to a more nuanced interpretation that considers the permanency of water across a landscape. The same approach therefore can be used to develop and test models that seek to explain the rapid dispersal of modern humans out of Africa via similar periodically interconnected hydro-ecological networks.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story>

<p>Ability to quantify the scale of the daily desertification of Lake Chad over a 10-year period.</p>

<p>97% accuracy achieved without use of confidence layers to constrain results based on terrain or known surface classes.</p>

<p>Improved accuracy over&#160;Google &#160;Earth &#160;Engine &#160;Aqua &#160;Monitor.</p>

<p>Significant reduction in processing time over standard approaches.</p>

<p>Case 1, Lake Baringo (Kenya):</p>

<ul>
	<li>3.5 GHz Intel processor (4-core), 64GB RAM, Linux computer.</li>
	<li>Computation time of 1-2 minutes for an annual analysis and ~30 minutes for a full time series (11+ years) analysis.</li>
</ul>

<p>Case 2, Central Rangelands (Colombia):</p>

<ul>
	<li>AWS setup has 36 virtual CPU units, 60 GB memory, 300 GB SSD and 2 TB EBS storage.</li>
	<li>Computation time of 5 to 41 seconds for the annual products and ~6 minutes for a full time series (15 year) analysis</li>
</ul>

<p>Case 3, Lake Chad (Northern Cameroon):</p>

<ul dir="ltr">
	<li>3.5 &#160;GHz &#160;Intel &#160;processor &#160;(4-core), &#160;64GB &#160;RAM, &#160;Linux &#160;computer &#160;</li>
	<li>Computation &#160;time &#160;of &#160;38 &#160;seconds &#160;for &#160;a &#160;full &#160;time &#160;series &#160;(10 &#160;years) &#160;analysis &#160;on &#160;a &#160;1.2 &#160;GHz &#160;computer &#160;&#160;with &#160;66GB &#160;RAM, &#160;8 &#160;cores. &#160;</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_benefits><field_benefit_type>

</ul>

attempting match on: </field_data_collection><field_date_range/><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues><value><![CDATA[<p>Due to image overlap and cloud cover, the WOFS analysis results can vary across a region. However, these additional analysis results can be helpful when evaluating the final results.</p>

<p>Slightly more water is detected with the WOfS algorithm as compared to CFMASK and ACCA (water flags provided by USGS). This is due to several reasons; including WOfS consideration of mixed water-vegetation pixels and ACCA/CFMASK scene-wide statistical bias in the presence of clouds.</p>

However, these additional analysis results can be helpful when evaluating the final results.</p>

<p>Slightly more water is detected with the WOfS algorithm as compared to CFMASK and ACCA (water flags provided by USGS). This is due to several reasons; including WOfS consideration of mixed water-vegetation pixels and ACCA/CFMASK scene-wide statistical bias in the presence of clouds.</p>

attempting match on: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_societal_benefit_area>
No match node contents append: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_societal_benefit_area>
attempting match on: %!12550%!
No match node contents append: %!12550%!
attempting match on: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong></p>

<p>The CEOS Systems Engineering Office (SEO) recently completed testing of the Australian Water Observations&#160;from Space (WOfS) algorithm (Reference: Mueller,&#160;N.,&#160;et al,2016) using sample version 2 &#160;data cubes over Kenya, Colombia and Cameroon.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong></p>

<p>The WOfS analysis results were compared with the <a href="http://www.aqua%E2%80%90monitor.appspot.com">Google Earth Engine Aqua Monitor</a>. The Aqua Monitor results, also based on Landsat data, look nearly the same as the WOFS results. However, the WOFS results using a Data Cube have a significant advantage over the Aqua Monitor tool. The Landsat data is analysisready and atmospherically corrected, which leads to more accurate results. The user also has access to all of the pixel-level information for any portion of the time series. Finally, the output shows the existence of water at any time during the analysis period.</p>

<p>The WOfS results were also compared with the Landsat CFmask Water Mask. The more sophisticated 23-step band-based WOfS algorithm is able to detect water in contaminated lakes, whereas the CFmask algorithm does not detect these lakes.</p>

<p><strong>Outcomes</strong></p>

<p>Pilot achieved 97% overall accuracy with no additional filtering performed using confidence layers to constrain the results based on terrain slope or known surface classes. The SEO only used the primary 23step band-based classification for their analyses.</p>

<p>In the Lake Chad case study, all three algorithms tested showed a consistent trend in desertification (decreased surface water area) over the 10 year period. WOfS shows a trend of (minus) -17,656 square meters per day, or a loss of 1.77 hectares of water per day.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story>

<p>Ability to quantify the scale of the daily desertification of Lake Chad over a 10-year period.</p>

<p>97% accuracy achieved without use of confidence layers to constrain results based on terrain or known surface classes.</p>

<p>Improved accuracy over&#160;Google &#160;Earth &#160;Engine &#160;Aqua &#160;Monitor.</p>

<p>Significant reduction in processing time over standard approaches.</p>

<p>Case 1, Lake Baringo (Kenya):</p>

<ul>
	<li>3.5 GHz Intel processor (4-core), 64GB RAM, Linux computer.</li>
	<li>Computation time of 1-2 minutes for an annual analysis and ~30 minutes for a full time series (11+ years) analysis.</li>
</ul>

<p>Case 2, Central Rangelands (Colombia):</p>

<ul>
	<li>AWS setup has 36 virtual CPU units, 60 GB memory, 300 GB SSD and 2 TB EBS storage.</li>
	<li>Computation time of 5 to 41 seconds for the annual products and ~6 minutes for a full time series (15 year) analysis</li>
</ul>

<p>Case 3, Lake Chad (Northern Cameroon):</p>

<ul dir="ltr">
	<li>3.5 &#160;GHz &#160;Intel &#160;processor &#160;(4-core), &#160;64GB &#160;RAM, &#160;Linux &#160;computer &#160;</li>
	<li>Computation &#160;time &#160;of &#160;38 &#160;seconds &#160;for &#160;a &#160;full &#160;time &#160;series &#160;(10 &#160;years) &#160;analysis &#160;on &#160;a &#160;1.2 &#160;GHz &#160;computer &#160;&#160;with &#160;66GB &#160;RAM, &#160;8 &#160;cores. &#160;</li>
</ul>

No match node contents append: %!12544%!
attempting match on: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_societal_benefit_area>
No match node contents append: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_societal_benefit_area>
attempting match on: %!12547%!
No match node contents append: %!12547%!
attempting match on: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Overview</strong><br />
The Orange-bellied Parrot Neophema chrysogaster is a small (41-50g), critically endangered, migratory<br />
parrot that breeds in south-western Tasmania and spends the non-breeding period (April-October) in<br />
coastal areas of south-eastern Australia. During winter, Orange-bellied Parrots inhabit low lying coastal<br />
regions of southeast mainland Australia and are rarely found more than one km from the coast. The<br />
number of individuals counted during coordinated winter surveys has declined from 70-90 individuals<br />
in the 1980s (with a peak of 122 in 1983) to fewer than 20 in each year since 2001 and fewer than 10 in<br />
the last 5 years.</p>

<p>This project aimed to assess whether a reduction in Orange-bellied Parrot non-breeding habitat has<br />
occurred since 1983 which may have contributed to the species decline.</p>

<p><strong>Methods</strong><br />
Records from the Orange-bellied Parrot winter sightings database were combined with<br />
contemporaneous data from the Landsat Thematic Mapper, to develop a series of spatio-temporal<br />
models of Orange-bellied Parrot habitat for six time periods between 1983 and 2015. The pixel size of<br />
25 m x 25 m in our habitat data provides a close approximation to the scale of habitat selection by the<br />
Orange-bellied Parrot. The models predict, on a continuous scale, the likelihood that a 25 m x 25 m<br />
pixel will support Orange-bellied Parrot habitat.</p>

<p>Using the Geoscience Australia data-cube and the National Computing Infrastructure, the project team<br />
created 36 independent datasets from the Landsat chrono-sequence for each epoch. From the set of<br />
cloud-free images we derived median (and therefore stable) data for Bands 1, 3, 4, 5 and 7 for each of the summer, winter and autumn seasons at every 25 m x 25 m pixel in the study area. Various standard Landsat indices were then derived from the median images. While the winter and autumn image sets were used in the modelling at their native 25 m spatial resolution, the set of summer images was resampled to 250 m to supply landscape context data to each model. These data were supplied as independent variables because landscape configuration is likely to be a component of OBP feeding and roosting site selection (Ehmke 2009).</p>

<p>The project team used these models to explore shifts in Orange-bellied Parrot habitat availability and utilisation through time.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story>
No match node contents append: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Overview</strong><br />

These measures are relative to Mean Sea Level, and have no consistent relationship to Lowest (LAT) and Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT).</span></p>

match node contents append: <nid><value>166</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>ae6cf9c4-ea1b-4bb1-a84f-efd0c66c4656</value></uuid><vid><value>240</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Water Observations from Space Detection Algorithm 1.2</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495434983</value></created><changed><value>1495435207</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495435207</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>The water detection algorithm used to detect water from each observed pixel is based on a statistical regression tree analysis of a set of normalised difference indices and corrected band values. The regression is based on a set of water and non-water samples created by visual interpretation of 20 Landsat scenes from across Australia. The sample locations, indicated below, ensure that the logistic regression is based on the full geographic range of conditions experienced in Australia.</p>

<p>The regression analysis determined a set of best indices and bands for the analysis and the associated thresholds in each component to derive a final classification tree, producing a water/non-water classification for pixel in the Data Cube. The final water classification for each pixel is modified by Pixel Quality (see associated PQ product information) and terrain.<br />
Once the water algorithm has completed its process, the water detection for a pixel through time is combined to produce a total number of water observations for each pixel. This is compared to a total number of clear observations for the same pixel, derived from the PQ analysis. The ratio is expressed as a percentage water recurrence.</p>

<p>Confidence that a pixel depicted as having had water detected at some time is calculated by a Confidence Layer. The layer is computed by combining a set of confidence factors using a weighted sum approach, with the weightings derived by logistic regression.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description/><field_source_code/><field_version_number><value>1.2</value></field_version_number>

The regression is based on a set of water and non-water samples created by visual interpretation of 20 Landsat scenes from across Australia. The sample locations, indicated below, ensure that the logistic regression is based on the full geographic range of conditions experienced in Australia.</p>

<p>The regression analysis determined a set of best indices and bands for the analysis and the associated thresholds in each component to derive a final classification tree, producing a water/non-water classification for pixel in the Data Cube. The final water classification for each pixel is modified by Pixel Quality (see associated PQ product information) and terrain.<br />
Once the water algorithm has completed its process, the water detection for a pixel through time is combined to produce a total number of water observations for each pixel. This is compared to a total number of clear observations for the same pixel, derived from the PQ analysis. The ratio is expressed as a percentage water recurrence.</p>

<p>Confidence that a pixel depicted as having had water detected at some time is calculated by a Confidence Layer. The layer is computed by combining a set of confidence factors using a weighted sum approach, with the weightings derived by logistic regression.</p>
