match node contents append: <nid><value>169</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>e8c34358-8cb2-49b8-b7a7-d78862d6487b</value></uuid><vid><value>264</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Fractional Cover Algorithm 1.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495502673</value></created><changed><value>1495502806</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495502806</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p><span>Fractional Cover provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent.<span>&#160; </span>It is generated using the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and described in Scarth et al. (2010).</span></p>

<p>Fractional cover data &#160;can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition.<span><span> This information could enable </span></span>policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>The fractional cover unmixing algorthim uses the spectral signature for a picture element (pixel) to break it up into three parts or fractions. This is based on field work identifying the spectral characteristics of each of the fractions. The three fractions are green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare soil. The green fraction includes leaves and grass, the non-photosynthetic includes branches, dry grass and dead leaf litter, and the bare soil fraction includes bare soil or rock.</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The method used to generate this data was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and implemented by Geoscience Australia over the Landsat archive which has been pre-processed to surface reflectance (ARG25). The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction  the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis, <em>Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</em>, viewed 4 January 2011, </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland, <em>Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</em>, viewed 4 January 2011, </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://data.auscover.org.au/xwiki/bin/view/Product+pages/Landsat+Fractional+Cover">http://data.auscover.org.au/xwiki/bin/view/Product+pages/Landsat+Fractional+Cover</a></span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number><value>1.0</value></field_version_number>

(2010).</span></p>

<p>Fractional cover data &#160;can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition.<span><span> This information could enable </span></span>policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>The fractional cover unmixing algorthim uses the spectral signature for a picture element (pixel) to break it up into three parts or fractions. This is based on field work identifying the spectral characteristics of each of the fractions. The three fractions are green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare soil. The green fraction includes leaves and grass, the non-photosynthetic includes branches, dry grass and dead leaf litter, and the bare soil fraction includes bare soil or rock.</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The method used to generate this data was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and implemented by Geoscience Australia over the Landsat archive which has been pre-processed to surface reflectance (ARG25). The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction  the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis, <em>Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</em>, viewed 4 January 2011, </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland, <em>Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</em>, viewed 4 January 2011, </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://data.auscover.org.au/xwiki/bin/view/Product+pages/Landsat+Fractional+Cover">http://data.auscover.org.au/xwiki/bin/view/Product+pages/Landsat+Fractional+Cover</a></span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number><value>1.0</value></field_version_number>

	-<uuid><value>e8c34358-8cb2-49b8-b7a7-d78862d6487b</value></uuid><vid><value>264</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Fractional Cover Algorithm 1.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495502673</value></created><changed><value>1495502806</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495502806</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p><span>Fractional Cover provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent.<span>&#160; </span>It is generated using the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and described in Scarth et al. (2010).</span></p>

<p>Fractional cover data &#160;can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition.<span><span> This information could enable </span></span>policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>The fractional cover unmixing algorthim uses the spectral signature for a picture element (pixel) to break it up into three parts or fractions. This is based on field work identifying the spectral characteristics of each of the fractions. The three fractions are green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare soil. The green fraction includes leaves and grass, the non-photosynthetic includes branches, dry grass and dead leaf litter, and the bare soil fraction includes bare soil or rock.</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The method used to generate this data was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and implemented by Geoscience Australia over the Landsat archive which has been pre-processed to surface reflectance (ARG25). The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction  the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis, <em>Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</em>, viewed 4 January 2011, </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland, <em>Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</em>, viewed 4 January 2011, </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://data.auscover.org.au/xwiki/bin/view/Product+pages/Landsat+Fractional+Cover">http://data.auscover.org.au/xwiki/bin/view/Product+pages/Landsat+Fractional+Cover</a></span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number><value>1.0</value></field_version_number>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>f48f22df-8540-48c0-a824-cbbe93ec67fa</value></uuid><vid><value>272</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Dynamic Land Cover Algorithm</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495506358</value></created><changed><value>1495506676</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495506676</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images><target_id>15</target_id><alt>DLCD Processing Workflow</alt><title></title><width>480</width><height>646</height><target_type>file</target_type><target_uuid>b442e3d9-ad83-45fd-9b40-987cea1a77fe</target_uuid><url>http://cmi.ga.gov.au/sites/default/files/2017-05/DLCD1_Flowchart.jpg</url></field_images><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose/><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCD classification methodology and process along with major algorithms used are described in detail in the National Dynamic Land Cover Dataset - Technical Report (Lymburner et al, 2011).</p>

<p>The DLCD is based on an analysis of a 16-day EVI composite collected at 250 metre resolution using the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) satellite for the period 2000 to 2008.</p>

<p>The MODIS time series for each pixel was analysed using an innovative technique which reduced each time series into 12 coefficients based on the statistical, phenological and seasonal characteristics of each pixel.<br />
These coefficients were then clustered using a support vector clustering algorithm and the resultant classes were labelled using agreed National data supplied from catchment scale land use mapping and the National Vegetation Information System (NVIS).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number><value>1.0</value></field_version_number>

<p>The DLCD is based on an analysis of a 16-day EVI composite collected at 250 metre resolution using the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) satellite for the period 2000 to 2008.</p>

<p>The DLCD is based on an analysis of a 16-day EVI composite collected at 250 metre resolution using the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) satellite for the period 2000 to 2008.</p>

<p>The MODIS time series for each pixel was analysed using an innovative technique which reduced each time series into 12 coefficients based on the statistical, phenological and seasonal characteristics of each pixel.<br />
These coefficients were then clustered using a support vector clustering algorithm and the resultant classes were labelled using agreed National data supplied from catchment scale land use mapping and the National Vegetation Information System (NVIS).</p>

<ul>

	<li>Monitoring land surface motion risks</li>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe's Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-1 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dap.nci.org.au/thredds/remoteCatalogService?catalog=http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fj7/Copernicus/Sentinel-1/catalog.xml</uri><title>THREDDS</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe's Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-1 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dap.nci.org.au/thredds/remoteCatalogService?catalog=http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fj7/Copernicus/Sentinel-1/catalog.xml</uri><title>THREDDS</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>

attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>Sentinel-1 Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data products are acquired in Stripmap (SM), Interferometric Wide swath (IW), Extra Wide swath (EW) and Wave (WV) mode and are distributed at three levels of processing:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Level-0: SAR raw data</li>
	<li>Level-1: Single Look Complex (SLC) data comprising complex imagery with amplitude and phase, and Ground Range Detected (GRD) data with multi-looked intensity only;</li>
	<li>Level-2: Ocean (OCN) data for retrieved geophysical parameters of the ocean.</li>
</ul>

<p>More information at: <a href="https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-1-sar/product-types-processing-levels">https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-1-sar/product...</a></p>

<p>A single SENTINEL-1 satellite is potentially able to map the global landmasses in the Interferometric Wide swath mode once every 12 days, in a single pass (ascending or descending). The two-satellite constellation offers a 6 day exact repeat cycle at the equator. Since the orbit track spacing varies with latitude, the revisit rate is significantly greater at higher latitudes than at the equator.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>Sentinel-1 Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data products are acquired in Stripmap (SM), Interferometric Wide swath (IW), Extra Wide swath (EW) and Wave (WV) mode and are distributed at three levels of processing:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Level-0: SAR raw data</li>
	<li>Level-1: Single Look Complex (SLC) data comprising complex imagery with amplitude and phase, and Ground Range Detected (GRD) data with multi-looked intensity only;</li>
	<li>Level-2: Ocean (OCN) data for retrieved geophysical parameters of the ocean.</li>
</ul>

<p>More information at: <a href="https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-1-sar/product-types-processing-levels">https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-1-sar/product...</a></p>

<p>A single SENTINEL-1 satellite is potentially able to map the global landmasses in the Interferometric Wide swath mode once every 12 days, in a single pass (ascending or descending). The two-satellite constellation offers a 6 day exact repeat cycle at the equator. Since the orbit track spacing varies with latitude, the revisit rate is significantly greater at higher latitudes than at the equator.</p>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_access_constraints><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-1 SAR</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Potential applications are:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Monitoring sea ice zones and the Arctic environment, and surveillance of marine environment.</li>
	<li>Monitoring land surface motion risks</li>
	<li>Mapping of land surfaces: forest, water and soil</li>
	<li>Mapping in support of humanitarian aid in crisis situations</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe's Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-1 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dap.nci.org.au/thredds/remoteCatalogService?catalog=http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fj7/Copernicus/Sentinel-1/catalog.xml</uri><title>THREDDS</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_custodian><field_data_description/><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-05-09T06:29:29</value><end_value>2017-05-09T06:29:29</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources/><field_data_source_contact>

	-%!113%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>Sentinel-1 Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data products are acquired in Stripmap (SM), Interferometric Wide swath (IW), Extra Wide swath (EW) and Wave (WV) mode and are distributed at three levels of processing:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Level-0: SAR raw data</li>
	<li>Level-1: Single Look Complex (SLC) data comprising complex imagery with amplitude and phase, and Ground Range Detected (GRD) data with multi-looked intensity only;</li>
	<li>Level-2: Ocean (OCN) data for retrieved geophysical parameters of the ocean.</li>
</ul>

<p>More information at: <a href="https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-1-sar/product-types-processing-levels">https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-1-sar/product...</a></p>

<p>A single SENTINEL-1 satellite is potentially able to map the global landmasses in the Interferometric Wide swath mode once every 12 days, in a single pass (ascending or descending). The two-satellite constellation offers a 6 day exact repeat cycle at the equator. Since the orbit track spacing varies with latitude, the revisit rate is significantly greater at higher latitudes than at the equator.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

<ul>
	<li>Monitoring land cover change for environmental monitoring</li>
	<li>Agricultural applications, such as crop monitoring and management to help food security</li>
	<li>Detailed vegetation and forest monitoring and parameter generation (e.g. leaf area index, chlorophyll concentration, carbon mass estimations)</li>
	<li>Observation of coastal zones (marine environmental monitoring, coastal zone mapping)</li>
	<li>Inland water monitoring</li>
	<li>Glacier monitoring, ice extent mapping, snow cover monitoring</li>
	<li>Flood mapping &amp; management (risk analysis, loss assessment, disaster management during floods)</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe's Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-2 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe's Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-2 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dap.nci.org.au/thredds/remoteCatalogService?catalog=http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fj7/Copernicus/Sentinel-1/catalog.xml</uri><title>THREDDS</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>

No match node contents append: </field_custodian><field_data_description/><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-05-09T06:29:29</value><end_value>2017-05-09T06:29:29</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources/><field_data_source_contact>

attempting match on: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>

attempting match on: %!113%!
No match node contents append: %!113%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Sentinel-2 mission will offer the following capabilities:</p>

<ul>
	<li>systematic global coverage of land surfaces from 56?S to 84?N, including coastal waters;</li>
	<li>high revisit frequency: every five days at the equator under the same viewing conditions;</li>
	<li>a wide field of view: 290 km.</li>
</ul>

<p>Sentinel-2 MultiSpectral Instrument (MSI) has 13 spectral bands in the visible/near infrared (VNIR) and short wave infrared spectral range (SWIR). In particular:</p>

<p>Sentinel-2 Bands/ Central Wavelength (?m) /Resolution (m)<br />
Band 1 - Coastal aerosol / 0.443 / 60<br />
Band 2 - Blue / 0.490 /10<br />
Band 3 - Green / 0.560 / 10<br />
Band 4 - Red / 0.665 / 10<br />
Band 5 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.705/ 20<br />
Band 6 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.740 / 20<br />
Band 7 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.783 / 20<br />
Band 8 - NIR / 0.842 / 10<br />
Band 8A - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.865 / 20<br />
Band 9 - Water vapour / 0.945 / 60<br />
Band 10 - SWIR - Cirrus / 1.375 / 60<br />
Band 11 - SWIR / 1.610 / 20<br />
Band 12 - SWIR / 2.190 / 20</p>

<p>The average observation time per orbit is 17 min, while the peak value is 32 min. The combination of the large swath and broad spectral range, coupled with the requirement for global and continuous acquisition with a high revisit frequency, will lead to the generation of about 1.6 TBytes of compressed raw image data each day from the constellation of two satellites.</p>

<p>Sentinel-2's multi-spectral imager undertakes systematic acquisition in a single observation mode. Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-2 MSI will distribute Level-1C product only: Top of atmosphere reflectances in fixed cartographic geometry (combined UTM projection and WGS84 ellipsoid). Level-1C images are a set of tiles of 100 km2, each of which is approximately 500 MB. These products contain applied radiometric and geometric corrections (including orthorectification and spatial registration). More information at: <a href="https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product-types/level-1c">https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product...</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Sentinel-2 mission will offer the following capabilities:</p>

<ul>
	<li>systematic global coverage of land surfaces from 56?S to 84?N, including coastal waters;</li>
	<li>high revisit frequency: every five days at the equator under the same viewing conditions;</li>
	<li>a wide field of view: 290 km.</li>
</ul>

<p>Sentinel-2 MultiSpectral Instrument (MSI) has 13 spectral bands in the visible/near infrared (VNIR) and short wave infrared spectral range (SWIR). In particular:</p>

<p>Sentinel-2 Bands/ Central Wavelength (?m) /Resolution (m)<br />
Band 1 - Coastal aerosol / 0.443 / 60<br />
Band 2 - Blue / 0.490 /10<br />
Band 3 - Green / 0.560 / 10<br />
Band 4 - Red / 0.665 / 10<br />
Band 5 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.705/ 20<br />
Band 6 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.740 / 20<br />
Band 7 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.783 / 20<br />
Band 8 - NIR / 0.842 / 10<br />
Band 8A - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.865 / 20<br />
Band 9 - Water vapour / 0.945 / 60<br />
Band 10 - SWIR - Cirrus / 1.375 / 60<br />
Band 11 - SWIR / 1.610 / 20<br />
Band 12 - SWIR / 2.190 / 20</p>

<p>The average observation time per orbit is 17 min, while the peak value is 32 min. The combination of the large swath and broad spectral range, coupled with the requirement for global and continuous acquisition with a high revisit frequency, will lead to the generation of about 1.6 TBytes of compressed raw image data each day from the constellation of two satellites.</p>

<p>Sentinel-2's multi-spectral imager undertakes systematic acquisition in a single observation mode. Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-2 MSI will distribute Level-1C product only: Top of atmosphere reflectances in fixed cartographic geometry (combined UTM projection and WGS84 ellipsoid). Level-1C images are a set of tiles of 100 km2, each of which is approximately 500 MB. These products contain applied radiometric and geometric corrections (including orthorectification and spatial registration). More information at: <a href="https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product-types/level-1c">https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product...</a></p>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_access_constraints><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-2 MSI</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Examples for applications include:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Monitoring land cover change for environmental monitoring</li>
	<li>Agricultural applications, such as crop monitoring and management to help food security</li>
	<li>Detailed vegetation and forest monitoring and parameter generation (e.g. leaf area index, chlorophyll concentration, carbon mass estimations)</li>
	<li>Observation of coastal zones (marine environmental monitoring, coastal zone mapping)</li>
	<li>Inland water monitoring</li>
	<li>Glacier monitoring, ice extent mapping, snow cover monitoring</li>
	<li>Flood mapping &amp; management (risk analysis, loss assessment, disaster management during floods)</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe's Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-2 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dap.nci.org.au/thredds/remoteCatalogService?catalog=http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fj7/Copernicus/Sentinel-1/catalog.xml</uri><title>THREDDS</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_custodian><field_data_description/><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-05-09T06:29:29</value><end_value>2017-05-09T06:29:29</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources/><field_data_source_contact>
	-%!25%!
	-</field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Sentinel-2 mission will offer the following capabilities:</p>

<ul>
	<li>systematic global coverage of land surfaces from 56?S to 84?N, including coastal waters;</li>
	<li>high revisit frequency: every five days at the equator under the same viewing conditions;</li>
	<li>a wide field of view: 290 km.</li>
</ul>

<p>Sentinel-2 MultiSpectral Instrument (MSI) has 13 spectral bands in the visible/near infrared (VNIR) and short wave infrared spectral range (SWIR). In particular:</p>

<p>Sentinel-2 Bands/ Central Wavelength (?m) /Resolution (m)<br />
Band 1 - Coastal aerosol / 0.443 / 60<br />
Band 2 - Blue / 0.490 /10<br />
Band 3 - Green / 0.560 / 10<br />
Band 4 - Red / 0.665 / 10<br />
Band 5 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.705/ 20<br />
Band 6 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.740 / 20<br />
Band 7 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.783 / 20<br />
Band 8 - NIR / 0.842 / 10<br />
Band 8A - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.865 / 20<br />
Band 9 - Water vapour / 0.945 / 60<br />
Band 10 - SWIR - Cirrus / 1.375 / 60<br />
Band 11 - SWIR / 1.610 / 20<br />
Band 12 - SWIR / 2.190 / 20</p>

<p>The average observation time per orbit is 17 min, while the peak value is 32 min. The combination of the large swath and broad spectral range, coupled with the requirement for global and continuous acquisition with a high revisit frequency, will lead to the generation of about 1.6 TBytes of compressed raw image data each day from the constellation of two satellites.</p>

<p>Sentinel-2's multi-spectral imager undertakes systematic acquisition in a single observation mode. Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-2 MSI will distribute Level-1C product only: Top of atmosphere reflectances in fixed cartographic geometry (combined UTM projection and WGS84 ellipsoid). Level-1C images are a set of tiles of 100 km2, each of which is approximately 500 MB. These products contain applied radiometric and geometric corrections (including orthorectification and spatial registration). More information at: <a href="https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product-types/level-1c">https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product...</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-3 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>

attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Sentinel-2 mission will offer the following capabilities:</p>

<ul>
	<li>systematic global coverage of land surfaces from 56?S to 84?N, including coastal waters;</li>
	<li>high revisit frequency: every five days at the equator under the same viewing conditions;</li>
	<li>a wide field of view: 290 km.</li>
</ul>

<p>Sentinel-2 MultiSpectral Instrument (MSI) has 13 spectral bands in the visible/near infrared (VNIR) and short wave infrared spectral range (SWIR). In particular:</p>

<p>Sentinel-2 Bands/ Central Wavelength (?m) /Resolution (m)<br />
Band 1 - Coastal aerosol / 0.443 / 60<br />
Band 2 - Blue / 0.490 /10<br />
Band 3 - Green / 0.560 / 10<br />
Band 4 - Red / 0.665 / 10<br />
Band 5 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.705/ 20<br />
Band 6 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.740 / 20<br />
Band 7 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.783 / 20<br />
Band 8 - NIR / 0.842 / 10<br />
Band 8A - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.865 / 20<br />
Band 9 - Water vapour / 0.945 / 60<br />
Band 10 - SWIR - Cirrus / 1.375 / 60<br />
Band 11 - SWIR / 1.610 / 20<br />
Band 12 - SWIR / 2.190 / 20</p>

<p>The average observation time per orbit is 17 min, while the peak value is 32 min. The combination of the large swath and broad spectral range, coupled with the requirement for global and continuous acquisition with a high revisit frequency, will lead to the generation of about 1.6 TBytes of compressed raw image data each day from the constellation of two satellites.</p>

<p>Sentinel-2's multi-spectral imager undertakes systematic acquisition in a single observation mode. Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-2 MSI will distribute Level-1C product only: Top of atmosphere reflectances in fixed cartographic geometry (combined UTM projection and WGS84 ellipsoid). Level-1C images are a set of tiles of 100 km2, each of which is approximately 500 MB. These products contain applied radiometric and geometric corrections (including orthorectification and spatial registration). More information at: <a href="https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product-types/level-1c">https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product...</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

<ul>
	<li>systematic global coverage of land surfaces from 56?S to 84?N, including coastal waters;</li>
	<li>high revisit frequency: every five days at the equator under the same viewing conditions;</li>
	<li>a wide field of view: 290 km.</li>
</ul>

<p>Sentinel-2 MultiSpectral Instrument (MSI) has 13 spectral bands in the visible/near infrared (VNIR) and short wave infrared spectral range (SWIR). In particular:</p>

<p>Sentinel-2 Bands/ Central Wavelength (?m) /Resolution (m)<br />
Band 1 - Coastal aerosol / 0.443 / 60<br />
Band 2 - Blue / 0.490 /10<br />
Band 3 - Green / 0.560 / 10<br />
Band 4 - Red / 0.665 / 10<br />
Band 5 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.705/ 20<br />
Band 6 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.740 / 20<br />
Band 7 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.783 / 20<br />
Band 8 - NIR / 0.842 / 10<br />
Band 8A - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.865 / 20<br />
Band 9 - Water vapour / 0.945 / 60<br />
Band 10 - SWIR - Cirrus / 1.375 / 60<br />
Band 11 - SWIR / 1.610 / 20<br />
Band 12 - SWIR / 2.190 / 20</p>

<p>The average observation time per orbit is 17 min, while the peak value is 32 min. The combination of the large swath and broad spectral range, coupled with the requirement for global and continuous acquisition with a high revisit frequency, will lead to the generation of about 1.6 TBytes of compressed raw image data each day from the constellation of two satellites.</p>

<p>Sentinel-2's multi-spectral imager undertakes systematic acquisition in a single observation mode. Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-2 MSI will distribute Level-1C product only: Top of atmosphere reflectances in fixed cartographic geometry (combined UTM projection and WGS84 ellipsoid). Level-1C images are a set of tiles of 100 km2, each of which is approximately 500 MB. These products contain applied radiometric and geometric corrections (including orthorectification and spatial registration). ]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_access_constraints><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-3-OCLI</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The observations acquired by the mission will be used to in conjunction with other ocean-observing missions to contribute to the Global Ocean Observing System (GOOS) which aims to create a permanent system of ocean observation:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Ocean colour and land reflectance data</li>
	<li>Sea, land and ice surface temperature</li>
	<li>Active fire and burnt area monitoring</li>
	<li>Sea surface topography data</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe's Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-3 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dap.nci.org.au/thredds/remoteCatalogService?catalog=http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fj7/Copernicus/Sentinel-1/catalog.xml</uri><title>THREDDS</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_custodian><field_data_description/><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-05-09T06:29:29</value><end_value>2017-05-09T06:29:29</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources/><field_data_source_contact>
	-%!25%!
	-</field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Sentinel-2 mission will offer the following capabilities:</p>

<ul>
	<li>systematic global coverage of land surfaces from 56?S to 84?N, including coastal waters;</li>
	<li>high revisit frequency: every five days at the equator under the same viewing conditions;</li>
	<li>a wide field of view: 290 km.</li>
</ul>

<p>Sentinel-2 MultiSpectral Instrument (MSI) has 13 spectral bands in the visible/near infrared (VNIR) and short wave infrared spectral range (SWIR). In particular:</p>

<p>Sentinel-2 Bands/ Central Wavelength (?m) /Resolution (m)<br />
Band 1 - Coastal aerosol / 0.443 / 60<br />
Band 2 - Blue / 0.490 /10<br />
Band 3 - Green / 0.560 / 10<br />
Band 4 - Red / 0.665 / 10<br />
Band 5 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.705/ 20<br />
Band 6 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.740 / 20<br />
Band 7 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.783 / 20<br />
Band 8 - NIR / 0.842 / 10<br />
Band 8A - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.865 / 20<br />
Band 9 - Water vapour / 0.945 / 60<br />
Band 10 - SWIR - Cirrus / 1.375 / 60<br />
Band 11 - SWIR / 1.610 / 20<br />
Band 12 - SWIR / 2.190 / 20</p>

<p>The average observation time per orbit is 17 min, while the peak value is 32 min. The combination of the large swath and broad spectral range, coupled with the requirement for global and continuous acquisition with a high revisit frequency, will lead to the generation of about 1.6 TBytes of compressed raw image data each day from the constellation of two satellites.</p>

<p>Sentinel-2's multi-spectral imager undertakes systematic acquisition in a single observation mode. Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-2 MSI will distribute Level-1C product only: Top of atmosphere reflectances in fixed cartographic geometry (combined UTM projection and WGS84 ellipsoid). Level-1C images are a set of tiles of 100 km2, each of which is approximately 500 MB. These products contain applied radiometric and geometric corrections (including orthorectification and spatial registration). More information at: <a href="https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product-types/level-1c">https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product...</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

match node contents append: <nid><value>178</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>08154d8b-cb3c-4516-956d-c020b98ed026</value></uuid><vid><value>342</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>a889e941-fb41-4d04-aa76-0d33f0033059</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>DLCD Time Series Analysis</value></title><uid><target_id>27</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>e7b560a4-0a39-4070-a52f-e2491bdb182a</target_uuid><url>/user/27</url></uid><created><value>1495692431</value></created><changed><value>1495692431</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495692431</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>27</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>e7b560a4-0a39-4070-a52f-e2491bdb182a</target_uuid><url>/user/27</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_process_description><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>The MODIS EVI data cube is analysed to characterise the time series trends for each pixel. This process represents the time series in a form that allows it to be classified more easily. The initial characterisation of the time series data involves three steps: </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>(1) Piece-wise Linear Segmentation</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The time series segmentation algorithm approximates a time series using a series of piece-wise linear segments. Each segment is characteristic of a sequence of environmental behaviour that typifies the associated land cover class. </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>(2) Sub-sequence Discretization </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>Each segment is then detailed by three values describing its starting value, slope and length to form a vector input to the classification process.</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>(3) Sequence Labelling</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The sequences are then clustered into groups of like behaviour, and each group then assigned a behaviour label. A time series is thus transformed from a large collection of varying values to a smaller set of behaviour types, joined as a kind of DNA string representing the pixel through time. </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>(4) Markov modelling</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The DNA string provides an initial class which is then modelled as a dynamic Markov Chain to estimate the likelihood that a particular land cover class would occur after any other land cover class. </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>(5) Bayesian classification</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The final class is then assigned using a Bayesian classifier.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_process_description>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>1f3a29cf-efbd-42b0-9682-fb185f8a277f</value></uuid><vid><value>347</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>DLCD classification (Lymburner et al., 2011)</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495773965</value></created><changed><value>1495774700</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495774700</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>The DLCD classification algorithm provides a basis for reporting on change and trends in vegetation cover and extent. Information about land cover dynamics is essential to understanding and addressing a range of national challenges such as drought, salinity, water availability and ecosystem health.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCD analysis<span><span><span> uses an innovative technique which reduces each time series into 12 coefficients based on the statistical, phenological and seasonal characteristics of each pixel. These coefficients were then clustered using a support vector clustering algorithm and the resultant classes were labelled using agreed National data supplied from catchment scale land use mapping and the National Vegetation Information System (NVIS). </span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>The DLCD classification methodology and process along with major algorithms used are described in detail in the National Dynamic Land Cover Dataset - Technical Report (</span></span></span><span><span><span>Ly</span></span></span><span><span><span>mburner et al, 2011).</span></span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>

This has application in emergency management and risk assessment.<br />
The product has many secondary uses. For example the WO_25_2.1.5 product provides an indication on the permanence of surface water in the Australian landscape by showing where water is observed rarely in comparison to where it is often observed. This has application in water management and mapping. WO_25_2.1.5 has also been used for wetland analyses, water connectivity and surface-ground water relationships.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Water Observations from Space product (WO_25_2.1.5) is a key component of the National Flood Risk Information Portal (NFRIP), developed by Geoscience Australia (GA). The objective of Water Observations from Space is to analyse GA's historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past.</p>

The objective of Water Observations from Space is to analyse GA's historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past.</p>

No match node contents append: %!113%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress><value>50</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-07-31</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>WO_25_2.1.5 shows water observed for every Landsat-5, Landsat-7 and Landsat-8 image across Australia (excluding External Territories) for the period of 1987 to 2016. The dataset is updated quarterly and is expected to increase in update frequency in the future so that as a satellite acquires data, it will automatically be analysed for the presence of water and added to the WO_25_2.1.5 product in near real time.<br />
Data is provided as Water Observation Feature Layers (WOFLs), in a 1 to 1 relationship with the input satellite data. Hence there is one WOFL for each NBAR dataset processed for the occurrence of water. The details of the content of each WOFL is below.<br />
In the future, WO_25_2.1.5 will be updated as new data are added. This is potentially possible because the dataset is produced using the Australian Geoscience Data Cube, containing GA's entire Australian Landsat archive in a supercomputing environment at the National Computational Infrastructure at the Australian National University.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

Data is provided as Water Observation Feature Layers (WOFLs), in a 1 to 1 relationship with the input satellite data. Hence there is one WOFL for each NBAR dataset processed for the occurrence of water. The details of the content of each WOFL is below.<br />
In the future, WO_25_2.1.5 will be updated as new data are added. This is potentially possible because the dataset is produced using the Australian Geoscience Data Cube, containing GA's entire Australian Landsat archive in a supercomputing environment at the National Computational Infrastructure at the Australian National University.</p>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>af76fe11-1985-4015-965d-21757841ddf8</value></uuid><vid><value>360</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>WO_25_1.1.2</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495433829</value></created><changed><value>1496111892</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496111892</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Water Observations from Space (WOfS) 25m 1.2</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The primary purpose of the WOfS product is to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. This has application in emergency management and risk assessment.<br />
It is anticipated that WOfS will have many secondary uses. For example the WOfS product provides an indication on the permanence of surface water in the Australian landscape by showing where water is observed rarely in comparison to where it is often observed. This has application in water management and mapping.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Water Observations from Space product (WOfS) is a key component of the National Flood Risk Information Portal (NFRIP)2, being developed by Geoscience Australia (GA). The objective of WOfS is to analyse GAs historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past.</p>

<p>WOfS is being developed in parallel with the National Flood Studies Database system which will provide Flood Study documentation and reports to a wide range of users. Both systems will be delivered via the internet through the NFRIP portal.</p>

<p>Satellite imagery has been used to map floods around the world for several years. Organisations such as the Colorado Flood Observatory in the USA and several state-based agencies in Australia regularly provide satellite-based flood extents for major flood events. GA developed a flood mapping methodology in 2008-2009 that was extensively used for the major Australian flood events since 2010, providing emergency service agencies with regional flood extent information.</p>

<p>The Phase 1 outputs from the NFRIP were delivered to the public in November 2012, including a proof of concept of WOfS. This displayed surface water extents for three study areas, including the original derived extents and the cumulative summary product. Subsequent stakeholder feedback has shown that the most desirable information is the summary product, providing and understanding of the long term dynamics of surface water.</p>

<p>The Phase 2 outputs from the NFRIP (release in April 2014), include this WOfS product, which will be accessible to the public as a web service from the NFRIP.</p>

<p><em><strong>Confidence Level</strong></em></p>

<p>Reviews of prototype products identified the need to indicate the level of confidence for the surface water observations. The confidence level will help the user to distinguish between unusual but valid water detections (such as flood plains which might only be observed as water once in the 15 year interval) and false positives which can be caused, for instance, by steep shady slopes.</p>

<p>The confidence level was determined through a multiple logistic regression of water observations against several factors that would either support or contra-indicate the finding of water being present at the site.</p>

<p>The factors comprise:</p>

<p><strong>MrVBF</strong>, a multi-resolution valley bottom flatness product (Gallant et al., 2012) derived from SRTM as part of the Terrestrial Ecosystems Research Network. Surface water pixels identified in valley bottoms were more likely to be positively detected.</p>

<p><strong>Slope</strong> derived from SRTM Digital Surface Models. Water pixels on a slope were considered less plausible than those on a flat surface.</p>

<p><strong>MODIS Open Water Likelihood (OWL)</strong> (Ticehurst et al, 2010) provides a plausibility based an independent water detection algorithm employing the MODIS sensor. If both detection algorithms agree on the presence of a surface water pixel, there is a greater plausibility that the detection is correct.</p>

<p><strong>Australian Hydrological Geospatial Fabric (Geofabric)</strong> is a GIS of hydrological features derived from manually interpreted topographic map grids. If known hydrologic features (pixels) from GeoFabric coincide with detected water pixels, the plausibility of detection is greater.</p>

<p><strong>P</strong>, the number of observations of water as a fraction of the number of clear observations of the target pixel. P is high for more permanent water bodies.</p>

<p><strong>Built-Up areas</strong> indicating areas of dense urban development. In such areas the water detection algorithm struggles to cope with the deep shadows cast by multi-story buildings and the generally noisy spectral response created by structures. The Built-Up layer is derived from the Ausralian Bureau of Statistics ASGS 2011 dataset, for urban centres of populations of 100 000 and over.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>af76fe11-1985-4015-965d-21757841ddf8</value></uuid><vid><value>360</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>WO_25_1.1.2</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495433829</value></created><changed><value>1496111892</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496111892</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Water Observations from Space (WOfS) 25m 1.2</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The primary purpose of the WOfS product is to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. This has application in emergency management and risk assessment.<br />
It is anticipated that WOfS will have many secondary uses. For example the WOfS product provides an indication on the permanence of surface water in the Australian landscape by showing where water is observed rarely in comparison to where it is often observed. This has application in water management and mapping.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Water Observations from Space product (WOfS) is a key component of the National Flood Risk Information Portal (NFRIP)2, being developed by Geoscience Australia (GA). The objective of WOfS is to analyse GAs historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past.</p>

<p>WOfS is being developed in parallel with the National Flood Studies Database system which will provide Flood Study documentation and reports to a wide range of users. Both systems will be delivered via the internet through the NFRIP portal.</p>

<p>Satellite imagery has been used to map floods around the world for several years. Organisations such as the Colorado Flood Observatory in the USA and several state-based agencies in Australia regularly provide satellite-based flood extents for major flood events. GA developed a flood mapping methodology in 2008-2009 that was extensively used for the major Australian flood events since 2010, providing emergency service agencies with regional flood extent information.</p>

<p>The Phase 1 outputs from the NFRIP were delivered to the public in November 2012, including a proof of concept of WOfS. This displayed surface water extents for three study areas, including the original derived extents and the cumulative summary product. Subsequent stakeholder feedback has shown that the most desirable information is the summary product, providing and understanding of the long term dynamics of surface water.</p>

<p>The Phase 2 outputs from the NFRIP (release in April 2014), include this WOfS product, which will be accessible to the public as a web service from the NFRIP.</p>

<p><em><strong>Confidence Level</strong></em></p>

<p>Reviews of prototype products identified the need to indicate the level of confidence for the surface water observations. The confidence level will help the user to distinguish between unusual but valid water detections (such as flood plains which might only be observed as water once in the 15 year interval) and false positives which can be caused, for instance, by steep shady slopes.</p>

<p>The confidence level was determined through a multiple logistic regression of water observations against several factors that would either support or contra-indicate the finding of water being present at the site.</p>

<p>The factors comprise:</p>

<p><strong>MrVBF</strong>, a multi-resolution valley bottom flatness product (Gallant et al., 2012) derived from SRTM as part of the Terrestrial Ecosystems Research Network. Surface water pixels identified in valley bottoms were more likely to be positively detected.</p>

<p><strong>Slope</strong> derived from SRTM Digital Surface Models. Water pixels on a slope were considered less plausible than those on a flat surface.</p>

<p><strong>MODIS Open Water Likelihood (OWL)</strong> (Ticehurst et al, 2010) provides a plausibility based an independent water detection algorithm employing the MODIS sensor. If both detection algorithms agree on the presence of a surface water pixel, there is a greater plausibility that the detection is correct.</p>

<p><strong>Australian Hydrological Geospatial Fabric (Geofabric)</strong> is a GIS of hydrological features derived from manually interpreted topographic map grids. If known hydrologic features (pixels) from GeoFabric coincide with detected water pixels, the plausibility of detection is greater.</p>

<p><strong>P</strong>, the number of observations of water as a fraction of the number of clear observations of the target pixel. P is high for more permanent water bodies.</p>

<p><strong>Built-Up areas</strong> indicating areas of dense urban development. In such areas the water detection algorithm struggles to cope with the deep shadows cast by multi-story buildings and the generally noisy spectral response created by structures. The Built-Up layer is derived from the Ausralian Bureau of Statistics ASGS 2011 dataset, for urban centres of populations of 100 000 and over.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
attempting match on: %!113%!
No match node contents append: %!113%!
attempting match on: </field_custodian><field_data_description><value><![CDATA[<p>Water Observations from Space is supplied as a WMS web service through the Portal of the National Flood Risk Information Project: http://www.ga.gov.au/hazards/flood.html</p>

<p>The service provides an Australia-wide coverage of the summary of water observations through time draped over a Google-Earth background. The coverage may be interrogated to provide information on:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Number of times a location was observed clearly by satellite</li>
	<li>Number of times water was indicated at the location</li>
	<li>The percentage of clear observations for which water was indicated</li>
	<li>The confidence that the water observation at the location is correct.</li>
</ul>

<p>Technical users may access each information item as a WMS directly from:<br />
http://eos.ga.gov.au/geoserver/wms, or browse the available layers in an OpenLayers interface at:<br />
http://eos.ga.gov.au/geoserver/web.</p>

<p>The available WMS sevices corresponding to each of the available information layers are:</p>

<ul>
	<li>ClearObservations_version : the number of clear satellite observations</li>
	<li>WaterObservations_version : the number of water observations</li>
	<li>WaterSummary_version : the percentage of clear observations for which water was indicated</li>
	<li>Confidence_version : the confidence that the indicated water is correct</li>
	<li>FilteredSummary_version : the Water Summary filtered to display only those areas for which confidence was above zero.</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_data_description><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-05-22T06:17:09</value><end_value>2017-05-22T06:17:09</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources>

<p>The service provides an Australia-wide coverage of the summary of water observations through time draped over a Google-Earth background. The coverage may be interrogated to provide information on:</p>

	<li>Number of times a location was observed clearly by satellite</li>
	<li>Number of times water was indicated at the location</li>
	<li>The percentage of clear observations for which water was indicated</li>
	<li>The confidence that the water observation at the location is correct.</li>

http://eos.ga.gov.au/geoserver/wms, or browse the available layers in an OpenLayers interface at:<br />
http://eos.ga.gov.au/geoserver/web.</p>

attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents><value>Geoscience Australia (2013) Australian Reflectance Grid (ARG25) Product Information - Beta Release- External Document TRIM Ref D2013-41317, Geoscience Australia, Canberra</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Gallant, J., Dowling, T., and Austin, J. (2012): Multi-resolution Valley Bottom Flatness (MrVBF, 3" resolution). v2. CSIRO. Data Collection. 10.4225/08/512EF27AC3888 http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/08/512EF27AC3888</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Ticehurst, C J., Bartsch, A., Doubkova M.,and van Dijk, A.I.J.M. (2010) Comparison of ENVISAT ASAR ASAR GM, AMSR-E Passive Microwave, and MODIS Optical Remote Sensing for Flood Monitoring in Australia. Proceedings of the &#x2018;Earth Observation and Water Cycle Science&#x2019;, Frascati, Italy, 18&#x2013;20 November 2009 (ESA SP-674, January 2010).</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>WOfS 1.0 shows water observed for every Landsat-5 and Landsat-7 image across Australia (excluding External Territories) for the period of 1998 to 2012. Future versions of the product are expected to include Landsat-8 and other observations, and are expected to be up-dated quarterly.</p>

<p>WOfS 1.0 is a cumulative summary that combines all water observations from the entire time series into a single gridded dataset. The dataset includes four values for each grid cell, viz:</p>

<ul>
	<li>the total number of clear observations for the cell (pixel);</li>
	<li>the number of times that surface water is detected for the cell;</li>
	<li>the recurrence frequency of water as a percentage of the total number of clear observations, and;</li>
	<li>confidence Level.</li>
</ul>

<p>The Confidence Level assigned to each water observation is based on a statistical analysis of factors, including topographic position, elevation and slope, other independent satellite observations of water, topographic maps of water features, and the observation frequency. The confidence layer can be used to filter uncertain observations, for instance when displaying the data.</p>

<p>In the future, WOfS may be updated regularly as new data are added. This is potentially possible because WOfS is produced using the Australian Geoscience Data Cube, containing GAs entire Australian Landsat archive in a supercomputing environment at the National Computational Infrastructure.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

Future versions of the product are expected to include Landsat-8 and other observations, and are expected to be up-dated quarterly.</p>

<p>WOfS 1.0 is a cumulative summary that combines all water observations from the entire time series into a single gridded dataset. The dataset includes four values for each grid cell, viz:</p>

<ul>
	<li>the total number of clear observations for the cell (pixel);</li>
	<li>the number of times that surface water is detected for the cell;</li>
	<li>the recurrence frequency of water as a percentage of the total number of clear observations, and;</li>
	<li>confidence Level.</li>
</ul>

<p>The Confidence Level assigned to each water observation is based on a statistical analysis of factors, including topographic position, elevation and slope, other independent satellite observations of water, topographic maps of water features, and the observation frequency. The confidence layer can be used to filter uncertain observations, for instance when displaying the data.</p>

<p>In the future, WOfS may be updated regularly as new data are added. This is potentially possible because WOfS is produced using the Australian Geoscience Data Cube, containing GAs entire Australian Landsat archive in a supercomputing environment at the National Computational Infrastructure.</p>
