	-<nid><value>165</value></nid>
	-<uuid><value>af76fe11-1985-4015-965d-21757841ddf8</value></uuid><vid><value>360</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>WO_25_1.1.2</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495433829</value></created><changed><value>1496111892</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496111892</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Water Observations from Space (WOfS) 25m 1.2</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The primary purpose of the WOfS product is to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. This has application in emergency management and risk assessment.<br />
It is anticipated that WOfS will have many secondary uses. For example the WOfS product provides an indication on the permanence of surface water in the Australian landscape by showing where water is observed rarely in comparison to where it is often observed. This has application in water management and mapping.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Water Observations from Space product (WOfS) is a key component of the National Flood Risk Information Portal (NFRIP)2, being developed by Geoscience Australia (GA). The objective of WOfS is to analyse GAs historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past.</p>

<p>WOfS is being developed in parallel with the National Flood Studies Database system which will provide Flood Study documentation and reports to a wide range of users. Both systems will be delivered via the internet through the NFRIP portal.</p>

<p>Satellite imagery has been used to map floods around the world for several years. Organisations such as the Colorado Flood Observatory in the USA and several state-based agencies in Australia regularly provide satellite-based flood extents for major flood events. GA developed a flood mapping methodology in 2008-2009 that was extensively used for the major Australian flood events since 2010, providing emergency service agencies with regional flood extent information.</p>

<p>The Phase 1 outputs from the NFRIP were delivered to the public in November 2012, including a proof of concept of WOfS. This displayed surface water extents for three study areas, including the original derived extents and the cumulative summary product. Subsequent stakeholder feedback has shown that the most desirable information is the summary product, providing and understanding of the long term dynamics of surface water.</p>

<p>The Phase 2 outputs from the NFRIP (release in April 2014), include this WOfS product, which will be accessible to the public as a web service from the NFRIP.</p>

<p><em><strong>Confidence Level</strong></em></p>

<p>Reviews of prototype products identified the need to indicate the level of confidence for the surface water observations. The confidence level will help the user to distinguish between unusual but valid water detections (such as flood plains which might only be observed as water once in the 15 year interval) and false positives which can be caused, for instance, by steep shady slopes.</p>

<p>The confidence level was determined through a multiple logistic regression of water observations against several factors that would either support or contra-indicate the finding of water being present at the site.</p>

<p>The factors comprise:</p>

<p><strong>MrVBF</strong>, a multi-resolution valley bottom flatness product (Gallant et al., 2012) derived from SRTM as part of the Terrestrial Ecosystems Research Network. Surface water pixels identified in valley bottoms were more likely to be positively detected.</p>

<p><strong>Slope</strong> derived from SRTM Digital Surface Models. Water pixels on a slope were considered less plausible than those on a flat surface.</p>

<p><strong>MODIS Open Water Likelihood (OWL)</strong> (Ticehurst et al, 2010) provides a plausibility based an independent water detection algorithm employing the MODIS sensor. If both detection algorithms agree on the presence of a surface water pixel, there is a greater plausibility that the detection is correct.</p>

<p><strong>Australian Hydrological Geospatial Fabric (Geofabric)</strong> is a GIS of hydrological features derived from manually interpreted topographic map grids. If known hydrologic features (pixels) from GeoFabric coincide with detected water pixels, the plausibility of detection is greater.</p>

<p><strong>P</strong>, the number of observations of water as a fraction of the number of clear observations of the target pixel. P is high for more permanent water bodies.</p>

<p><strong>Built-Up areas</strong> indicating areas of dense urban development. In such areas the water detection algorithm struggles to cope with the deep shadows cast by multi-story buildings and the generally noisy spectral response created by structures. The Built-Up layer is derived from the Ausralian Bureau of Statistics ASGS 2011 dataset, for urban centres of populations of 100 000 and over.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_custodian><field_data_description><value><![CDATA[<p>Water Observations from Space is supplied as a WMS web service through the Portal of the National Flood Risk Information Project: http://www.ga.gov.au/hazards/flood.html</p>

<p>The service provides an Australia-wide coverage of the summary of water observations through time draped over a Google-Earth background. The coverage may be interrogated to provide information on:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Number of times a location was observed clearly by satellite</li>
	<li>Number of times water was indicated at the location</li>
	<li>The percentage of clear observations for which water was indicated</li>
	<li>The confidence that the water observation at the location is correct.</li>
</ul>

<p>Technical users may access each information item as a WMS directly from:<br />
http://eos.ga.gov.au/geoserver/wms, or browse the available layers in an OpenLayers interface at:<br />
http://eos.ga.gov.au/geoserver/web.</p>

<p>The available WMS sevices corresponding to each of the available information layers are:</p>

<ul>
	<li>ClearObservations_version : the number of clear satellite observations</li>
	<li>WaterObservations_version : the number of water observations</li>
	<li>WaterSummary_version : the percentage of clear observations for which water was indicated</li>
	<li>Confidence_version : the confidence that the indicated water is correct</li>
	<li>FilteredSummary_version : the Water Summary filtered to display only those areas for which confidence was above zero.</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_data_description><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-05-22T06:17:09</value><end_value>2017-05-22T06:17:09</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources>

	-%!25%!
	-</field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents><value>Geoscience Australia (2013) Australian Reflectance Grid (ARG25) Product Information - Beta Release- External Document TRIM Ref D2013-41317, Geoscience Australia, Canberra</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Gallant, J., Dowling, T., and Austin, J. (2012): Multi-resolution Valley Bottom Flatness (MrVBF, 3" resolution). v2. CSIRO. Data Collection. 10.4225/08/512EF27AC3888 http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/08/512EF27AC3888</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Ticehurst, C J., Bartsch, A., Doubkova M.,and van Dijk, A.I.J.M. (2010) Comparison of ENVISAT ASAR ASAR GM, AMSR-E Passive Microwave, and MODIS Optical Remote Sensing for Flood Monitoring in Australia. Proceedings of the &#x2018;Earth Observation and Water Cycle Science&#x2019;, Frascati, Italy, 18&#x2013;20 November 2009 (ESA SP-674, January 2010).</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>WOfS 1.0 shows water observed for every Landsat-5 and Landsat-7 image across Australia (excluding External Territories) for the period of 1998 to 2012. Future versions of the product are expected to include Landsat-8 and other observations, and are expected to be up-dated quarterly.</p>

<p>WOfS 1.0 is a cumulative summary that combines all water observations from the entire time series into a single gridded dataset. The dataset includes four values for each grid cell, viz:</p>

<ul>
	<li>the total number of clear observations for the cell (pixel);</li>
	<li>the number of times that surface water is detected for the cell;</li>
	<li>the recurrence frequency of water as a percentage of the total number of clear observations, and;</li>
	<li>confidence Level.</li>
</ul>

<p>The Confidence Level assigned to each water observation is based on a statistical analysis of factors, including topographic position, elevation and slope, other independent satellite observations of water, topographic maps of water features, and the observation frequency. The confidence layer can be used to filter uncertain observations, for instance when displaying the data.</p>

<p>In the future, WOfS may be updated regularly as new data are added. This is potentially possible because WOfS is produced using the Australian Geoscience Data Cube, containing GAs entire Australian Landsat archive in a supercomputing environment at the National Computational Infrastructure.</p>

The WOfS product Version 1.0 includes observations taken between 1998 and 2012 (inclusive) from the Landsat 5 and 7 satellites. Future versions of the product will extend the temporal range and diversify the data sources. WOfS covers all of mainland Australia and Tasmania but excludes off-shore Territories.</p>

The collection of many hundred thousand WOFLs that make up WO_2.1.5 are too cumbersome to display easily. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides the mechanism to present and deliver WO_2.1.5 in an easily digestible form, and provides understanding of water in the landscape.</p>

The objective of Water Observations from Space is to analyse GA's historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. The collection of many hundred thousand WOFLs that make up WO_2.1.5 are too cumbersome to display easily. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides the mechanism to present and deliver WO_2.1.5 in an easily digestible form, and provides understanding of water in the landscape.</p>

attempting match on: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
No match node contents append: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
attempting match on: %!113%!
No match node contents append: %!113%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>81568</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress><value>50</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-06-30</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>WO_STATS_2.1.5 delivers statistics of the WO_2.1.5 data in cumulative "summaries" that combine all water observations from the entire time series into a gridded datasets. Each WOFL in WO_2.1.5 provides information for each pixel, defining whether an observation was clear and dry, clear and wet or masked due to the presence of clouds, shadows or technical issues with the observation. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides basic statistical summaries of the observation of each pixel through the entire time series from 1987 to present. Five statistics are calculated and delivered as individual dataset: There are five datasets:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Total number of clear observations for the pixel, is a count per pixel of the number of observations that were clear and either wet or dry for the full depth of the time series.</li>
	<li>Total number of wet observation for the pixel, is a count per pixel of the number of observations that were clear and wet for the full depth of the time series.</li>
	<li>Summary, is the ratio of clear wet observations to clear wet or dry observation, expressed as a percentage.</li>
	<li>Confidence, is a value assigned to each pixel based on a statistical analysis of factors, including topographic position, elevation and slope, other independent satellite observations of water, topographic maps of water features, and the observation frequency. It indicates how well the Summary indicates the presence of water in a pixel.</li>
	<li>Filtered Summary, is produced by combining the Summary and Confidence outputs to mask out those areas where Confidence is less than 1%. Online display of the Water Observations from Space suite of products defaults to the Filtered Summary.</li>
</ol>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>81568</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress><value>50</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-06-30</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>WO_STATS_2.1.5 delivers statistics of the WO_2.1.5 data in cumulative "summaries" that combine all water observations from the entire time series into a gridded datasets. Each WOFL in WO_2.1.5 provides information for each pixel, defining whether an observation was clear and dry, clear and wet or masked due to the presence of clouds, shadows or technical issues with the observation. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides basic statistical summaries of the observation of each pixel through the entire time series from 1987 to present. Five statistics are calculated and delivered as individual dataset: There are five datasets:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Total number of clear observations for the pixel, is a count per pixel of the number of observations that were clear and either wet or dry for the full depth of the time series.</li>
	<li>Total number of wet observation for the pixel, is a count per pixel of the number of observations that were clear and wet for the full depth of the time series.</li>
	<li>Summary, is the ratio of clear wet observations to clear wet or dry observation, expressed as a percentage.</li>
	<li>Confidence, is a value assigned to each pixel based on a statistical analysis of factors, including topographic position, elevation and slope, other independent satellite observations of water, topographic maps of water features, and the observation frequency. It indicates how well the Summary indicates the presence of water in a pixel.</li>
	<li>Filtered Summary, is produced by combining the Summary and Confidence outputs to mask out those areas where Confidence is less than 1%. Online display of the Water Observations from Space suite of products defaults to the Filtered Summary.</li>
</ol>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

	<li>The percentage of clear observations on which water was detected, masked where the confidence is less than 1%.</li>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Water Observations from Space Statistics 25m 2.1.5</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The primary purpose of the WO_2.1.5 and WO_STATS_2.1.5 products is to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. This has application in emergency management and risk assessment.<br />
The product has many secondary uses. For example the products provide an indication of the permanence of surface water in the Australian landscape by showing where water is observed rarely in comparison to where it is often observed. This has application in water management and mapping. The products have also been used for wetland analyses, water connectivity and surface-ground water relationships.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors><value>Norman Mueller</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Water Observations from Space product (WO_2.1.5) is a key component of the National Flood Risk Information Portal (NFRIP), developed by Geoscience Australia (GA). The objective of Water Observations from Space is to analyse GA's historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. The collection of many hundred thousand WOFLs that make up WO_2.1.5 are too cumbersome to display easily. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides the mechanism to present and deliver WO_2.1.5 in an easily digestible form, and provides understanding of water in the landscape.</p>

Each WOFL in WO_2.1.5 provides information for each pixel, defining whether an observation was clear and dry, clear and wet or masked due to the presence of clouds, shadows or technical issues with the observation. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides basic statistical summaries of the observation of each pixel through the entire time series from 1987 to present. 	<li>Total number of clear observations for the pixel, is a count per pixel of the number of observations that were clear and either wet or dry for the full depth of the time series.</li>

match node contents append: <nid><value>141</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>a77c8d53-0e29-4819-83ce-3fb1c48ff74b</value></uuid><vid><value>362</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>SR_MEDOID_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494306917</value></created><changed><value>1496112005</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112005</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>

<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>

<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25 Medoid v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:</p>

<ul>
	<li>surface reflectance;</li>
	<li>atmospheric condition;</li>
	<li>interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and</li>
	<li>land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.</li>
</ul>

<p>It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>a77c8d53-0e29-4819-83ce-3fb1c48ff74b</value></uuid><vid><value>362</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>SR_MEDOID_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494306917</value></created><changed><value>1496112005</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112005</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>

<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>

<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25 Medoid v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:</p>

<ul>
	<li>surface reflectance;</li>
	<li>atmospheric condition;</li>
	<li>interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and</li>
	<li>land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.</li>
</ul>

<p>It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>

No match node contents append: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title><value>sr_medoid_albers</value></field_developer_title><field_distribution_entity>
attempting match on: %!113%!
No match node contents append: %!113%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction (see SR-NT_25)</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction (see SR-NT_25)</p>

attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Surface Reflectance (SR) is a suite of Earth Observation (EO) products from GA. The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Surface Reflectance (SR) is a suite of Earth Observation (EO) products from GA. The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>

No match node contents append: </field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-09T05:15:17</value><end_value>2017-05-09T05:15:17</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
attempting match on: %!26%!
No match node contents append: %!26%!
attempting match on: </field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame/><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA - correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland?normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>

<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Frome - correlation (measured as r) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.93-0.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>

<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types. Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.80-0.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>

<p>The Geometric QA software utilises an area based image-to-image correlation technique to assess and compare the difference between the target image and the reference image at regular gridded QA points. The residual of each QA point will be derived and scene statistics such as number of valid QA points, mean residual X/Y, STD residual X/Y and CEP90 will be recorded in v2 AGDC.</p>

<p>Because each scene recorded in v2 AGDC will have a GQA assessment result, the 'minimum GCP number' threshold has been lowered to enable more products processed to Ortho level, especially for coastal scenes where only a very small portion of the image contains land for GCP identification purpose.</p>

<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>

<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earth's surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains:</p>

<p>Spectral Contiguity</p>

<ul>
	<li>Per band saturation assessment</li>
	<li>Cloud detection</li>
	<li>Cloud shadow estimation</li>
	<li>Offshore (sea)</li>
	<li>Onshore (land)</li>
</ul>

<p>The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which don?t meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>
No match node contents append: </field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame/><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA - correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

	-<nid><value>141</value></nid>
	-<uuid><value>a77c8d53-0e29-4819-83ce-3fb1c48ff74b</value></uuid><vid><value>362</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>SR_MEDOID_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494306917</value></created><changed><value>1496112005</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112005</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>

<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>

<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25 Medoid v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:</p>

<ul>
	<li>surface reflectance;</li>
	<li>atmospheric condition;</li>
	<li>interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and</li>
	<li>land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.</li>
</ul>

<p>It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>

	-</field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title><value>sr_medoid_albers</value></field_developer_title><field_distribution_entity>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction (see SR-NT_25)</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
	-%!29%!
	-</field_feedback_contact><field_files/><field_hprm_references/><field_images/><field_ingestion_contact>
	-%!25%!
	-</field_ingestion_contact><field_license>
	-%!12507%!
	-</field_license><field_maintenance><value><![CDATA[<p>New data is added continuously (at least once week) . Entire archive will be reprocessed when data spec is upgraded to V2.0 (release schedule not yet determined).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_maintenance><field_maintenance_contact>
	-%!25%!
	-</field_maintenance_contact><field_major_algorithms/><field_media_contact>
	-%!28%!
	-</field_media_contact><field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><value>2017-05-09T05:15:17</value><end_value>2017-05-09T05:15:17</end_value></field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><field_metadata_contact>
	-%!27%!
	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary/><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Surface Reflectance (SR) is a suite of Earth Observation (EO) products from GA. The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_owner><field_principal_contact>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_principal_contact><field_processing_steps>

	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!108%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!109%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!94%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_product_life_span/><field_product_type>
	-%!12524%!
	-</field_product_type><field_publishing_entity>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-09T05:15:17</value><end_value>2017-05-09T05:15:17</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
	-%!26%!
	-</field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame/><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA - correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland?normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>

<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Frome - correlation (measured as r) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.93-0.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>

<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types. Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.80-0.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>

<p>The Geometric QA software utilises an area based image-to-image correlation technique to assess and compare the difference between the target image and the reference image at regular gridded QA points. The residual of each QA point will be derived and scene statistics such as number of valid QA points, mean residual X/Y, STD residual X/Y and CEP90 will be recorded in v2 AGDC.</p>

<p>Because each scene recorded in v2 AGDC will have a GQA assessment result, the 'minimum GCP number' threshold has been lowered to enable more products processed to Ortho level, especially for coastal scenes where only a very small portion of the image contains land for GCP identification purpose.</p>

<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>

<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earth's surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains:</p>

<p>Spectral Contiguity</p>

<ul>
	<li>Per band saturation assessment</li>
	<li>Cloud detection</li>
	<li>Cloud shadow estimation</li>
	<li>Offshore (sea)</li>
	<li>Onshore (land)</li>
</ul>

<p>The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which don?t meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>
	-%!12561%!

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_rights_statement><field_schema/><field_security_classification>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25m Geomedian 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geomedian provides an annual reflectance composite for any area of interest within the area covered by the AGDC. It provides a cloud-free overview of the middle surface reflectance value for each year and can be used in further analyses such as Tasselled Cap, Principal Components Analysis and Normalised Difference Indices.</p>

<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia's archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:</p>

<ul>
	<li>surface reflectance;</li>
	<li>atmospheric condition;</li>
	<li>interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and</li>
	<li>land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.</li>
</ul>

<p>It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>

attempting match on: %!113%!
No match node contents append: %!113%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geomedian product provides the median surface reflectance of each calendar year. The geomedian is a synthetic value as opposed to an actual observation, and is the high dimensional median of all reflectance bands of the source dataset for each year.</p>

<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geomedian product provides the median surface reflectance of each calendar year. The geomedian is a synthetic value as opposed to an actual observation, and is the high dimensional median of all reflectance bands of the source dataset for each year.</p>

<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

No match node contents append: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>Annual geometric median of surface reflectance data.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!24%!
No match node contents append: %!24%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Surface Reflectance suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Statistics products are derived from SR and provide statistical summaries of SR over specified periods (epochs) to highlight extrema, average conditions, or other statistical quantities that give insight into the behaviour of the earth. The geometric median (Geomedian) provides a high dimensional median (the median of a multi-dimensional dataset rather than the basic median) value of earth observations for a specified epoch, and as such gives a representation of the middle of surface reflectance over the time period.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Surface Reflectance suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Statistics products are derived from SR and provide statistical summaries of SR over specified periods (epochs) to highlight extrema, average conditions, or other statistical quantities that give insight into the behaviour of the earth. The geometric median (Geomedian) provides a high dimensional median (the median of a multi-dimensional dataset rather than the basic median) value of earth observations for a specified epoch, and as such gives a representation of the middle of surface reflectance over the time period.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

No match node contents append: </field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-09T05:03:36</value><end_value>2017-05-09T05:03:36</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
attempting match on: %!26%!
No match node contents append: %!26%!
attempting match on: </field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame/><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA - correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland - normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>

<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Frome - correlation (measured as r2) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.93-0.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>

<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types. Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.80-0.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>

<p>The Geometric QA software utilises an area based image-to-image correlation technique to assess and compare the difference between the target image and the reference image at regular gridded QA points. The residual of each QA point will be derived and scene statistics such as number of valid QA points, mean residual X/Y, STD residual X/Y and CEP90 will be recorded in v2 AGDC.</p>

<p>Because each scene recorded in v2 AGDC will have a GQA assessment result, the minimum GCP number threshold has been lowered to enable more products processed to Ortho level, especially for coastal scenes where only a very small portion of the image contains land for GCP identification purpose.</p>

<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>

<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Spectral Contiguity</li>
	<li>Per band saturation assessment</li>
	<li>Cloud detection</li>
	<li>Cloud shadow estimation</li>
	<li>Offshore (sea)</li>
	<li>Onshore (land)</li>
</ul>

<p>The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which don?t meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type/><field_rights_statement><value><![CDATA[<p><span></span> Commonwealth of Australia (Geoscience Australia) 2015. Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_rights_statement><field_schema/><field_security_classification>
No match node contents append: </field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame/><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA - correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland - normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>

(2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types. Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. <p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>

<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Spectral Contiguity</li>
	<li>Per band saturation assessment</li>
	<li>Cloud detection</li>
	<li>Cloud shadow estimation</li>
	<li>Offshore (sea)</li>
	<li>Onshore (land)</li>
</ul>

<p>The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which don?t meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type/><field_rights_statement><value><![CDATA[<p><span></span> Commonwealth of Australia (Geoscience Australia) 2015. ]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_rights_statement><field_schema/><field_security_classification>
attempting match on: %!12552%!
No match node contents append: %!12552%!
attempting match on: </field_security_classification><field_services/><field_simple_title><value>Surface Reflectance Geometric Median 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_subject_matter_experts/><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geometric medians of surface reflectance measurements are calculated per calendar year, on individual sensors (ie. only Lndsat 5 TM or Landsat 7 ETM+ or Landsat 8 OLI) to maintain data integrity. An annual geometric median (geomedian) is a high-dimensional median calculated from the reflectance values drawn from a calendar year. The years available are each full calendar year since 1987. The geomedian (Roberts et al 2017) is used in preference to the mean, as the mean can be adversely effected by extrema whereas the median is less sensitive to outliers. The geomedian is used in preference to the basic median, as it preserves the physical relationship between spectral measurements which the basic median does not. The geometric median is used in preference to the medoid (Flood 2013) as the medoid must choose from available measurements and hence may create a noisy composite, while the geomedian creates a synthetic representation of an epoch while reducing noise and permitting further analysis that is consistent with mathematical and statistical theory. Where the provenance of each pixel in a composite is required the medoid is the preferred method and the geomedian should not be used. The input data used to calculate the geomedian are filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band) using the Pixel Quality Assessment (PQA) product. To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated using the following satellites/sensors for the following periods of time:</p>

<ul>
	<li>1987-1998 : Landsat 5</li>
	<li>1999 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2000-2002 : Landsat 7</li>
	<li>2003 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2004-2010 : Landsat 5</li>
	<li>2011 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2012 : Landsat 7</li>
	<li>2013 : Landsat 7 and Landsat 8 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2014 onward : Landsat 8</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_update_frequency>
No match node contents append: </field_security_classification><field_services/><field_simple_title><value>Surface Reflectance Geometric Median 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_subject_matter_experts/><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geometric medians of surface reflectance measurements are calculated per calendar year, on individual sensors (ie. only Lndsat 5 TM or Landsat 7 ETM+ or Landsat 8 OLI) to maintain data integrity. An annual geometric median (geomedian) is a high-dimensional median calculated from the reflectance values drawn from a calendar year. The years available are each full calendar year since 1987. The geomedian (Roberts et al 2017) is used in preference to the mean, as the mean can be adversely effected by extrema whereas the median is less sensitive to outliers. The geomedian is used in preference to the basic median, as it preserves the physical relationship between spectral measurements which the basic median does not. The geometric median is used in preference to the medoid (Flood 2013) as the medoid must choose from available measurements and hence may create a noisy composite, while the geomedian creates a synthetic representation of an epoch while reducing noise and permitting further analysis that is consistent with mathematical and statistical theory. Where the provenance of each pixel in a composite is required the medoid is the preferred method and the geomedian should not be used. The input data used to calculate the geomedian are filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band) using the Pixel Quality Assessment (PQA) product. To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated using the following satellites/sensors for the following periods of time:</p>

<ul>
	<li>1987-1998 : Landsat 5</li>
	<li>1999 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2000-2002 : Landsat 7</li>
	<li>2003 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2004-2010 : Landsat 5</li>
	<li>2011 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2012 : Landsat 7</li>
	<li>2013 : Landsat 7 and Landsat 8 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2014 onward : Landsat 8</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_update_frequency>

attempting match on: <nid><value>111</value></nid>
