USGS, USA.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>OGC (2006) OpenGIS&#xAE; Web Map Server Implementation Specification (Ed: Jeff de la Beaujardiere) Ref. OGC&#xAE; 06&#x2013;042.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>OGC (2010) OGC&#xAE; WCS 2.0 Interface Standard &#x2013; Core. (Ed: Peter Baumann) Ref. OGC 09&#x2013;110r3.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>OGC (2013) CF-netCDF3 Data Model Extension Standard (Eds: Ben Domenico and Stefano Nativi) Ref. OGC 11-165r2.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Strahler, A.H., and Muller, J.-P. (1999) MODIS BRDF/Albedo Product: Algorithm Theoretical Basis Document Version 5.0. http://modis.gsfc.nasa.gov/data/atbd/atbd_mod09.pdf</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>TM World Borders vector file: http://thematicmapping.org/downloads/world_borders.php.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>USGS (2012a) Landsat Thematic Mapper (TM) Level 1 (L1) Data Format Control Book (DFCB). LS-DFCB-20 Version 4.0. USGS, USA. http://landsat.usgs.gov/documents/LS-DFCB-20.pdf.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>USGS (2012b) Landsat 7 ETM+ Level 1 Product Data Format Control Book (DFCB). LS-DFCB-04 Version 15.0. http://landsat.usgs.gov/documents/LS-DFCB-04.pdf.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Vincenty, T. (1975) Direct and Inverse Solutions of Geodesies on the Ellipsoid with Application of Nested Equations. Survey Review 23, 88&#x2013;93.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Zhu, Z. and Woodcock, C. E. (2012) Object-based cloud and cloud shadow detection in Landsat imagery. Remote Sensing of Environment 118, 83&#x2013;94.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5487CC0D4F40B</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>http://dx.doi.org/10.1109/JSTARS.2010.2042281</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>102288</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress><value>95</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-05-31</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>Terrain affects optical satellite images through both irradiance and bidirectional reflectance distribution function (BRDF) effects. Slopes facing the sun receive enhanced solar irradiance and appear brighter compared to those facing away from the sun. For anisotropic surfaces, the radiance received at the satellite sensor from a sloping surface is also affected by surface BRDF which varies with combinations of surface landcover types, sun, and satellite geometry (sun and sensor view, and their relative azimuth angle) as well as topographic geometry (primarily slope and aspect angles). Consequently, to obtain comparable surface reflectance from satellite images covering mountainous areas, it is necessary to process the images to reduce or remove the topographic effect so that the images can be used for different purposes on the same spectral base. A Digital Surface Model (DSM) resolution appropriate to the scale of the resolution of satellite image is needed for the best results. 1 second SRTM DSM is used for NBART processing.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
	-%!29%!
	-</field_feedback_contact><field_files/><field_hprm_references><value>D2013-175180</value></field_hprm_references><field_images/><field_ingestion_contact>
	-%!25%!

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_maintenance><field_maintenance_contact>

	-%!97%!
	-</field_major_algorithms><field_media_contact>
	-%!28%!
	-</field_media_contact><field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><value>2017-05-05T01:44:34</value><end_value>2017-05-05T01:44:34</end_value></field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><field_metadata_contact>
	-%!27%!
	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to the atmosphere, and sun and sensor geometry. SR-NT corrects for terrain shadow.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Surface Reflectance (SR) is a suite of Earth Observation (EO) products from GA. The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_owner><field_principal_contact>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_principal_contact><field_processing_steps>
	-%!112%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!107%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!108%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!109%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!94%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_product_life_span><value>1986-08-15T23:45:00</value><end_value>2017-05-05T01:44:34</end_value></field_product_life_span><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>1986-08-15T23:45:00</value><end_value>2017-05-05T01:44:34</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
	-%!26%!
	-</field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>1986-08-15T23:45:00</value><end_value>2017-05-05T01:44:34</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA; correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland - normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>

<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Frome; correlation (measured as r2) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.93-0.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>

<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types.</p>

<p>Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.80-0.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>

<p>The Geometric QA software utilises an area based image-to-image correlation technique to assess and compare the difference between the target image and the reference image at regular gridded QA points. The residual of each QA point will be derived and scene statistics such as number of valid QA points, mean residual X/Y, STD residual X/Y and CEP90 will be recorded in v2 AGDC.</p>

<p>Because each scene recorded in v2 AGDC will have a GQA assessment result, the minimum GCP number threshold has been lowered to enable more products processed to Ortho level, especially for coastal scenes where only a very small portion of the image contains land for GCP identification purpose.</p>

<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>

<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Spectral Contiguity</li>
	<li>Per band saturation assessment</li>
	<li>Cloud detection</li>
	<li>Cloud shadow estimation</li>
	<li>Offshore (sea)</li>
	<li>Onshore (land)</li>
</ul>

<p>The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which don't meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>
	-%!12561%!
	-</field_resource_type><field_rights_statement><value><![CDATA[<p><span></span> Commonwealth of Australia (Geoscience Australia) 2015. Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_rights_statement><field_schema/><field_security_classification>
	-%!12552%!
	-</field_security_classification><field_services/><field_simple_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+Terrain Elimination</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_subject_matter_experts>
	-%!17%!
	-</field_subject_matter_experts><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>The Surface Reflectance product is an algorithm that has been applied to all satellite imagery in the Landsat archive since 1987 that corrects each image to account for variations due to atmospheric properties, sun position and sensor view angle when the imagery was captured. This is undertaken to allow comparison of imagery acquired at different times, by different sensors, in different seasons and in different geographic regions. These products also indicate whether the imagery has been affected by cloud or cloud shadow, contains missing data or has been affected in other ways. The Surface Reflectance products are useful as a fundamental starting point for any further analysis and are the underlying data of all other AGDC products.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_update_frequency>

	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress><value>50</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-06-30</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>SR-N-Stats is a statistical summary of SR25 for specified epochs (which may be seasons).</p>

<p>To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated using the following satellites for the following periods of time:<br />
1987-1998 : Landsat 5<br />
1999 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2000-2002 : Landsat 7<br />
2003 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2004-2010 : Landsat 5<br />
2011-2012 : Landsat 7<br />
2013 onward : Landsat 8</p>

<p>The product is derived from surface reflectance data described in the ARG25 product description. This product includes quality assurance information for each pixel.</p>

<p>The products are produced through the Australian Geoscience Data Cube (AGDC). The Data Cube allows the workflows for the product, once developed, to be run over large areas at marginal cost, offering major efficiencies and cost savings over previous approaches and enabling more timely and effective monitoring and management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
	-%!29%!
	-</field_feedback_contact><field_files/><field_hprm_references/><field_images/><field_ingestion_contact>
	-%!25%!
	-</field_ingestion_contact><field_license>
	-%!12507%!
	-</field_license><field_maintenance/><field_maintenance_contact>
	-%!25%!
	-</field_maintenance_contact><field_major_algorithms/><field_media_contact>
	-%!28%!
	-</field_media_contact><field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><value>2017-05-09T03:39:50</value><end_value>2017-05-09T03:39:50</end_value></field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><field_metadata_contact>
	-%!27%!
	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>Surface reflectance statistics provide a summary of reflectance per year/season.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The seasonal statistics of surface reflectance measurements are calculated per season (three months)<br />
- Dec/Jan/Feb - Season 1<br />
- Mar/Apr/May - Season 2<br />
- Jun/July/August - Season 3<br />
- September/October/November - Season 4</p>

<p>Each epoch is summarised using the geo-median.</p>

<p>Statistics are drawn from the reflectance values for each epoch. The epochs available are the most recent 8 seasons and each full calendar year since 1987</p>

<p>The input data used to calculate the geo-median are filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band). Sea is not filtered. Water is not filtered.</p>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>7b05e0b3-38ed-44dd-bd5e-1250fe12d00f</value></uuid><vid><value>367</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Sentinel Hotspots</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495494880</value></created><changed><value>1496112193</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112193</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<ul>
	<li><span>False positives are possible (showing a Hotspot without an underlying cause).</span></li>
	<li><span>False negatives are possible (failing to show a Hotspot, despite a heated land surface, fire etc.).</span></li>
	<li><span>Hotspots may indicate phenomena other than fires when locations are identified as hot for some other reason, such as black soil, gas fires, industry and hot rocks.</span></li>
	<li><span>Not all fires will be detected as Hotspots. If no satellite has passed over the fire, or if smoke, cloud, distance or topography prevent the instruments from sensing the fire, or if the fire is too small or too cool to produce enough heat, or if there is some other technical failure, no Hotspot will be identified.</span></li>
	<li><span>The location of the Hotspot on a map is approximate only (as a guide, within 1.5 km of the centre of the observation).</span></li>
	<li><span><span>Hotspot locations represent an <em>area around the point</em> , dependent on the sensor and the satellite position. With current sensors, this is typically more than one square kilometre.</span></span></li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Sentinel Hotspots</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p><span>Hotspots are useful for detecting possible active fires in some circumstances. Taken as an ensemble, the Hotspots provide an overview of fire activity in Australia and capture the pattern of actual fires across the Australian continent through time.</span></p>

<p><span><span>Emergency management agencies use the Hotspots as one of many operational data feeds to inform their broad situational awareness of, and at times tactical response to, fires.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background/><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

No match node contents append: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>&#x2022;	Hotspots are point data, derived from (a growing number of) satellite-born instruments that detect light in the thermal wavelengths. Taken as an ensemble, the Hotspots provide an overview of fire activity in Australia.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!24%!
No match node contents append: %!24%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p><span>Hotspots are point data, derived from a growing number of satellite-borne instruments that detect light in the thermal wavelengths. Typically, the satellite data are processed with a specific algorithm that highlights areas with an unusually high temperature.</span></p>

<p><span><span>Hotspot sources include the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) sensor aboard the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) Terra and Aqua satellites, the Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) night time imagery from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) satellites, the Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) on the Suomi- NPP satellite and the Advanced Himawari Imager (AHI) sensor aboard the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) on the Himawari-8 satellite.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p><span>Hotspots are point data, derived from a growing number of satellite-borne instruments that detect light in the thermal wavelengths. Typically, the satellite data are processed with a specific algorithm that highlights areas with an unusually high temperature.</span></p>

<p><span><span>Hotspot sources include the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) sensor aboard the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) Terra and Aqua satellites, the Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) night time imagery from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) satellites, the Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) on the Suomi- NPP satellite and the Advanced Himawari Imager (AHI) sensor aboard the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) on the Himawari-8 satellite.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

	-<uuid><value>7b05e0b3-38ed-44dd-bd5e-1250fe12d00f</value></uuid><vid><value>367</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Sentinel Hotspots</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495494880</value></created><changed><value>1496112193</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112193</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<ul>
	<li><span>False positives are possible (showing a Hotspot without an underlying cause).</span></li>
	<li><span>False negatives are possible (failing to show a Hotspot, despite a heated land surface, fire etc.).</span></li>
	<li><span>Hotspots may indicate phenomena other than fires when locations are identified as hot for some other reason, such as black soil, gas fires, industry and hot rocks.</span></li>
	<li><span>Not all fires will be detected as Hotspots. If no satellite has passed over the fire, or if smoke, cloud, distance or topography prevent the instruments from sensing the fire, or if the fire is too small or too cool to produce enough heat, or if there is some other technical failure, no Hotspot will be identified.</span></li>
	<li><span>The location of the Hotspot on a map is approximate only (as a guide, within 1.5 km of the centre of the observation).</span></li>
	<li><span><span>Hotspot locations represent an <em>area around the point</em> , dependent on the sensor and the satellite position. With current sensors, this is typically more than one square kilometre.</span></span></li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Sentinel Hotspots</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p><span>Hotspots are useful for detecting possible active fires in some circumstances. Taken as an ensemble, the Hotspots provide an overview of fire activity in Australia and capture the pattern of actual fires across the Australian continent through time.</span></p>

<p><span><span>Emergency management agencies use the Hotspots as one of many operational data feeds to inform their broad situational awareness of, and at times tactical response to, fires.</span></span></p>

match node contents append: <nid><value>138</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>eb44806b-a9bc-49eb-8ac3-2ba2c0f13324</value></uuid><vid><value>368</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_COUNT_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494300836</value></created><changed><value>1496112250</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112250</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>reviewed</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality Count 25m 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsats 5, 7 and 8.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>eb44806b-a9bc-49eb-8ac3-2ba2c0f13324</value></uuid><vid><value>368</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_COUNT_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494300836</value></created><changed><value>1496112250</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112250</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>reviewed</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality Count 25m 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsats 5, 7 and 8.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>

<ul>
	<li>Spectral Contiguity (lack of signal in any band)</li>
	<li>Saturation in any band</li>
	<li>Presence of cloud</li>
	<li>Presence of cloud shadow</li>
	<li>Land or sea</li>
</ul>

	<li>Presence of cloud</li>
	<li>Presence of cloud shadow</li>

No match node contents append: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>PQ25 Count is an aggregate assessment of a collection of image pixels to determine if they are unobscured, unsaturated observations of the Earth's surface and whether the pixels are represented in each spectral band.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>

No match node contents append: %!24%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The PQ25 product facilitates interpretation and processing of Surface Reflectance (SR-N/NT), Fractional Cover 25 (FC25) and all derivative products.<br />
PQ25 is an assessment of each image pixel to determine if it is an unobscured, unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and also whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude pixels which don?t meet their quality criteria from analysis . The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>Users can choose to process only land pixels, or only sea pixels depending on their analytical requirements, leading to enhanced computationally efficient.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude pixels which don?t meet their quality criteria from analysis . The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>Users can choose to process only land pixels, or only sea pixels depending on their analytical requirements, leading to enhanced computationally efficient.</p>

However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality Count 25m 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsats 5, 7 and 8.</p>

match node contents append: <nid><value>118</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>3db22d26-cd94-4b11-8108-74f84edf6346</value></uuid><vid><value>369</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493954905</value></created><changed><value>1496112357</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112357</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>in_development</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality 25 v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsats 5, 7 and 8.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>None</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>3db22d26-cd94-4b11-8108-74f84edf6346</value></uuid><vid><value>369</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493954905</value></created><changed><value>1496112357</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112357</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>in_development</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality 25 v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsats 5, 7 and 8.</p>

attempting match on: %!24%!
No match node contents append: %!24%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The PQ25 product facilitates interpretation and processing of Surface Reflectance (SR-N/NT), Fractional Cover 25 (FC25) and all derivative products.<br />
PQ25 is an assessment of each image pixel to determine if it is an unobscured, unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and also whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude pixels which don?t meet their quality criteria from analysis . The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>Users can choose to process only land pixels, or only sea pixels depending on their analytical requirements, leading to enhanced computationally efficient.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The PQ25 product facilitates interpretation and processing of Surface Reflectance (SR-N/NT), Fractional Cover 25 (FC25) and all derivative products.<br />
PQ25 is an assessment of each image pixel to determine if it is an unobscured, unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and also whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude pixels which don?t meet their quality criteria from analysis . The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>Users can choose to process only land pixels, or only sea pixels depending on their analytical requirements, leading to enhanced computationally efficient.</p>

Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsats 5, 7 and 8.</p>

	-</field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>102290</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress><value>95</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-05-31</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>Pixel Quality provides an assessment of the quality of observations at a pixel level and includes information about:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Spectral Contiguity (lack of signal in any band)</li>
	<li>Saturation in any band</li>
	<li>Presence of cloud</li>
	<li>Presence of cloud shadow</li>
	<li>Land or sea</li>
</ul>

	-%!27%!
	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>PQ25 is an assessment of each image pixel to determine if it is an unobscured, unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and also whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The PQ25 product facilitates interpretation and processing of Surface Reflectance (SR-N/NT), Fractional Cover 25 (FC25) and all derivative products.<br />
PQ25 is an assessment of each image pixel to determine if it is an unobscured, unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and also whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude pixels which don?t meet their quality criteria from analysis . The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>Users can choose to process only land pixels, or only sea pixels depending on their analytical requirements, leading to enhanced computationally efficient.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_owner><field_principal_contact>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_principal_contact><field_processing_steps/><field_product_life_span/><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-05T03:28:25</value><end_value>2017-05-05T03:28:25</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
	-%!26%!
	-</field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame/><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>The validation of the underlying algorithms is contained within the journal articles that describe ACCA (Irish et al. 2006), Fmask (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) and the ATBD that describes the sensor saturation flagging method (Roy et al. 2010).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type/><field_rights_statement><value><![CDATA[<p><span></span> Commonwealth of Australia (Geoscience Australia) 2015. matches: [0] = <nid><value>164 [1] = nid [2] = 164
match node contents append: <nid><value>164</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>59300fdc-ad49-4748-8cc3-13e84c0b0774</value></uuid><vid><value>370</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495428582</value></created><changed><value>1496112416</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112416</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 <a>product</a>.</p>

<p>Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels.&#160; The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks.&#160; This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p><span><span>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery.&#160; In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality 25m v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p><span>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe.&#160; Most researchers typically use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable &#160;pixels, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or&#160; saturated pixels.&#160; In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud free scenes.&#160; However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection.&#160; Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (<a href="#_ENREF_1"><span><span>Irish et al. 2006</span></span></a>) and Function of mask (Fmask) (<a href="#_ENREF_2"><span><span>Zhu and Woodcock 2012</span></span></a>) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate.&#160; Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation</p>

<p><span><span>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsats 5, 7 and 8</span></span>.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>59300fdc-ad49-4748-8cc3-13e84c0b0774</value></uuid><vid><value>370</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495428582</value></created><changed><value>1496112416</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112416</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 <a>product</a>.</p>

<p>Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels.&#160; The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks.&#160; This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p><span><span>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery.&#160; In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality 25m v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p><span>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe.&#160; Most researchers typically use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable &#160;pixels, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or&#160; saturated pixels.&#160; In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud free scenes.&#160; However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection.&#160; Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (<a href="#_ENREF_1"><span><span>Irish et al. 2006</span></span></a>) and Function of mask (Fmask) (<a href="#_ENREF_2"><span><span>Zhu and Woodcock 2012</span></span></a>) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate.&#160; Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation</p>

<p><span><span>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsats 5, 7 and 8</span></span>.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

</div>

<div>&#160;
<hr align="left" size="1" width="33%" />
<div id="ftn1">
<p><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title="">[1]</a> This is designed to match Landsat 7 ETM+. The thermal band for Landsat 5 TM corresponds to Band 6-1 and this value is duplicated in Band 6-2.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn2">
<p><a href="#_ftnref2" name="_ftn2" title="">[2]</a> Land and sea masking is based on vector data from TM World Borders ( <a href="http://thematicmapping.org/downloads/world_borders.php"> http://thematicmapping.org/downloads/world_borders.php </a> ) spliced with Australian Coastal Boundary using a 100m buffer into the sea.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn3">
<p><a href="#_ftnref3" name="_ftn3" title="">[3]</a> Automatic Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) algorithm described in Irish (2000) and Irish et al., (2006).</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn4">
<p><a href="#_ftnref4" name="_ftn4" title="">[4]</a> Function of Mask (Fmask) uses TOAR rather than NBAR as input reflectance ( <a href="http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0034425711003853"> http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0034425711003853 </a> ).</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn5">
<p><a href="#_ftnref5" name="_ftn5" title="">[5]</a> Only computed for cloud detected by ACCA algorithm using in-house algorithm.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn6">
<p><a href="#_ftnref6" name="_ftn6" title="">[6]</a> Only computed for cloud detected by Fmask algorithm using in-house algorithm.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn7">
<p><a href="#_ftnref7" name="_ftn7" title="">[7]</a> This feature has not been implemented yet so bit 14 is set to value 0.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn8">
<p><a href="#_ftnref8" name="_ftn8" title="">[8]</a> Default untested value currently set to 0.</p>
</div>
</div>

			<p>13166</p>
			</td>
			<td width="178">
			<p>Bands 1, 5 and 7 are saturated (bits 0, 4 and 7 = 0)</p>

			<p>No null values (bit 8 = 1)</p>

			<p>Land pixel (bit 9 = 1)<br />
			Clouds detected by ACCA and Fmask (bits 10 and 11 = 0)</p>

			<p>No cloud shadow<br />
			(bits 12 and 13 = 1)</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td width="19">
			<p>0</p>
			</td>
			<td width="19">
			<p>0</p>
			</td>
			<td width="19">
			<p>1</p>
			</td>
			<td width="19">
			<p>1</p>
			</td>
			<td width="19">
			<p>1</p>
			</td>
			<td width="19">
			<p>1</p>
			</td>
			<td width="19">
			<p>1</p>
			</td>
			<td width="19">
			<p>1</p>
			</td>
			<td width="19">
			<p>1</p>
			</td>
			<td width="19">
			<p>1</p>
			</td>
			<td width="19">
			<p>1</p>

			<p>1</p>

			<p>1</p>

			<p>1</p>
			</td>
			<td width="19">
			<p>1</p>
			</td>
			<td width="79">
			<p>16383</p>
			</td>
			<td width="178">
			<p>Clear Land Pixel<br />
			no saturation, null values, cloud, or cloud shadow</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>
</div>

<div>&#160;
<hr align="left" size="1" width="33%" />
<div id="ftn1">
<p><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title="">[1]</a> This is designed to match Landsat 7 ETM+. The thermal band for Landsat 5 TM corresponds to Band 6-1 and this value is duplicated in Band 6-2.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn2">
<p><a href="#_ftnref2" name="_ftn2" title="">[2]</a> Land and sea masking is based on vector data from TM World Borders ( <a href="http://thematicmapping.org/downloads/world_borders.php"> http://thematicmapping.org/downloads/world_borders.php </a> ) spliced with Australian Coastal Boundary using a 100m buffer into the sea.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn3">
<p><a href="#_ftnref3" name="_ftn3" title="">[3]</a> Automatic Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) algorithm described in Irish (2000) and Irish et al., (2006).</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn4">
<p><a href="#_ftnref4" name="_ftn4" title="">[4]</a> Function of Mask (Fmask) uses TOAR rather than NBAR as input reflectance ( <a href="http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0034425711003853"> http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0034425711003853 </a> ).</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn5">
<p><a href="#_ftnref5" name="_ftn5" title="">[5]</a> Only computed for cloud detected by ACCA algorithm using in-house algorithm.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn6">
<p><a href="#_ftnref6" name="_ftn6" title="">[6]</a> Only computed for cloud detected by Fmask algorithm using in-house algorithm.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn7">
<p><a href="#_ftnref7" name="_ftn7" title="">[7]</a> This feature has not been implemented yet so bit 14 is set to value 0.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn8">
<p><a href="#_ftnref8" name="_ftn8" title="">[8]</a> Default untested value currently set to 0.</p>
</div>
</div>

<ul>
	<li>Spectral Contiguity (lack of signal in any band)</li>
	<li>Saturation in any band</li>
	<li>Presence of cloud</li>
	<li>Presence of cloud shadow</li>
	<li>Being offshore (sea)</li>
</ul>

attempting match on: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>PQ25 is an assessment of each image pixel to determine if it is an unobscured, unsaturated observation of the Earth's surface, and also whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
No match node contents append: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>PQ25 is an assessment of each image pixel to determine if it is an unobscured, unsaturated observation of the Earth's surface, and also whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!24%!
No match node contents append: %!24%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The PQ25 product is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation&#160; of the Earths surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude&#160; affected pixels from which dont meet their quality criteria from further analysis. The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels from analysis is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>Users can choose to process only land pixels, or only sea pixels depending on their analytical requirements.&#160; This makes analysis of coastal locations more rapid and more computationally efficient.</p>

<p>The different sensor designs of Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+, and Landsat 8 OLI all have different sensor saturation characteristics.&#160; The PQ25 layer enables users to exclude observations from a given band where the pixels are &#160;saturated (exceed the dynamic range of the sensor).&#160; The per-band saturation information in PQ &#160;allows users to exclude pixels where their specific band of interest is saturated.</p>

<p>The PQ 25 layer uses two industry standard cloud/cloud shadow detection algorithms to flag pixels that potentially contain cloud and allows the user to generate masks based on either algorithm or both algorithms.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The PQ25 product is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation&#160; of the Earths surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude&#160; affected pixels from which dont meet their quality criteria from further analysis. The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels from analysis is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>Users can choose to process only land pixels, or only sea pixels depending on their analytical requirements.&#160; This makes analysis of coastal locations more rapid and more computationally efficient.</p>

<p>The different sensor designs of Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+, and Landsat 8 OLI all have different sensor saturation characteristics.&#160; The PQ25 layer enables users to exclude observations from a given band where the pixels are &#160;saturated (exceed the dynamic range of the sensor).&#160; The per-band saturation information in PQ &#160;allows users to exclude pixels where their specific band of interest is saturated.</p>

<p>The PQ 25 layer uses two industry standard cloud/cloud shadow detection algorithms to flag pixels that potentially contain cloud and allows the user to generate masks based on either algorithm or both algorithms.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_rights_statement><field_schema/><field_security_classification>
No match node contents append: </field_resource_type><field_rights_statement><value><![CDATA[<p><span></span> Commonwealth of Australia (Geoscience Australia) 2015. Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/.</p>
