No match node contents append: </field_security_classification><field_services/><field_simple_title><value>Pixel Quality v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_subject_matter_experts/><field_summary/><field_update_frequency/><field_use_constraints/><field_version_number><value>1.0.0</value></field_version_number><field_websites/>
attempting match on: <nid><value>137</value></nid>
Adding node contents to map with id: 164
	-<nid><value>164</value></nid>
	-<uuid><value>59300fdc-ad49-4748-8cc3-13e84c0b0774</value></uuid><vid><value>370</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495428582</value></created><changed><value>1496112416</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112416</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 <a>product</a>.</p>

<p>Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels.&#160; The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks.&#160; This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p><span><span>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery.&#160; In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality 25m v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p><span>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe.&#160; Most researchers typically use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable &#160;pixels, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or&#160; saturated pixels.&#160; In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud free scenes.&#160; However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection.&#160; Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (<a href="#_ENREF_1"><span><span>Irish et al. 2006</span></span></a>) and Function of mask (Fmask) (<a href="#_ENREF_2"><span><span>Zhu and Woodcock 2012</span></span></a>) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate.&#160; Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation</p>

<p><span><span>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsats 5, 7 and 8</span></span>.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>
	-%!24%!

	</tbody>
</table>
</div>

<div>&#160;
<hr align="left" size="1" width="33%" />
<div id="ftn1">
<p><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title="">[1]</a> This is designed to match Landsat 7 ETM+. The thermal band for Landsat 5 TM corresponds to Band 6-1 and this value is duplicated in Band 6-2.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn2">
<p><a href="#_ftnref2" name="_ftn2" title="">[2]</a> Land and sea masking is based on vector data from TM World Borders ( <a href="http://thematicmapping.org/downloads/world_borders.php"> http://thematicmapping.org/downloads/world_borders.php </a> ) spliced with Australian Coastal Boundary using a 100m buffer into the sea.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn3">
<p><a href="#_ftnref3" name="_ftn3" title="">[3]</a> Automatic Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) algorithm described in Irish (2000) and Irish et al., (2006).</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn4">
<p><a href="#_ftnref4" name="_ftn4" title="">[4]</a> Function of Mask (Fmask) uses TOAR rather than NBAR as input reflectance ( <a href="http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0034425711003853"> http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0034425711003853 </a> ).</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn5">
<p><a href="#_ftnref5" name="_ftn5" title="">[5]</a> Only computed for cloud detected by ACCA algorithm using in-house algorithm.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn6">
<p><a href="#_ftnref6" name="_ftn6" title="">[6]</a> Only computed for cloud detected by Fmask algorithm using in-house algorithm.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn7">
<p><a href="#_ftnref7" name="_ftn7" title="">[7]</a> This feature has not been implemented yet so bit 14 is set to value 0.</p>
</div>

<div id="ftn8">
<p><a href="#_ftnref8" name="_ftn8" title="">[8]</a> Default untested value currently set to 0.</p>
</div>
</div>

<ul>
	<li>Spectral Contiguity (lack of signal in any band)</li>
	<li>Saturation in any band</li>
	<li>Presence of cloud</li>
	<li>Presence of cloud shadow</li>
	<li>Being offshore (sea)</li>
</ul>

	-%!27%!
	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>PQ25 is an assessment of each image pixel to determine if it is an unobscured, unsaturated observation of the Earth's surface, and also whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The PQ25 product is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation&#160; of the Earths surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude&#160; affected pixels from which dont meet their quality criteria from further analysis. The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels from analysis is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>Users can choose to process only land pixels, or only sea pixels depending on their analytical requirements.&#160; This makes analysis of coastal locations more rapid and more computationally efficient.</p>

<p>The different sensor designs of Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+, and Landsat 8 OLI all have different sensor saturation characteristics.&#160; The PQ25 layer enables users to exclude observations from a given band where the pixels are &#160;saturated (exceed the dynamic range of the sensor).&#160; The per-band saturation information in PQ &#160;allows users to exclude pixels where their specific band of interest is saturated.</p>

<p>The PQ 25 layer uses two industry standard cloud/cloud shadow detection algorithms to flag pixels that potentially contain cloud and allows the user to generate masks based on either algorithm or both algorithms.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_owner><field_principal_contact>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_principal_contact><field_processing_steps/><field_product_life_span/><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-22T04:49:43</value><end_value>2017-05-22T04:49:43</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
	-%!26%!
	-</field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-05-22T04:49:43</value><end_value>2017-05-22T04:49:43</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p><span>The validation of the underlying algorithms is contained within the journal articles that<span> </span>describe ACCA </span><span>(<a href="#_ENREF_1"><span>Irish et al. 2006</span></a>)</span><span>, Fmask&#160; </span><span>(<a href="#_ENREF_2"><span>Zhu and Woodcock 2012</span></a>)</span><span> and the ATBD that describes the sensor saturation flagging method (Roy et al. 2010).</span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>

This information can also be used to normalise observation counts of particular phenomena. For example what percentage of time did a pixel meet a particular criteria during a particular year.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The different sensor designs of Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+, and Landsat 8 OLI all have different sensor saturation characteristics. The PQ25 layer enables users to exclude observations from a given band where the pixels are saturated (exceed the dynamic range of the sensor). The per-band saturation information in PQ allows users to exclude pixels where their specific band of interest is saturated.</p>

<p>The PQ 25 layer uses two industry standard cloud/cloud shadow detection algorithms to flag pixels that potentially contain cloud and allows the user to generate masks based on either algorithm or both algorithms.</p>

<p>The PQ25-STATS product is a summary of all of the individual PQ_25 layers.</p>

attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Pixel Quality (PQ) product is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an un-obscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels from which don?t meet their quality criteria from further analysis. The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels from analysis is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>The PQ-STATS shows the breakdown of how many times a pixel contains a clear observation of the surface (land or sea).</p>

<p>PQ-STATS is available as a per year summary and as a 'whole of archive' summary (1987 to present).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels from which don?t meet their quality criteria from further analysis. The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels from analysis is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>The PQ-STATS shows the breakdown of how many times a pixel contains a clear observation of the surface (land or sea).</p>

This information can also be used to normalise observation counts of particular phenomena. For example what percentage of time did a pixel meet a particular criteria during a particular year.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The different sensor designs of Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+, and Landsat 8 OLI all have different sensor saturation characteristics. The PQ25 layer enables users to exclude observations from a given band where the pixels are saturated (exceed the dynamic range of the sensor). The per-band saturation information in PQ allows users to exclude pixels where their specific band of interest is saturated.</p>

<p>The PQ 25 layer uses two industry standard cloud/cloud shadow detection algorithms to flag pixels that potentially contain cloud and allows the user to generate masks based on either algorithm or both algorithms.</p>

<p>The PQ25-STATS product is a summary of all of the individual PQ_25 layers.</p>

attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>NDVI values range between -1 and +1, and have been scaled by 10000 to be stored as integers between -10000 and +10000.</p>

<p>Negative values of NDVI (values between 0 and -1) usually correspond to non vegetation targets such as water. Values close to zero (-0.1 to 0.1) generally correspond to barren areas of rock, sand, or snow. Low, positive values usually represent shrub and grassland (approximately 0.2 to 0.4), while high values are indicative of healthy crops or dense vegetation such as temperate and tropical rainforests (values approaching 1).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

<p>Negative values of NDVI (values between 0 and -1) usually correspond to non vegetation targets such as water. Values close to zero (-0.1 to 0.1) generally correspond to barren areas of rock, sand, or snow. Low, positive values usually represent shrub and grassland (approximately 0.2 to 0.4), while high values are indicative of healthy crops or dense vegetation such as temperate and tropical rainforests (values approaching 1).</p>

No match node contents append: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>NDVI is an indicator used to assess the degree of live green vegetation at a given location.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!24%!
No match node contents append: %!24%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Live green plants absorb solar radiation in the photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) spectral region, which they use as a source of energy in the process of photosynthesis. Leaf cells have also evolved to reflect, scatter and re-emit solar radiation in the near-infrared spectral region. The pigment in plant leaves, chlorophyll, strongly absorbs visible light (from 0.4 to 0.7 micrometres) for use in photosynthesis. The cell structure of the leaves, on the other hand, strongly reflects near-infrared light (from 0.7 to 1.1 micrometres). Hence, live green plants appear relatively dark in the PAR and relatively bright in the near-infrared.<br />
By contrast, clouds and snow tend to be rather bright in the red (as well as other visible wavelengths) and quite dark in the near-infrared.</p>

<p>The Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is calculated as follows:</p>

<p>(NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED)</p>

<p>where RED and NIR stand for the spectral reflectance measurements acquired in the red and near-infrared regions, respectively.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Live green plants absorb solar radiation in the photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) spectral region, which they use as a source of energy in the process of photosynthesis. Leaf cells have also evolved to reflect, scatter and re-emit solar radiation in the near-infrared spectral region. The pigment in plant leaves, chlorophyll, strongly absorbs visible light (from 0.4 to 0.7 micrometres) for use in photosynthesis. The cell structure of the leaves, on the other hand, strongly reflects near-infrared light (from 0.7 to 1.1 micrometres). Hence, live green plants appear relatively dark in the PAR and relatively bright in the near-infrared.<br />
By contrast, clouds and snow tend to be rather bright in the red (as well as other visible wavelengths) and quite dark in the near-infrared.</p>

<p>The Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is calculated as follows:</p>

<p>(NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED)</p>

<p>where RED and NIR stand for the spectral reflectance measurements acquired in the red and near-infrared regions, respectively.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

attempting match on: %!17%!
No match node contents append: %!17%!
attempting match on: </field_subject_matter_experts><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is one of two vegetation-related products currently offered by the AGDC, the other being the Fractional Cover (FC) product. NDVI provides the ability to assess the relative extent of living green vegetation across the Australian continent at any point in time since 1987 till now. NDVI can potentially provide insight into the health and/or growth of vegetation whilst allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_update_frequency/><field_use_constraints/><field_version_number><value>2.0.0</value></field_version_number><field_websites/>

NDVI provides the ability to assess the relative extent of living green vegetation across the Australian continent at any point in time since 1987 till now. NDVI can potentially provide insight into the health and/or growth of vegetation whilst allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_update_frequency/><field_use_constraints/><field_version_number><value>2.0.0</value></field_version_number><field_websites/>

	-%!24%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Live green plants absorb solar radiation in the photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) spectral region, which they use as a source of energy in the process of photosynthesis. Leaf cells have also evolved to reflect, scatter and re-emit solar radiation in the near-infrared spectral region. The pigment in plant leaves, chlorophyll, strongly absorbs visible light (from 0.4 to 0.7 micrometres) for use in photosynthesis. The cell structure of the leaves, on the other hand, strongly reflects near-infrared light (from 0.7 to 1.1 micrometres). Hence, live green plants appear relatively dark in the PAR and relatively bright in the near-infrared.<br />
By contrast, clouds and snow tend to be rather bright in the red (as well as other visible wavelengths) and quite dark in the near-infrared.</p>

<p>The Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is calculated as follows:</p>

<p>(NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED)</p>

<p>where RED and NIR stand for the spectral reflectance measurements acquired in the red and near-infrared regions, respectively.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
	-%!113%!

NDVI provides the ability to assess the relative extent of living green vegetation across the Australian continent at any point in time since 1987 till now. NDVI can potentially provide insight into the health and/or growth of vegetation whilst allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>

attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress><value>50</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-06-30</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental composites for NDVI.</p>

<p>The 10th and 90th percentile are used in preference to the minimum and maximum values because they are less prone to residual noise associated with undetected cloud/cloud shadow. The 50th percentile (median) are used in preference to the mean as the median is less prone to being skewed by extreme values. It is worth noting that some undetected cloud and cloud shadow artefacts may still be present in the 10th and 90th percentiles, especially in areas with frequent cloud cover such as the wet tropics and Tasmania.</p>

<p>To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated from observations made by the following sensors for the following periods of time:</p>

<ul>
	<li>1987-1998 : Landsat 5 TM</li>
	<li>1999 : Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2000-2002 : Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2003 : Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2004-2010 : Landsat 5 TM</li>
	<li>2011-2012 : Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2013 onward : Landsat 8 OLI</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

No match node contents append: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>This product provides continental seasonal (most recent 8 seasons) and annual (each calendar year from 1987 to present) statistical (10th, 50th and 90th percentile) summaries of NDVI.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!24%!
No match node contents append: %!24%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental seasonal (most recent 8 seasons) and annual (each calendar year from 1987 to present) statistical (10th, 50th and 90th percentile) summaries of NDVI. The NDVI statistics are calculated from the observations in the NDVI product (NDVI_25_2.0.0) that are not affected by cloud, cloud shadow or sensor saturation (as captured by the PQ_25_2.0.0 product)</p>

<p>The percentile ranges for each compositing period can be used to identify the 'greenest' observation i.e. 90th percentile of NDVI and low vegetation cover i.e. 10th percentile of NDVI that occurred within the compositing period. It is worth noting that in areas that are subject to inundation (clay pans, salt lakes, rivers, lakes, floodplains, wetlands) the percentile values of NDVI may be affected by open water. In these settings NDVI values may not be representative of 'vegetation cover'.</p>

<p>Seasons are defined as:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Season 1: December, January, February</li>
	<li>Season 2: March, April, May,</li>
	<li>Season 3: June, July, August</li>
	<li>Season 4: September, October, November</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

The NDVI statistics are calculated from the observations in the NDVI product (NDVI_25_2.0.0) that are not affected by cloud, cloud shadow or sensor saturation (as captured by the PQ_25_2.0.0 product)</p>

<p>The percentile ranges for each compositing period can be used to identify the 'greenest' observation i.e. 90th percentile of NDVI and low vegetation cover i.e. 10th percentile of NDVI that occurred within the compositing period. In these settings NDVI values may not be representative of 'vegetation cover'.</p>

<p>Seasons are defined as:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Season 1: December, January, February</li>
	<li>Season 2: March, April, May,</li>
	<li>Season 3: June, July, August</li>
	<li>Season 4: September, October, November</li>

No match node contents append: %!24%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The collection represents a multi-decadal record of surface brightness temperature (Kelvin) as observed by the Landsat series of satellites (5, 7 and 8).</p>

<p>The ground-sampling-distance of the Landsat thermal sensors is 120 metres (Landsat 5 TM), 60 metres (Landsat 7 ETM+) and 100 metres (Landsat 8 TIRS). All sensors are resampled to 25 metres to enable analysis of thermal data in the context of the optical wavelengths.</p>

<p>Whilst the data is resampled to 25 metres, the variable/coarser spatial resolution of the thermal sensors means that caution should be used when measuring features that are at or below 200 metres in scale (~2 ground sample distance units wide).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

<p>The ground-sampling-distance of the Landsat thermal sensors is 120 metres (Landsat 5 TM), 60 metres (Landsat 7 ETM+) and 100 metres (Landsat 8 TIRS). All sensors are resampled to 25 metres to enable analysis of thermal data in the context of the optical wavelengths.</p>

<p>Whilst the data is resampled to 25 metres, the variable/coarser spatial resolution of the thermal sensors means that caution should be used when measuring features that are at or below 200 metres in scale (~2 ground sample distance units wide).</p>

attempting match on: %!12552%!
No match node contents append: %!12552%!
attempting match on: </field_security_classification><field_services/><field_simple_title><value>Surface Brightness Temperature 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_subject_matter_experts/><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>Surface temperature (Ts) is a key boundary condition in many remote sensing-based land surface modeling schemes including calculating evapotranspiration, water balance modelling and vegetation condition assessment. Surface brightness temperature is a measure of the temperature of the Earth's surface that has not been corrected for emissivity. The LST_25 product is a 25 metre resolution surface brightness temperature measurement calculated from the Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+ and Landsat 8 TIRS sensors. The surface brightness temperature (Kelvin) is calculated using MODTRAN software and atmospheric profile data from the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF). Per pixel cloud/cloud shadow screening (PQ_25) can be used to screen cloud affected observation from the LST_25 meter product.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_update_frequency/><field_use_constraints/><field_version_number><value>1.0.0</value></field_version_number><field_websites/>

Surface brightness temperature is a measure of the temperature of the Earth's surface that has not been corrected for emissivity. The LST_25 product is a 25 metre resolution surface brightness temperature measurement calculated from the Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+ and Landsat 8 TIRS sensors. The surface brightness temperature (Kelvin) is calculated using MODTRAN software and atmospheric profile data from the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF). Per pixel cloud/cloud shadow screening (PQ_25) can be used to screen cloud affected observation from the LST_25 meter product.</p>

Hence, terminology has been adopted for the product to reflect the highest modelled tide observed in a given cell (HOT) and the lowest modelled tide observed (LOT) (Figure 2). These measures are relative to Mean Sea Level, and have no consistent relationship to Lowest (LAT) and Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Intertidal Extents Model 25m v. 1.1.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The purpose of the ITEM v1.1 product is to assist in understanding the extent and elevation profile of the Australian intertidal zone. Examples of where this knowledge can contribute include environmental monitoring applications for migratory bird species, habitat mapping in coastal regions, hydrodynamic modelling, and geomorphology studies of features in the intertidal zone.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.1) product analyses GAs historic archive of satellite imagery to derive a model of the spatial extents of the intertidal zone throughout the tidal cycle. The model can assist in understanding the relative elevation profile of the intertidal zone, delineating exposed areas at differing tidal heights and stages.</p>

<p>The product differs from previous methods used to map the intertidal zone which have been predominately focused on analysing a small number of individual satellite images per location (e.g Ryu et al., 2002; Murray et al., 2012). By utilising a full 28 year time series of observations, the methodology enables us to overcome the requirement for clear, high quality observations acquired concurrent to the time of high and low tide.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fk4/ITEM/catalog.html</uri><title>THREDDS</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>6e1e826e-90f1-41da-8346-1533c1e08097</value></uuid><vid><value>377</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>ITEM_25_1.1.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493967314</value></created><changed><value>1496112668</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112668</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Due the sun-synchronous nature of the various Landsat sensor observations; it is unlikely that the full physical extents of the tidal range in any cell will be observed. Hence, terminology has been adopted for the product to reflect the highest modelled tide observed in a given cell (HOT) and the lowest modelled tide observed (LOT) (Figure 2). These measures are relative to Mean Sea Level, and have no consistent relationship to Lowest (LAT) and Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Intertidal Extents Model 25m v. 1.1.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The purpose of the ITEM v1.1 product is to assist in understanding the extent and elevation profile of the Australian intertidal zone. Examples of where this knowledge can contribute include environmental monitoring applications for migratory bird species, habitat mapping in coastal regions, hydrodynamic modelling, and geomorphology studies of features in the intertidal zone.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.1) product analyses GAs historic archive of satellite imagery to derive a model of the spatial extents of the intertidal zone throughout the tidal cycle. The model can assist in understanding the relative elevation profile of the intertidal zone, delineating exposed areas at differing tidal heights and stages.</p>

<p>The product differs from previous methods used to map the intertidal zone which have been predominately focused on analysing a small number of individual satellite images per location (e.g Ryu et al., 2002; Murray et al., 2012). By utilising a full 28 year time series of observations, the methodology enables us to overcome the requirement for clear, high quality observations acquired concurrent to the time of high and low tide.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fk4/ITEM/catalog.html</uri><title>THREDDS</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>

No match node contents append: %!113%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents><value>McFeeters, S.K., 1996. The use of the Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI) in the delineation of open water features. Int. J. Remote Sens. 17, 1425&#x2013;1432. doi:10.1080/01431169608948714</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Murray, N.J., Phinn, S.R., Clemens, R.S., Roelfsema, C.M., Fuller, R.A., 2012. Continental Scale Mapping of Tidal Flats across East Asia Using the Landsat Archive. Remote Sens. 4, 3417&#x2013;3426. doi:10.3390/rs4113417</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Ryu, J.-H., Won, J.-S., Min, K.D., 2002. Waterline extraction from Landsat TM data in a tidal flat: A case study in Gomso Bay, Korea. Remote Sens. Environ. 83, 442&#x2013;456. doi:10.1016/S0034-4257(02)00059-7</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Sagar, S., Roberts, D., Bala, B., Lymburner, L., 2017. Extracting the intertidal extent and topography of the Australian coastline from a 28 year time series of Landsat observations. Remote Sensing of Environment 195, 153&#x2013;169. doi:10.1016/j.rse.2017.04.009</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F64E5BA264</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F64E5BA264</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F47F34675D</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5760F5452D371</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/5760F5452D371</title><options/></field_doi><field_ecat_id><value>100600</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.1) consists of three datasets derived from the Landsat NBAR data managed in the Australian Geoscience Data Cube (AGDC) for the period 1987 to 2015.</p>

<p>The <strong>Coastal Cells shapefile (ITEM_CoastalCells.shp)</strong> identifies the location and extents of the 221 one degree by one degree AGDC cells used in the product, covering the mainland and Tasmanian coastline of the continent (Figure 1). The shapefile also includes information on the lowest (LOT) and highest (HOT) observed tides for the cell, and hence the observed tidal range (HOT-LOT), based on tidal modelling for the time of acquisition of each of the corresponding Landsat tile observations in the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes: </em></strong></p>

<p>AGDC Cell Identifier</p>

<p>Lowest Observed Tide (LOT)  The lowest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>Highest Observed Tide (HOT)  The highest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>The <strong>Relative Extents Model (ITEM_REL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> utilises the tidal information attributed to each tile observation to indicate the spatial extent of intertidal substratum exposed at percentile intervals of the observed tidal range for the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster: </em></strong></p>

<p>0  Always water<br />
1  Exposed at lowest 0-10% of the observed tidal range<br />
2  Exposed at 10-20% of the observed tidal range<br />
3  Exposed at 20-30% of the observed tidal range<br />
4  Exposed at 30-40% of the observed tidal range<br />
5  Exposed at 40-50% of the observed tidal range<br />
6  Exposed at 50-60% of the observed tidal range<br />
7  Exposed at 60-70% of the observed tidal range<br />
8  Exposed at 70-80% of the observed tidal range<br />
9 - Exposed at highest 80-100% of the observed tidal range (land)<br />
-999  No Data</p>

<p>The <strong>Confidence Layer (ITEM_CL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> reflects the confidence level of the Relative Extents Model, based on the distribution of classification metrics within each of the percentile intervals of the tidal range. The layer should be used to filter region/pixels in the model where the derived spatial extents may be adversely affected by data and modelling errors.</p>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster:</em></strong></p>

<p>0  Model is invalid. Indicates pixels where data quality and/or number of observations have resulted in no available observations in one or more of the percentile interval subsets.</p>

<p>-32767  No Data</p>

<p>All other values  The pixel-based average of the NDWI standard deviations calculated independently for each percentile interval of the observed tidal range (x 1000).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

-999  No Data</p>

The current version utilises all Landsat observations (5, 7, and 8) for Australian coastal regions (excluding off-shore Territories) between 1987 and 2015 (inclusive).</p>

No match node contents append: %!162%!
attempting match on: </field_processing_steps><field_product_life_span/><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity/><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</value><end_value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact/><field_qa_time_frame/><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>The Confidence layer is designed to assess the reliability of the Relative Extent Model. Within each tidal range percentile interval, the pixel-based standard deviation of the NDWI values for all tiles in the interval subset is calculated. The average standard deviation across all tidal range intervals is then calculated and retained as a quality indicator in this product layer.</p>

<p>The Confidence Layer reflects the pixel based consistency of the NDWI values within each subset of observations, based on the tidal range. Higher standard deviation values indicate water classification changes not based on the tidal cycle, and hence lower confidence in the extent model. Possible drivers of these changes include:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Inadequacies of the tidal model, due perhaps to complex coastal bathymetry or estuarine structures not captured in the model.</li>
	<li>Change in the structure and exposure of water/non-water features NOT driven by tidal variation. For example, movement of sand banks in estuaries, construction of man-made features (ports etc.).</li>
	<li>Terrestrial/Inland water features not influenced by the tidal cycle.</li>
</ol>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>
No match node contents append: </field_processing_steps><field_product_life_span/><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity/><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</value><end_value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact/><field_qa_time_frame/><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>The Confidence layer is designed to assess the reliability of the Relative Extent Model. Within each tidal range percentile interval, the pixel-based standard deviation of the NDWI values for all tiles in the interval subset is calculated. The average standard deviation across all tidal range intervals is then calculated and retained as a quality indicator in this product layer.</p>

<p>The Confidence Layer reflects the pixel based consistency of the NDWI values within each subset of observations, based on the tidal range. Higher standard deviation values indicate water classification changes not based on the tidal cycle, and hence lower confidence in the extent model. Possible drivers of these changes include:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Inadequacies of the tidal model, due perhaps to complex coastal bathymetry or estuarine structures not captured in the model.</li>
	<li>Change in the structure and exposure of water/non-water features NOT driven by tidal variation. For example, movement of sand banks in estuaries, construction of man-made features (ports etc.).</li>
	<li>Terrestrial/Inland water features not influenced by the tidal cycle.</li>
</ol>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>

ITEM provides the extent and topography of the intertidal zone of Australia's coastline (excluding off-shore Territories). This information was collated using observations in the Landsat archive since 1987. ITEM can be a valuable complimentary dataset to both onshore LiDAR survey data and coarser offshore bathymetry data, enabling a more realistic representation of the land and ocean interface.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_update_frequency/><field_use_constraints/><field_version_number><value>1.1.0</value></field_version_number><field_websites><uri>http://eos.ga.gov.au</uri><title>http://eos.ga.gov.au</title><options/></field_websites>
No match node contents append: </field_security_classification><field_services><uri><![CDATA[http://geoserver.nci.org.au/geoserver/ITEM/wms?request=GetCapabilities&service=WMS]]></uri><title>WMS</title><options/></field_services><field_services><uri><![CDATA[http://geoserver.nci.org.au/geoserver/ITEM/wcs?request=GetCapabilities&service=WCS]]></uri><title>WCS</title><options/></field_services><field_simple_title><value>Intertidal Extents Model</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_subject_matter_experts/><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM) product is a national dataset of the exposed intertidal zone; the land between the observed highest and lowest tide. ITEM provides the extent and topography of the intertidal zone of Australia's coastline (excluding off-shore Territories). This information was collated using observations in the Landsat archive since 1987. ITEM can be a valuable complimentary dataset to both onshore LiDAR survey data and coarser offshore bathymetry data, enabling a more realistic representation of the land and ocean interface.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_update_frequency/><field_use_constraints/><field_version_number><value>1.1.0</value></field_version_number><field_websites><uri>http://eos.ga.gov.au</uri><title>http://eos.ga.gov.au</title><options/></field_websites>

	-<uuid><value>6e1e826e-90f1-41da-8346-1533c1e08097</value></uuid><vid><value>377</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>ITEM_25_1.1.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493967314</value></created><changed><value>1496112668</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112668</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Due the sun-synchronous nature of the various Landsat sensor observations; it is unlikely that the full physical extents of the tidal range in any cell will be observed. Hence, terminology has been adopted for the product to reflect the highest modelled tide observed in a given cell (HOT) and the lowest modelled tide observed (LOT) (Figure 2). These measures are relative to Mean Sea Level, and have no consistent relationship to Lowest (LAT) and Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Intertidal Extents Model 25m v. 1.1.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The purpose of the ITEM v1.1 product is to assist in understanding the extent and elevation profile of the Australian intertidal zone. Examples of where this knowledge can contribute include environmental monitoring applications for migratory bird species, habitat mapping in coastal regions, hydrodynamic modelling, and geomorphology studies of features in the intertidal zone.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.1) product analyses GAs historic archive of satellite imagery to derive a model of the spatial extents of the intertidal zone throughout the tidal cycle. The model can assist in understanding the relative elevation profile of the intertidal zone, delineating exposed areas at differing tidal heights and stages.</p>

<p>The product differs from previous methods used to map the intertidal zone which have been predominately focused on analysing a small number of individual satellite images per location (e.g Ryu et al., 2002; Murray et al., 2012). By utilising a full 28 year time series of observations, the methodology enables us to overcome the requirement for clear, high quality observations acquired concurrent to the time of high and low tide.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fk4/ITEM/catalog.html</uri><title>THREDDS</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>

	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents><value>McFeeters, S.K., 1996. The use of the Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI) in the delineation of open water features. Int. J. Remote Sens. 17, 1425&#x2013;1432. doi:10.1080/01431169608948714</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Murray, N.J., Phinn, S.R., Clemens, R.S., Roelfsema, C.M., Fuller, R.A., 2012. Continental Scale Mapping of Tidal Flats across East Asia Using the Landsat Archive. Remote Sens. 4, 3417&#x2013;3426. doi:10.3390/rs4113417</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Ryu, J.-H., Won, J.-S., Min, K.D., 2002. Waterline extraction from Landsat TM data in a tidal flat: A case study in Gomso Bay, Korea. Remote Sens. Environ. 83, 442&#x2013;456. doi:10.1016/S0034-4257(02)00059-7</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Sagar, S., Roberts, D., Bala, B., Lymburner, L., 2017. Extracting the intertidal extent and topography of the Australian coastline from a 28 year time series of Landsat observations. Remote Sensing of Environment 195, 153&#x2013;169. doi:10.1016/j.rse.2017.04.009</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F64E5BA264</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F64E5BA264</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F47F34675D</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5760F5452D371</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/5760F5452D371</title><options/></field_doi><field_ecat_id><value>100600</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.1) consists of three datasets derived from the Landsat NBAR data managed in the Australian Geoscience Data Cube (AGDC) for the period 1987 to 2015.</p>

<p>The <strong>Coastal Cells shapefile (ITEM_CoastalCells.shp)</strong> identifies the location and extents of the 221 one degree by one degree AGDC cells used in the product, covering the mainland and Tasmanian coastline of the continent (Figure 1). The shapefile also includes information on the lowest (LOT) and highest (HOT) observed tides for the cell, and hence the observed tidal range (HOT-LOT), based on tidal modelling for the time of acquisition of each of the corresponding Landsat tile observations in the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes: </em></strong></p>

<p>AGDC Cell Identifier</p>

<p>Lowest Observed Tide (LOT)  The lowest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>Highest Observed Tide (HOT)  The highest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>The <strong>Relative Extents Model (ITEM_REL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> utilises the tidal information attributed to each tile observation to indicate the spatial extent of intertidal substratum exposed at percentile intervals of the observed tidal range for the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster: </em></strong></p>

<p>0  Always water<br />
1  Exposed at lowest 0-10% of the observed tidal range<br />
2  Exposed at 10-20% of the observed tidal range<br />
3  Exposed at 20-30% of the observed tidal range<br />
4  Exposed at 30-40% of the observed tidal range<br />
5  Exposed at 40-50% of the observed tidal range<br />
6  Exposed at 50-60% of the observed tidal range<br />
7  Exposed at 60-70% of the observed tidal range<br />
8  Exposed at 70-80% of the observed tidal range<br />
9 - Exposed at highest 80-100% of the observed tidal range (land)<br />
-999  No Data</p>

<p>The <strong>Confidence Layer (ITEM_CL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> reflects the confidence level of the Relative Extents Model, based on the distribution of classification metrics within each of the percentile intervals of the tidal range. The layer should be used to filter region/pixels in the model where the derived spatial extents may be adversely affected by data and modelling errors.</p>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster:</em></strong></p>

<p>0  Model is invalid. Indicates pixels where data quality and/or number of observations have resulted in no available observations in one or more of the percentile interval subsets.</p>

<p>-32767  No Data</p>

<p>All other values  The pixel-based average of the NDWI standard deviations calculated independently for each percentile interval of the observed tidal range (x 1000).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

	-%!24%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.1) product is a national scale gridded dataset characterising the spatial extents of the exposed intertidal zone, at intervals of the observed tidal range. The current version utilises all Landsat observations (5, 7, and 8) for Australian coastal regions (excluding off-shore Territories) between 1987 and 2015 (inclusive).</p>

	-%!162%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_product_life_span/><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity/><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</value><end_value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact/><field_qa_time_frame/><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>The Confidence layer is designed to assess the reliability of the Relative Extent Model. Within each tidal range percentile interval, the pixel-based standard deviation of the NDWI values for all tiles in the interval subset is calculated. The average standard deviation across all tidal range intervals is then calculated and retained as a quality indicator in this product layer.</p>

<p>The Confidence Layer reflects the pixel based consistency of the NDWI values within each subset of observations, based on the tidal range. Higher standard deviation values indicate water classification changes not based on the tidal cycle, and hence lower confidence in the extent model. Possible drivers of these changes include:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Inadequacies of the tidal model, due perhaps to complex coastal bathymetry or estuarine structures not captured in the model.</li>
	<li>Change in the structure and exposure of water/non-water features NOT driven by tidal variation. For example, movement of sand banks in estuaries, construction of man-made features (ports etc.).</li>
	<li>Terrestrial/Inland water features not influenced by the tidal cycle.</li>
</ol>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>

ITEM provides the extent and topography of the intertidal zone of Australia's coastline (excluding off-shore Territories). This information was collated using observations in the Landsat archive since 1987. ITEM can be a valuable complimentary dataset to both onshore LiDAR survey data and coarser offshore bathymetry data, enabling a more realistic representation of the land and ocean interface.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_update_frequency/><field_use_constraints/><field_version_number><value>1.1.0</value></field_version_number><field_websites><uri>http://eos.ga.gov.au</uri><title>http://eos.ga.gov.au</title><options/></field_websites>

attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The product is composed of the synthetic median surface reflectance values based on an ensemble of tiles observed at the lowest tidal epochs for a specified date range, estimated for each cell in the AGDC archive. The product also includes the count of clear observations per pixel, and the tidal offset range utilised for each cell.</p>

<p>The product will utilise tidal offset values relative to MSL, calculated for each coastal tile observation at time of acquisition, using the Oregon State Tidal Prediction (OTPS) software TPX08 Atlas model (<a href="http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html">http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html</a>).</p>

<p>Observations per coastal cell will then be sorted by tidal offset to obtain tiles corresponding to the lowest 10% of tides observed in the archive. A band based median for each Landsat band will then be calculated from the lowest 10% subset of tiles for each cell.</p>

<p>Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 8 OLI data will be used for this product, as inclusion of Landsat 7 leaves a large number of data artefacts.</p>

<p>The product will be calculated for the epoch 1995-2015.</p>

<p>Observations will be filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

The product also includes the count of clear observations per pixel, and the tidal offset range utilised for each cell.</p>

<p>The product will utilise tidal offset values relative to MSL, calculated for each coastal tile observation at time of acquisition, using the Oregon State Tidal Prediction (OTPS) software TPX08 Atlas model (<a href="http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html">http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html</a>).</p>

<p>Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 8 OLI data will be used for this product, as inclusion of Landsat 7 leaves a large number of data artefacts.</p>

<p>The product will be calculated for the epoch 1995-2015.</p>

match node contents append: <nid><value>119</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>cc2b37b8-e1f4-454b-a1be-09f72814c5a2</value></uuid><vid><value>380</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>FC_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493962627</value></created><changed><value>1496112795</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112795</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>in_development</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Based on the comparison with the field data the FC product has an overall Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 11.8%. The error margins vary for the three different layers: green RMSE: 11.0%, non-green RMSE: 17.4% and bare RMSE: 12.5%.</p>

<p>The effect of soil moisture may impact the accuracy of the FC product, and the similarity between some bare soil endmembers and non-photosynthetic vegetation endmembers can lead to model instability. Pixels that show poor model stability are flagged in the model error band as a value of 2, and can be omitted from further analysis if necessary.</p>

<p>FC products have no water masking applied, so erroneous values for green vegetation over the water may appear. These should be ignored and can be masked out by applying the Water Observations (WO) layer.</p>

<p>Occasionally the sum of the three components is not equal to 100%. Differences are usually small and are not rounded in order to preserve what may be useful seasonal indicators.</p>

<p>Landsat 8 OLI has different relative spectral response curves to the Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+ sensors. As a consequence the absolute values for fractional cover estimated from unadjusted Landsat 8 OLI data using the current algorithm may be inaccurate. The magnitude of this impact is described in more detail in Flood (2014).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25 v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environemental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australias longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australias partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a consistent classification which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

The error margins vary for the three different layers: green RMSE: 11.0%, non-green RMSE: 17.4% and bare RMSE: 12.5%.</p>

<p>The effect of soil moisture may impact the accuracy of the FC product, and the similarity between some bare soil endmembers and non-photosynthetic vegetation endmembers can lead to model instability. Pixels that show poor model stability are flagged in the model error band as a value of 2, and can be omitted from further analysis if necessary.</p>

<p>FC products have no water masking applied, so erroneous values for green vegetation over the water may appear. These should be ignored and can be masked out by applying the Water Observations (WO) layer.</p>

<p>Occasionally the sum of the three components is not equal to 100%. Differences are usually small and are not rounded in order to preserve what may be useful seasonal indicators.</p>

<p>Landsat 8 OLI has different relative spectral response curves to the Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+ sensors. As a consequence the absolute values for fractional cover estimated from unadjusted Landsat 8 OLI data using the current algorithm may be inaccurate. The magnitude of this impact is described in more detail in Flood (2014).</p>

These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australias longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australias partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 January 2011, www.scribd.com/doc/37455826/15arspc-Submission-119.]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>79676</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress><value>75</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-06-30</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>To maintain compatibility with the Joint Remote Sensing Research Programs Fractional Cover product the values for this product are scaled as follows:<br />
For the fractional cover bands (PV, NPV, BS)<br />
0-100 = no data values<br />
101-200 = fractional cover values that range between 1 and 100%</p>

<p>For example an area that has green (photosynthetic) vegetation cover of 50% would have a PV value of 150.<br />
For the unmixing error (UE) band, the values are scaled as per the JRSRP product.</p>

Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and Sciences, Canberra, Australia. (https://remote-sensing.nci.org.au/u39/public/html/modis/fractionalcover-sitedata-abares/index.shtml). Remote Sensing, 6, 7952-7970.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Muir, J., Schmidt, M., Tindall, D., Trevithick, R., Scarth, P., Stewart, J., 2011. Guidelines for Field measurement of fractional ground cover: a technical handbook supporting the Australian collaborative land use and management program. Tech. rep., Queensland Department of Environment and Resource Management for the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and Sciences, Canberra.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value><![CDATA[Scarth, P., Roder, A. and Schmidt, M., 2010. Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction  the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 January 2011, www.scribd.com/doc/37455672/15arspc-Submission-140.]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value><![CDATA[Schmidt, M., Denham, R. and Scarth, P., 2010. Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 January 2011, www.scribd.com/doc/37455826/15arspc-Submission-119.]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>79676</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress><value>75</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-06-30</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>To maintain compatibility with the Joint Remote Sensing Research Programs Fractional Cover product the values for this product are scaled as follows:<br />
For the fractional cover bands (PV, NPV, BS)<br />
0-100 = no data values<br />
101-200 = fractional cover values that range between 1 and 100%</p>

<p>For example an area that has green (photosynthetic) vegetation cover of 50% would have a PV value of 150.<br />
For the unmixing error (UE) band, the values are scaled as per the JRSRP product.</p>

attempting match on: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name><value>Fractional Cover (FC25)</value></field_nci_product_name><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
No match node contents append: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name><value>Fractional Cover (FC25)</value></field_nci_product_name><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!24%!
No match node contents append: %!24%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>

attempting match on: </field_security_classification><field_services/><field_simple_title><value>Fractional Cover</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_subject_matter_experts/><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional Cover (FC) is one of two vegetation-related products currently offered by the AGDC, the other being the Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) product. FC provides a 25m x 25m ground footprint of the proportions of living vegetation, dry/dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dry grass, etc.), and bare soils across the whole Australian continent. This information is available for any location and point in time over Australia since 1987 till now. FC can potentially provide insights into areas of dry/dying vegetation and/or bare soil as well as allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_update_frequency/><field_use_constraints/><field_version_number><value>2.0.0</value></field_version_number><field_websites/>
No match node contents append: </field_security_classification><field_services/><field_simple_title><value>Fractional Cover</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_subject_matter_experts/><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional Cover (FC) is one of two vegetation-related products currently offered by the AGDC, the other being the Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) product. FC provides a 25m x 25m ground footprint of the proportions of living vegetation, dry/dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dry grass, etc.), and bare soils across the whole Australian continent. This information is available for any location and point in time over Australia since 1987 till now. FC can potentially provide insights into areas of dry/dying vegetation and/or bare soil as well as allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_update_frequency/><field_use_constraints/><field_version_number><value>2.0.0</value></field_version_number><field_websites/>
