Adding node contents to map with id: 119
	-<nid><value>119</value></nid>
	-<uuid><value>cc2b37b8-e1f4-454b-a1be-09f72814c5a2</value></uuid><vid><value>380</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>FC_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493962627</value></created><changed><value>1496112795</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112795</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>in_development</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Based on the comparison with the field data the FC product has an overall Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 11.8%. The error margins vary for the three different layers: green RMSE: 11.0%, non-green RMSE: 17.4% and bare RMSE: 12.5%.</p>

<p>The effect of soil moisture may impact the accuracy of the FC product, and the similarity between some bare soil endmembers and non-photosynthetic vegetation endmembers can lead to model instability. Pixels that show poor model stability are flagged in the model error band as a value of 2, and can be omitted from further analysis if necessary.</p>

<p>FC products have no water masking applied, so erroneous values for green vegetation over the water may appear. These should be ignored and can be masked out by applying the Water Observations (WO) layer.</p>

<p>Occasionally the sum of the three components is not equal to 100%. Differences are usually small and are not rounded in order to preserve what may be useful seasonal indicators.</p>

<p>Landsat 8 OLI has different relative spectral response curves to the Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+ sensors. As a consequence the absolute values for fractional cover estimated from unadjusted Landsat 8 OLI data using the current algorithm may be inaccurate. The magnitude of this impact is described in more detail in Flood (2014).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25 v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environemental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australias longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australias partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a consistent classification which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>
	-%!12561%!
	-</field_resource_type><field_rights_statement><value><![CDATA[<p><span></span> Commonwealth of Australia (Geoscience Australia) 2015. Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_rights_statement><field_schema/><field_security_classification>
	-%!12552%!
	-</field_security_classification><field_services/><field_simple_title><value>Fractional Cover</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_subject_matter_experts/><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional Cover (FC) is one of two vegetation-related products currently offered by the AGDC, the other being the Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) product. FC provides a 25m x 25m ground footprint of the proportions of living vegetation, dry/dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dry grass, etc.), and bare soils across the whole Australian continent. This information is available for any location and point in time over Australia since 1987 till now. FC can potentially provide insights into areas of dry/dying vegetation and/or bare soil as well as allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_update_frequency/><field_use_constraints/><field_version_number><value>2.0.0</value></field_version_number><field_websites/>
matches: [0] = <nid><value>168 [1] = nid [2] = 168
match node contents append: <nid><value>168</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>6dcc2e17-6204-4a76-8883-c18470e92ca1</value></uuid><vid><value>381</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>FC_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495500857</value></created><changed><value>1496112846</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112846</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>Based on the comparison with the field data the FC25 product has an overall Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 11.8%. The error margins vary for the three different layers: green RMSE: 11.0%, non-green RMSE: 17.4% and bare RMSE: 12.5%.</span></span></p>

<p>The effect of soil moisture may impact the accuracy of the FC25 product, and the similarity between some bare soil endmembers and non-photosynthetic vegetation endmembers can lead to model instability.&#160; Pixels that show poor model stability are flagged in Band 4 (the mask band) as a value of 2, and can be omitted from further analysis if necessary.</p>

<p>Scene-based FC products have no ocean masking applied, so erroneous values for green vegetation over the ocean may appear. These should be ignored.</p>

<p>Occasionally the sum of the three components is not equal to 100%. Differences are usually small and are not rounded in order to preserve what may be useful seasonal indicators.&#160;</p>

<p><span><span>Landsat 8 OLI has different relative spectral response curves to the Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+ sensors.&#160; As a consequence the absolute values for fractional cover estimated from unadjusted Landsat 8 OLI data using the current algorithm may be inaccurate.&#160; The magnitude of this impact is described in more detail in Flood (2014).</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25 v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environmental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
</ul>

<p><span><span>Ecosystem modelling</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span><span>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>FC25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and the leadership and capabilities of Geoscience Australia and the </span></span></span><span><span>Joint Remote Sensing Research Program</span></span><span><span><span>. The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australias longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible.&#160; Geoscience Australias partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube  a high performance data framework  makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data. </span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>FC25 provides a consistent classification which will be an important foundation for fractional cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</span></span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

attempting match on: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>The Fractional Cover product provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegeta</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
No match node contents append: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>The Fractional Cover product provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegeta</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!24%!
No match node contents append: %!24%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover data &#160;can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition.<span><span> This information could enable </span></span>policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>

<p><span><span>The fractional cover unmixing algorthim uses the spectral signature for a picture element (pixel) to break it up into three parts or fractions. This is based on field work identifying the spectral characteristics of each of the fractions. The three fractions are green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare soil. The green fraction includes leaves and grass, the non-photosynthetic includes branches, dry grass and dead leaf litter, and the bare soil fraction includes bare soil or rock.</span></span></p>

<p>FC25 is limited by the frequency and number of successful observations, which are determined by the satellite revisit rate (see table below) and by clouds. In particular, short-lived green flush grass growth events may not have been observed. In practice, areas of inland Australia have been observed over 600 times, whereas highly-cloud-prone coastal and mountainous areas may have no successful observations (see Figure 1). FC25 is also limited by the quality of the sensors, including their spatial resolution, and the accuracy of the fractional cover algorithms used.</p>

<table align="center" border="1" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" style="width: 500px;">
	<caption><strong>Table 1 Revisit frequency of the Landsat series of satellites as captured by the Geoscience Australia ground station network.</strong></caption>
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th scope="col">Time Range</th>
			<th scope="col">Revisit frequency</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td align="center">1986-2003</td>
			<td align="center">16 days</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td align="center">2003-2011<sup>2</sup></td>
			<td align="center">8 days</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td align="center">2011-2013<sup>3</sup></td>
			<td align="center">16 days</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td align="center">2013-present<sup>4</sup></td>
			<td align="center">8 days</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p>&#160;</p>

<p><a href="#_ftnref1"><span>[1]</span></a> This period represents the period when both Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 were being acquired by Geoscience Australia until Landsat 5 ceased operating in 2011.</p>

<p><a href="#_ftnref2"><span>[2]</span></a> The Landsat 7 ETM+ sensor suffered a scan-line-corrector failure in 2003, as a consequence, images acquired after that time have fewer observations and this appears as strips of missing data.&#160; This is visible as striping artefacts in parts of FC25.</p>

<p><a href="#_ftnref3"><span>[3]</span></a> This period represents the period when both Landsat 7 and Landsat 8 were being acquired by Geoscience Australia.</p>
]]></value><format>full_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover data &#160;can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition.<span><span> This information could enable </span></span>policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>

<p><span><span>The fractional cover unmixing algorthim uses the spectral signature for a picture element (pixel) to break it up into three parts or fractions. This is based on field work identifying the spectral characteristics of each of the fractions. The three fractions are green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare soil. The green fraction includes leaves and grass, the non-photosynthetic includes branches, dry grass and dead leaf litter, and the bare soil fraction includes bare soil or rock.</span></span></p>

<p>FC25 is limited by the frequency and number of successful observations, which are determined by the satellite revisit rate (see table below) and by clouds. In particular, short-lived green flush grass growth events may not have been observed. In practice, areas of inland Australia have been observed over 600 times, whereas highly-cloud-prone coastal and mountainous areas may have no successful observations (see Figure 1). FC25 is also limited by the quality of the sensors, including their spatial resolution, and the accuracy of the fractional cover algorithms used.</p>

<table align="center" border="1" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" style="width: 500px;">
	<caption><strong>Table 1 Revisit frequency of the Landsat series of satellites as captured by the Geoscience Australia ground station network.</strong></caption>
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th scope="col">Time Range</th>
			<th scope="col">Revisit frequency</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td align="center">1986-2003</td>
			<td align="center">16 days</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td align="center">2003-2011<sup>2</sup></td>
			<td align="center">8 days</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td align="center">2011-2013<sup>3</sup></td>
			<td align="center">16 days</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td align="center">2013-present<sup>4</sup></td>
			<td align="center">8 days</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p>&#160;</p>

<p><a href="#_ftnref1"><span>[1]</span></a> This period represents the period when both Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 were being acquired by Geoscience Australia until Landsat 5 ceased operating in 2011.</p>

<p><a href="#_ftnref2"><span>[2]</span></a> The Landsat 7 ETM+ sensor suffered a scan-line-corrector failure in 2003, as a consequence, images acquired after that time have fewer observations and this appears as strips of missing data.&#160; This is visible as striping artefacts in parts of FC25.</p>

<p><a href="#_ftnref3"><span>[3]</span></a> This period represents the period when both Landsat 7 and Landsat 8 were being acquired by Geoscience Australia.</p>

	-<nid><value>168</value></nid>
	-<uuid><value>6dcc2e17-6204-4a76-8883-c18470e92ca1</value></uuid><vid><value>381</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>FC_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495500857</value></created><changed><value>1496112846</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112846</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>Based on the comparison with the field data the FC25 product has an overall Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 11.8%. The error margins vary for the three different layers: green RMSE: 11.0%, non-green RMSE: 17.4% and bare RMSE: 12.5%.</span></span></p>

<p>The effect of soil moisture may impact the accuracy of the FC25 product, and the similarity between some bare soil endmembers and non-photosynthetic vegetation endmembers can lead to model instability.&#160; Pixels that show poor model stability are flagged in Band 4 (the mask band) as a value of 2, and can be omitted from further analysis if necessary.</p>

<p>Scene-based FC products have no ocean masking applied, so erroneous values for green vegetation over the ocean may appear. These should be ignored.</p>

<p>Occasionally the sum of the three components is not equal to 100%. Differences are usually small and are not rounded in order to preserve what may be useful seasonal indicators.&#160;</p>

<p><span><span>Landsat 8 OLI has different relative spectral response curves to the Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+ sensors.&#160; As a consequence the absolute values for fractional cover estimated from unadjusted Landsat 8 OLI data using the current algorithm may be inaccurate.&#160; The magnitude of this impact is described in more detail in Flood (2014).</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25 v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environmental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
</ul>

<p><span><span>Ecosystem modelling</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span><span>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>FC25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and the leadership and capabilities of Geoscience Australia and the </span></span></span><span><span>Joint Remote Sensing Research Program</span></span><span><span><span>. The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australias longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible.&#160; Geoscience Australias partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube  a high performance data framework  makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data. </span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>FC25 provides a consistent classification which will be an important foundation for fractional cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</span></span></span></p>

	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>The Fractional Cover product provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegeta</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover data &#160;can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition.<span><span> This information could enable </span></span>policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>

<p><span><span>The fractional cover unmixing algorthim uses the spectral signature for a picture element (pixel) to break it up into three parts or fractions. This is based on field work identifying the spectral characteristics of each of the fractions. The three fractions are green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare soil. The green fraction includes leaves and grass, the non-photosynthetic includes branches, dry grass and dead leaf litter, and the bare soil fraction includes bare soil or rock.</span></span></p>

<p>FC25 is limited by the frequency and number of successful observations, which are determined by the satellite revisit rate (see table below) and by clouds. In particular, short-lived green flush grass growth events may not have been observed. In practice, areas of inland Australia have been observed over 600 times, whereas highly-cloud-prone coastal and mountainous areas may have no successful observations (see Figure 1). FC25 is also limited by the quality of the sensors, including their spatial resolution, and the accuracy of the fractional cover algorithms used.</p>

<table align="center" border="1" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" style="width: 500px;">
	<caption><strong>Table 1 Revisit frequency of the Landsat series of satellites as captured by the Geoscience Australia ground station network.</strong></caption>
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th scope="col">Time Range</th>
			<th scope="col">Revisit frequency</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td align="center">1986-2003</td>
			<td align="center">16 days</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td align="center">2003-2011<sup>2</sup></td>
			<td align="center">8 days</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td align="center">2011-2013<sup>3</sup></td>
			<td align="center">16 days</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td align="center">2013-present<sup>4</sup></td>
			<td align="center">8 days</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p>&#160;</p>

<p><a href="#_ftnref1"><span>[1]</span></a> This period represents the period when both Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 were being acquired by Geoscience Australia until Landsat 5 ceased operating in 2011.</p>

<p><a href="#_ftnref2"><span>[2]</span></a> The Landsat 7 ETM+ sensor suffered a scan-line-corrector failure in 2003, as a consequence, images acquired after that time have fewer observations and this appears as strips of missing data.&#160; This is visible as striping artefacts in parts of FC25.</p>

<p><a href="#_ftnref3"><span>[3]</span></a> This period represents the period when both Landsat 7 and Landsat 8 were being acquired by Geoscience Australia.</p>
]]></value><format>full_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

	-%!26%!

<p><a href="http://data.auscover.org.au/xwiki/bin/view/Product+pages/Landsat+Fractional+Cover"><span><span>http://data.auscover.org.au/xwiki/bin/view/Product+pages/Landsat+Fractional+Cover</span></span></a></p>

<p><span><span>The bare soil, green vegetation and non-green vegetation endmenbers are calculated using models linked to an intensive field sampling program whereby more than 600 sites covering a wide variety of vegetation, soil and climate types were sampled to measure overstorey and ground cover following the procedure outlined in Muir et al (2011). </span></span></p>

	-%!12552%!
	-</field_security_classification><field_services/><field_simple_title><value>Fractional Cover 1.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_subject_matter_experts/><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>The Fractional Cover product is derived from Geoscience Australias Australian Reflectance Grid 25 (ARG25) product and provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent.&#160; It is generated using the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and described in Scarth et al. (2010)</p>

<p><span><span>The FC25 product suite is currently available for every scene Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) scene acquired since 1987</span></span> (for scenes that were successfully processed through to surface reflectance).</p>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>dd8d2898-fb38-4c24-b5c2-f77fe84d36af</value></uuid><vid><value>382</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>FC-STATS_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493964077</value></created><changed><value>1496112884</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112884</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>in_development</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australias satellite reception facility or download. The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture &amp; ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent. FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25 Statistics</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environmental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australia?s longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australia's partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS provides a consistent summary of fractional cover which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>dd8d2898-fb38-4c24-b5c2-f77fe84d36af</value></uuid><vid><value>382</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>FC-STATS_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493964077</value></created><changed><value>1496112884</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112884</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>in_development</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australias satellite reception facility or download. The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture &amp; ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent. FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25 Statistics</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environmental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australia?s longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australia's partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS provides a consistent summary of fractional cover which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>

attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents><value>ABARES, 2014 Australian ground cover reference sites database 2014. Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and Sciences, Canberra, Australia. (https://remote-sensing.nci.org.au/u39/public/html/modis/fractionalcover-sitedata-abares/index.shtml).</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Flood, N., 2014. Continuity of Reflectance Data between Landsat-7 ETM+ and Landsat-8 OLI, for Both Top-of-Atmosphere and Surface Reflectance: A Study in the Australian Landscape. Remote Sensing, 6, 7952-7970.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Muir, J., Schmidt, M., Tindall, D., Trevithick, R., Scarth, P., Stewart, J., 2011. Guidelines for Field measurement of fractional ground cover: a technical handbook supporting the Australian collaborative land use and management program. Tech. rep., Queensland Department of Environment and Resource Management for the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and Sciences, Canberra.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value><![CDATA[Scarth, P., Roder, A. and Schmidt, M., 2010. Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction  the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 January 2011, www.scribd.com/doc/37455672/15arspc-Submission-140.]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value><![CDATA[Schmidt, M., Denham, R. and Scarth, P., 2010. Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 January 2011, www.scribd.com/doc/37455826/15arspc-Submission-119.]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>79676</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress><value>50</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-06-30</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental composites for each cover fraction.</p>

<p>The percentile ranges for each compositing period can be used to identify the 'greenest' observation i.e. 90th percentile of green cover and 'barest' observation i.e. 90th percentile of bare soil that occurred within the compositing period.</p>

<p>The 10th and 90th percentile are used in preference to the minimum and maximum values because they are less prone to residual noise associated with undetected cloud/cloud shadow. The 50th percentile (median) are used in preference to the mean as the median is less prone to being skewed by extreme values. It is worth noting that some undetected cloud and cloud shadow artefacts may still be present in the 10th and 90th percentiles, especially in areas with frequent cloud cover such as the wet tropics and Tasmania.</p>

<p>To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated using the following satellites for the following periods of time:<br />
1987-1998 : Landsat 5<br />
1999 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2000-2002 : Landsat 7<br />
2003 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2004-2010 : Landsat 5<br />
2011-2012 : Landsat 7<br />
2013 onward : Landsat 8</p>

<p>To maintain compatibility with the Joint Remote Sensing Research Programs Fractional Cover product the values for this product are scaled as follows:<br />
For the fractional cover bands (PV, NPV, BS)<br />
0-100 = no data values<br />
101-200 = fractional cover values that range between 1 and 100%</p>

<p>For example an area that has green (photosynthetic) vegetation cover of 50% would have a PV value of 150<br />
For the unmixing error (UE) band, the values are scaled as per the JRSRP product.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

<p>The percentile ranges for each compositing period can be used to identify the 'greenest' observation i.e. 90th percentile of green cover and 'barest' observation i.e. 90th percentile of bare soil that occurred within the compositing period.</p>

<p>The 10th and 90th percentile are used in preference to the minimum and maximum values because they are less prone to residual noise associated with undetected cloud/cloud shadow. The 50th percentile (median) are used in preference to the mean as the median is less prone to being skewed by extreme values. It is worth noting that some undetected cloud and cloud shadow artefacts may still be present in the 10th and 90th percentiles, especially in areas with frequent cloud cover such as the wet tropics and Tasmania.</p>

1987-1998 : Landsat 5<br />

2003 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2004-2010 : Landsat 5<br />
2011-2012 : Landsat 7<br />
2013 onward : Landsat 8</p>

For the fractional cover bands (PV, NPV, BS)<br />
0-100 = no data values<br />
101-200 = fractional cover values that range between 1 and 100%</p>

attempting match on: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
No match node contents append: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!24%!
No match node contents append: %!24%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental seasonal (most recent 8 seasons) and annual (each calendar year from 1987 to present) statistical (10th, 50th and 90th percentile) summaries of fractional cover. The fractional cover statistics are calculated from the fractional cover product (FC_25_2.0.0)</p>

<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC-STATS_25 provides fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental seasonal (most recent 8 seasons) and annual (each calendar year from 1987 to present) statistical (10th, 50th and 90th percentile) summaries of fractional cover. The fractional cover statistics are calculated from the fractional cover product (FC_25_2.0.0)</p>

<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC-STATS_25 provides fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>

The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture &amp; ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent. FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25 Statistics</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environmental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australia?s longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australia's partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS provides a consistent summary of fractional cover which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents><value>ABARES, 2014 Australian ground cover reference sites database 2014. Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and Sciences, Canberra, Australia. (https://remote-sensing.nci.org.au/u39/public/html/modis/fractionalcover-sitedata-abares/index.shtml).</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Flood, N., 2014. Continuity of Reflectance Data between Landsat-7 ETM+ and Landsat-8 OLI, for Both Top-of-Atmosphere and Surface Reflectance: A Study in the Australian Landscape. Remote Sensing, 6, 7952-7970.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Muir, J., Schmidt, M., Tindall, D., Trevithick, R., Scarth, P., Stewart, J., 2011. Guidelines for Field measurement of fractional ground cover: a technical handbook supporting the Australian collaborative land use and management program. Tech. rep., Queensland Department of Environment and Resource Management for the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and Sciences, Canberra.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value><![CDATA[Scarth, P., Roder, A. and Schmidt, M., 2010. Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction  the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 January 2011, www.scribd.com/doc/37455672/15arspc-Submission-140.]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value><![CDATA[Schmidt, M., Denham, R. and Scarth, P., 2010. Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 January 2011, www.scribd.com/doc/37455826/15arspc-Submission-119.]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>79676</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress><value>50</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-06-30</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental composites for each cover fraction.</p>

<p>The percentile ranges for each compositing period can be used to identify the 'greenest' observation i.e. 90th percentile of green cover and 'barest' observation i.e. 90th percentile of bare soil that occurred within the compositing period.</p>

<p>The 10th and 90th percentile are used in preference to the minimum and maximum values because they are less prone to residual noise associated with undetected cloud/cloud shadow. The 50th percentile (median) are used in preference to the mean as the median is less prone to being skewed by extreme values. It is worth noting that some undetected cloud and cloud shadow artefacts may still be present in the 10th and 90th percentiles, especially in areas with frequent cloud cover such as the wet tropics and Tasmania.</p>

<p>To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated using the following satellites for the following periods of time:<br />
1987-1998 : Landsat 5<br />
1999 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2000-2002 : Landsat 7<br />
2003 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2004-2010 : Landsat 5<br />
2011-2012 : Landsat 7<br />
2013 onward : Landsat 8</p>

<p>To maintain compatibility with the Joint Remote Sensing Research Programs Fractional Cover product the values for this product are scaled as follows:<br />
For the fractional cover bands (PV, NPV, BS)<br />
0-100 = no data values<br />
101-200 = fractional cover values that range between 1 and 100%</p>

<p>For example an area that has green (photosynthetic) vegetation cover of 50% would have a PV value of 150<br />
For the unmixing error (UE) band, the values are scaled as per the JRSRP product.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental seasonal (most recent 8 seasons) and annual (each calendar year from 1987 to present) statistical (10th, 50th and 90th percentile) summaries of fractional cover. The fractional cover statistics are calculated from the fractional cover product (FC_25_2.0.0)</p>

<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC-STATS_25 provides fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The product is composed of the surface reflectance and fractional cover pixels corresponding to the 90th percentile bare soil value in the fractional cover. The product also includes the sensor, observation date and the count of values used to calculate the 90th percentile bare.</p>

<p>Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 8 OLI data will be used for this product, as inclusion of Landsat 7 leaves a large number of data artifacts. Observations are filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band), and water.</p>

<p>The product is calculated for the epoch 2000 - 2015.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

The product also includes the sensor, observation date and the count of values used to calculate the 90th percentile bare.</p>

<p>Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 8 OLI data will be used for this product, as inclusion of Landsat 7 leaves a large number of data artifacts. Observations are filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band), and water.</p>

<p>The product is calculated for the epoch 2000 - 2015.</p>

	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>The EEM product shows fractional cover pixels corresponding to the 90th percentile bare soil value.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The product is composed of the surface reflectance and fractional cover pixels corresponding to the 90th percentile bare soil value in the fractional cover. The product also includes the sensor, observation date and the count of values used to calculate the 90th percentile bare.</p>

<p>Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 8 OLI data will be used for this product, as inclusion of Landsat 7 leaves a large number of data artifacts. Observations are filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band), and water.</p>

<p>The product is calculated for the epoch 2000 - 2015.</p>

<ul>
	<li>data accuracy (as defined in Section 4.5);</li>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Dynamic Land Cover Dataset 25 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>DLCD can be used as an input for modelling:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Groundwater recharge and discharge</li>
	<li>Climate</li>
	<li>Wind and water erosion risk</li>
	<li>Evapotranspiration</li>
	<li>Carbon dynamics</li>
	<li>Land surface processes</li>
	<li>Inundation</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>In 2009 the National Committee for Land Use and Management Information identified the need for land cover information to facilitate change detection and improve natural resource management.</p>

<p>Existing land cover datasets are composites of State and Territory datasets which have been developed to meet specific legislative needs. This leads to thematic mismatches between different datasets and limits the capacity for meaningful change detection.</p>

<p>Nationally consistent and thematically comprehensive land cover information is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include sustainable farming practices, management of water resources, air quality, soil erosion and forests, as well as emergency management and urban planning.</p>

<p>The DLCD is based on an analysis of a 16-day EVI composite collected at 250 metre resolution using the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) satellite for the period 2000 to 2008.</p>

<p>The MODIS time series for each pixel was analysed using an innovative technique which reduced each time series into 12 coefficients based on the statistical, phenological and seasonal characteristics of each pixel. These coefficients were then clustered using a support vector clustering algorithm and the resultant classes were labelled using agreed National data supplied from catchment scale land use mapping and the National Vegetation Information System (NVIS).</p>

<p>The DLCD classification methodology and process along with major algorithms used are described in detail in the National Dynamic Land Cover Dataset - Technical Report (Lymburner et al, 2011).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

	<li>Climate</li>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>In 2009 the National Committee for Land Use and Management Information identified the need for land cover information to facilitate change detection and improve natural resource management.</p>

<p>Existing land cover datasets are composites of State and Territory datasets which have been developed to meet specific legislative needs. This leads to thematic mismatches between different datasets and limits the capacity for meaningful change detection.</p>

<p>Nationally consistent and thematically comprehensive land cover information is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include sustainable farming practices, management of water resources, air quality, soil erosion and forests, as well as emergency management and urban planning.</p>

<p>The DLCD is based on an analysis of a 16-day EVI composite collected at 250 metre resolution using the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) satellite for the period 2000 to 2008.</p>

<p>The MODIS time series for each pixel was analysed using an innovative technique which reduced each time series into 12 coefficients based on the statistical, phenological and seasonal characteristics of each pixel. These coefficients were then clustered using a support vector clustering algorithm and the resultant classes were labelled using agreed National data supplied from catchment scale land use mapping and the National Vegetation Information System (NVIS).</p>

<p>The DLCD classification methodology and process along with major algorithms used are described in detail in the National Dynamic Land Cover Dataset - Technical Report (Lymburner et al, 2011).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

attempting match on: </field_custodian><field_data_description><value><![CDATA[<p>DLCDv1_Class contains the final 34 DLC classes. The dataset includes a layer file and an attribute table for use in ArcGIS. The files are as follows:</p>

<p>DLCDv1_Class.tif : main DLC 34 class data file<br />
DLCDv1_Class.tif.vat.dbf : attribute table for 34 class data<br />
DLCDv1_Class.lyr : ArcGIS layer file for 34 class data<br />
DLCDv1_Class.tif.aux : ArcGIS auxiliary file</p>

<p>trend_evi_max shows the trend in the annual maximum of the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) from 2000 to 2008. The dataset includes a layer file and an attribute table for use in ArcGIS. The files are as follows:</p>

<p>trend_evi_max.tif : main evi max data file<br />
trend_evi_max.tif.lyr : ArcGIS layer file for max evi trend<br />
trend_evi_max.rrd : ArcGIS pyramid file<br />
trend_evi_max.aux : ArcGIS auxiliary file<br />
trend_evi_max.tif.xml : ArcGIS metadata file</p>

<p>trend_evi_mean shows the trend in the annual mean of the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) from 2000 to 2010. The dataset includes a layer file and an attribute table for use in ArcGIS. The files are as follows:</p>

<p>trend_evi_mean.tif : main evi mean data file<br />
trend_evi_mean.tif.lyr : ArcGIS layer file for mean evi trend<br />
trend_evi_mean.rrd : ArcGIS pyramid file<br />
trend_evi_mean.aux : ArcGIS auxiliary file<br />
trend_evi_mean.tif.xml : ArcGIS metadata file</p>

<p>trend_evi_min shows the trend in the annual minimum of the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) from 2000 to 2010. The dataset includes a layer file and an attribute table for use in ArcGIS. The files are as follows:</p>

<p>trend_evi_min.tif : main evi min data file<br />
trend_evi_min.tif.lyr : ArcGIS layer file for min evi trend<br />
trend_evi_min.rrd : ArcGIS pyramid file<br />
trend_evi_min.aux : ArcGIS auxiliary file<br />
trend_evi_min.tif.xml : ArcGIS metadata file</p>

<p>The DLCD Technical Report (Lymburner et. al., 2011) describes the DLCD, how the dataset was generated, presents a comparison of the DLCD with independent datasets and examples of how the DLCD classification can be used to analyse trends in the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) and other data sources. The files are as follows:</p>

<p>DLCD-Technical-Report.pdf</p>

attempting match on: %!113%!
No match node contents append: %!113%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents><value>Lymburner, L., Tan, P., Mueller, N., Thackway, R., Lewis, A., Thankappan. M., Randall, L., Islam, A., and Senarath, U. (2011). The Dynamic Land Cover Datset. 95pp. GA Record 2011/31, ISBN 978-1-921954-30-6, Geoscience Australia, Canberra.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress><value>100</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset (DLCD) is the first nationally consistent and thematically comprehensive land cover reference for Australia. It provides a basis for reporting on change and trends in vegetation cover and extent. Information about land cover dynamics is essential to understanding and addressing a range of national challenges such as drought, salinity, water availability and ecosystem health.</p>

<p>DLCD presents a synopsis of land cover information for every 250m by 250m area of the country from April 2000 to April 2008. The classification scheme used to describe land cover categories in the Dataset conforms to the 2007 International Organization for Standardization (ISO) land cover standard (19144-2). The Dataset shows Australian land covers clustered into 34 ISO classes. These reflect the structural character of vegetation, ranging from cultivated and managed land covers (crops and pastures) to natural land covers such as closed forest and open grasslands.</p>

<p>The source data for the Dataset is a time series of EVI data from the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on the Terra and Aqua satellites operated by NASA. The time series includes 186 snapshots of vegetation greenness for each 250m by 250m area across the continent over an 8 year period. An example of the time series displayed by different land cover types is shown in Figure 1.</p>

<p>The EVI time series for each 250m by 250m area was characterised using 12 time series coefficients which describe the statistical, phenological and seasonal characteristics of the land cover. A clustering approach was applied to the 12 coefficients to define homogenous regions with similar greenness dynamics over time.</p>

<p>Regions that showed similar greenness characteristics over time were labelled using information derived from the 2009 Catchment Scale Land Use of Australia dataset and Native Vegetation Information System dataset provided by the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics and Sciences (ABARES).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents><value>Lymburner, L., Tan, P., Mueller, N., Thackway, R., Lewis, A., Thankappan. M., Randall, L., Islam, A., and Senarath, U. (2011). The Dynamic Land Cover Datset. 95pp. GA Record 2011/31, ISBN 978-1-921954-30-6, Geoscience Australia, Canberra.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress><value>100</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset (DLCD) is the first nationally consistent and thematically comprehensive land cover reference for Australia. It provides a basis for reporting on change and trends in vegetation cover and extent. Information about land cover dynamics is essential to understanding and addressing a range of national challenges such as drought, salinity, water availability and ecosystem health.</p>

<p>DLCD presents a synopsis of land cover information for every 250m by 250m area of the country from April 2000 to April 2008. The classification scheme used to describe land cover categories in the Dataset conforms to the 2007 International Organization for Standardization (ISO) land cover standard (19144-2). The Dataset shows Australian land covers clustered into 34 ISO classes. These reflect the structural character of vegetation, ranging from cultivated and managed land covers (crops and pastures) to natural land covers such as closed forest and open grasslands.</p>

<p>The source data for the Dataset is a time series of EVI data from the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on the Terra and Aqua satellites operated by NASA. The time series includes 186 snapshots of vegetation greenness for each 250m by 250m area across the continent over an 8 year period. An example of the time series displayed by different land cover types is shown in Figure 1.</p>

<p>The EVI time series for each 250m by 250m area was characterised using 12 time series coefficients which describe the statistical, phenological and seasonal characteristics of the land cover. A clustering approach was applied to the 12 coefficients to define homogenous regions with similar greenness dynamics over time.</p>

<p>Regions that showed similar greenness characteristics over time were labelled using information derived from the 2009 Catchment Scale Land Use of Australia dataset and Native Vegetation Information System dataset provided by the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics and Sciences (ABARES).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset comprises digital files of the land cover classification showing the change in behaviour of land cover across Australia.</p>

<p>The DLCD includes data for every 250m by 250m area for the period 2000 to 2008. DLCD provides a base-line for identifying and reporting on change and trends in vegetation cover and extent.<br />
DLCD can be used as an input for modelling:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Groundwater recharge and discharge</li>
	<li>Climate</li>
	<li>Wind and water erosion risk</li>
	<li>Evapotranspiration</li>
	<li>Carbon dynamics</li>
	<li>Land surface processes</li>
	<li>Inundation</li>
</ul>

<p>In conjunction with trends in annual Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) data, the DLCD can be used to identify emerging patterns of land cover change and provide a spatial and historical context within which to interpret land cover change.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

<p>The DLCD includes data for every 250m by 250m area for the period 2000 to 2008. DLCD provides a base-line for identifying and reporting on change and trends in vegetation cover and extent.<br />
DLCD can be used as an input for modelling:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Groundwater recharge and discharge</li>
	<li>Climate</li>
	<li>Wind and water erosion risk</li>
	<li>Evapotranspiration</li>
	<li>Carbon dynamics</li>
	<li>Land surface processes</li>
	<li>Inundation</li>
</ul>

<ul>
	<li>Review by a panel of peers;</li>
	<li>Comparison with other remotely sensed datasets, including CSIRO Land and Waters Fraction of absorbed</li>
	<li>Photosynthetically Active Radiation (FPAR) data and the Queensland Statewide Landcover and Trees Study (SLATS) teams FPC data;</li>
	<li>Comparison with the 2007 Landsat 7 mosaic based on visual interpretation;</li>
	<li>Comparison with Google Earth based on visual interpretation.</li>
</ul>

<p>All the clusters which were identified as being wrongly labelled were visually assessed and compared to high resolution imagery. Five different types of mismatch were identified. After each of the five error types had been addressed, the dataset was further evaluated by comparing it with 25,817 field survey data points captured between 1999 and 2009.</p>

<p>The classification process identified 34 final International Standard Organisation land cover classes for Australia.</p>
