]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>In 2009 the National Committee for Land Use and Management Information identified the need for land cover information to facilitate change detection and improve natural resource management.</p>

<p>Existing land cover datasets are composites of State and Territory datasets which have been developed to meet specific legislative needs. This leads to thematic mismatches between different datasets and limits the capacity for meaningful change detection.</p>

<p>Nationally consistent and thematically comprehensive land cover information is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include sustainable farming practices, management of water resources, air quality, soil erosion and forests, as well as emergency management and urban planning.</p>

<p>The DLCD is based on an analysis of a 16-day EVI composite collected at 250 metre resolution using the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) satellite for the period 2000 to 2008.</p>

<p>The MODIS time series for each pixel was analysed using an innovative technique which reduced each time series into 12 coefficients based on the statistical, phenological and seasonal characteristics of each pixel. These coefficients were then clustered using a support vector clustering algorithm and the resultant classes were labelled using agreed National data supplied from catchment scale land use mapping and the National Vegetation Information System (NVIS).</p>

<p>The DLCD classification methodology and process along with major algorithms used are described in detail in the National Dynamic Land Cover Dataset - Technical Report (Lymburner et al, 2011).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>
	-%!28%!
	-</field_coverage_content_type><field_custodian>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_custodian><field_data_description><value><![CDATA[<p>DLCDv1_Class contains the final 34 DLC classes. The dataset includes a layer file and an attribute table for use in ArcGIS. The files are as follows:</p>

<p>DLCDv1_Class.tif : main DLC 34 class data file<br />
DLCDv1_Class.tif.vat.dbf : attribute table for 34 class data<br />
DLCDv1_Class.lyr : ArcGIS layer file for 34 class data<br />
DLCDv1_Class.tif.aux : ArcGIS auxiliary file</p>

<p>trend_evi_max shows the trend in the annual maximum of the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) from 2000 to 2008. The dataset includes a layer file and an attribute table for use in ArcGIS. The files are as follows:</p>

<p>trend_evi_max.tif : main evi max data file<br />
trend_evi_max.tif.lyr : ArcGIS layer file for max evi trend<br />
trend_evi_max.rrd : ArcGIS pyramid file<br />
trend_evi_max.aux : ArcGIS auxiliary file<br />
trend_evi_max.tif.xml : ArcGIS metadata file</p>

<p>trend_evi_mean shows the trend in the annual mean of the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) from 2000 to 2010. The dataset includes a layer file and an attribute table for use in ArcGIS. The files are as follows:</p>

<p>trend_evi_mean.tif : main evi mean data file<br />
trend_evi_mean.tif.lyr : ArcGIS layer file for mean evi trend<br />
trend_evi_mean.rrd : ArcGIS pyramid file<br />
trend_evi_mean.aux : ArcGIS auxiliary file<br />
trend_evi_mean.tif.xml : ArcGIS metadata file</p>

<p>trend_evi_min shows the trend in the annual minimum of the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) from 2000 to 2010. The dataset includes a layer file and an attribute table for use in ArcGIS. The files are as follows:</p>

<p>trend_evi_min.tif : main evi min data file<br />
trend_evi_min.tif.lyr : ArcGIS layer file for min evi trend<br />
trend_evi_min.rrd : ArcGIS pyramid file<br />
trend_evi_min.aux : ArcGIS auxiliary file<br />
trend_evi_min.tif.xml : ArcGIS metadata file</p>

<p>The DLCD Technical Report (Lymburner et. al., 2011) describes the DLCD, how the dataset was generated, presents a comparison of the DLCD with independent datasets and examples of how the DLCD classification can be used to analyse trends in the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) and other data sources. The files are as follows:</p>

<p>DLCD-Technical-Report.pdf</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_data_description><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-05-23T01:39:55</value><end_value>2017-05-23T01:39:55</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources>

	-%!25%!
	-</field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title><value>dynamic_landcover</value></field_developer_title><field_distribution_entity>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents><value>Lymburner, L., Tan, P., Mueller, N., Thackway, R., Lewis, A., Thankappan. M., Randall, L., Islam, A., and Senarath, U. (2011). The Dynamic Land Cover Datset. 95pp. GA Record 2011/31, ISBN 978-1-921954-30-6, Geoscience Australia, Canberra.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress><value>100</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset (DLCD) is the first nationally consistent and thematically comprehensive land cover reference for Australia. It provides a basis for reporting on change and trends in vegetation cover and extent. Information about land cover dynamics is essential to understanding and addressing a range of national challenges such as drought, salinity, water availability and ecosystem health.</p>

<p>DLCD presents a synopsis of land cover information for every 250m by 250m area of the country from April 2000 to April 2008. The classification scheme used to describe land cover categories in the Dataset conforms to the 2007 International Organization for Standardization (ISO) land cover standard (19144-2). The Dataset shows Australian land covers clustered into 34 ISO classes. These reflect the structural character of vegetation, ranging from cultivated and managed land covers (crops and pastures) to natural land covers such as closed forest and open grasslands.</p>

<p>The source data for the Dataset is a time series of EVI data from the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on the Terra and Aqua satellites operated by NASA. The time series includes 186 snapshots of vegetation greenness for each 250m by 250m area across the continent over an 8 year period. An example of the time series displayed by different land cover types is shown in Figure 1.</p>

<p>The EVI time series for each 250m by 250m area was characterised using 12 time series coefficients which describe the statistical, phenological and seasonal characteristics of the land cover. A clustering approach was applied to the 12 coefficients to define homogenous regions with similar greenness dynamics over time.</p>

<p>Regions that showed similar greenness characteristics over time were labelled using information derived from the 2009 Catchment Scale Land Use of Australia dataset and Native Vegetation Information System dataset provided by the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics and Sciences (ABARES).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
	-%!29%!

<p>The DLCD includes data for every 250m by 250m area for the period 2000 to 2008. DLCD provides a base-line for identifying and reporting on change and trends in vegetation cover and extent.<br />
DLCD can be used as an input for modelling:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Groundwater recharge and discharge</li>
	<li>Climate</li>
	<li>Wind and water erosion risk</li>
	<li>Evapotranspiration</li>

<ul>
	<li>Review by a panel of peers;</li>
	<li>Comparison with other remotely sensed datasets, including CSIRO Land and Waters Fraction of absorbed</li>
	<li>Photosynthetically Active Radiation (FPAR) data and the Queensland Statewide Landcover and Trees Study (SLATS) teams FPC data;</li>
	<li>Comparison with the 2007 Landsat 7 mosaic based on visual interpretation;</li>
	<li>Comparison with Google Earth based on visual interpretation.</li>
</ul>

<p>All the clusters which were identified as being wrongly labelled were visually assessed and compared to high resolution imagery. Five different types of mismatch were identified. After each of the five error types had been addressed, the dataset was further evaluated by comparing it with 25,817 field survey data points captured between 1999 and 2009.</p>

<p>The classification process identified 34 final International Standard Organisation land cover classes for Australia.</p>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>488583be-01c0-4c03-af8c-2c76184f5f1c</value></uuid><vid><value>386</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>ARG_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495003925</value></created><changed><value>1496113024</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496113024</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Reflectance Grid 25 v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>ARG25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat TM/ETM+ imagery over Australia for several decades and more recently Landsat OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery.<br />
To improve access to Australias archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012).<br />
The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ imagery to create the ARG25-V0.0 and ARG25-V0.1 products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes5 and processing complexities involved with production of this product. It is intended that the Landsat archives from 1987 will be incrementally incorporated into the ARG25 product and released as subsequent versions.<br />
Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:</p>

<ul>
	<li>surface reflectance;</li>
	<li>atmospheric condition;</li>
	<li>interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and</li>
	<li>land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.</li>
</ul>

<p>It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012).<br />
The ARG25 product delivers an estimate of surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artefacts of the imaging environment.<br />
Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time. This process is further simplified when the surface reflectance data conforms to a sensor agnostic nested grid, as envisaged for future versions of the ARG25 product.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in Australian land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The ARG25 collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background_and_recovery><field_catalogues><uri><![CDATA[http://eos.ga.gov.au/geonetwork/srv/eng/csw?service=CSW&request=GetCapabilities]]></uri><title>CSW</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>488583be-01c0-4c03-af8c-2c76184f5f1c</value></uuid><vid><value>386</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>ARG_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495003925</value></created><changed><value>1496113024</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496113024</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Reflectance Grid 25 v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>ARG25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />

Remote Sensing of Environment 118, 83&#x2013;94.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi><uri>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5487CC0D4F40B</uri><title>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5487CC0D4F40B</title><options/></field_doi><field_ecat_id><value>75062</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress><value>100</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The ARG product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets for Australia using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry.<br />
It is the intention of GA that this suite of products will be available within a more general framework of nested grids. The grid cell sizes of products comprising this suite will be scalable to facilitate easy data comparison between different products. This format will greatly simplify comparison of image datasets acquired by different sensors at varying spatial scales.<br />
The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are effectively consistent over space and time, and will be instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

Remote Sensing of Environment 118, 83&#x2013;94.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi><uri>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5487CC0D4F40B</uri><title>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5487CC0D4F40B</title><options/></field_doi><field_ecat_id><value>75062</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress><value>100</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The ARG product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets for Australia using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry.<br />
It is the intention of GA that this suite of products will be available within a more general framework of nested grids. The grid cell sizes of products comprising this suite will be scalable to facilitate easy data comparison between different products. This format will greatly simplify comparison of image datasets acquired by different sensors at varying spatial scales.<br />
The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are effectively consistent over space and time, and will be instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

attempting match on: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name><value>Australian Reflectance Grid 25 (ARG25)</value></field_nci_product_name><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>The ARG product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets for Australia.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
No match node contents append: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name><value>Australian Reflectance Grid 25 (ARG25)</value></field_nci_product_name><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>The ARG product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets for Australia.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!24%!
No match node contents append: %!24%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Australian Reflectance Grid (ARG) is a suite of new generation EO products from GA. These standard data products deliver optical surface reflectance data across the Australian landmass and its coastal fringes. The resulting datasets are effectively sensor agnostic and future versions of products in this suite are intended to be readily comparable between scales.<br />
The first product in this suite is the ARG25, a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on Landsat imagery. A low resolution grid based on MODIS data is under development.<br />
The ARG25 is the first ARG product to be released by GA. It is based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m grid cells.<br />
Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.<br />
The ARG25 product is created using a physics-based coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.<br />
This product can be viewed as a data cube, with time as the third dimension. The surface reflectance data for each imaged date and time are stacked in chronological order, with Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI sources being interleaved as appropriate to their acquisition time. Interrogation of this data cube allows the time series for individual grid cells, as well as their heritage and data quality, to be extracted and compared.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Australian Reflectance Grid (ARG) is a suite of new generation EO products from GA. These standard data products deliver optical surface reflectance data across the Australian landmass and its coastal fringes. The resulting datasets are effectively sensor agnostic and future versions of products in this suite are intended to be readily comparable between scales.<br />
The first product in this suite is the ARG25, a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on Landsat imagery. A low resolution grid based on MODIS data is under development.<br />
The ARG25 is the first ARG product to be released by GA. It is based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m grid cells.<br />
Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.<br />
The ARG25 product is created using a physics-based coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.<br />
This product can be viewed as a data cube, with time as the third dimension. The surface reflectance data for each imaged date and time are stacked in chronological order, with Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI sources being interleaved as appropriate to their acquisition time. Interrogation of this data cube allows the time series for individual grid cells, as well as their heritage and data quality, to be extracted and compared.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

No match node contents append: </field_processing_steps><field_product_life_span><value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</value><end_value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</end_value></field_product_life_span><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity>

attempting match on: </field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</value><end_value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</value><end_value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
attempting match on: %!26%!
No match node contents append: %!26%!
attempting match on: </field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</value><end_value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SAcorrelation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queenslandnormalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Fromecorrelation (measured as r2) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.930.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types. Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.800.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earths surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Spectral Contiguity</li>
	<li>Per band saturation assessment</li>
	<li>Cloud detection</li>
	<li>Cloud shadow estimation</li>
	<li>Offshore (sea)</li>
	<li>Onshore (land)</li>
</ul>

<p>The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which dont meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type/><field_rights_statement><value><![CDATA[<p><span></span> Commonwealth of Australia (Geoscience Australia) 2015. Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_rights_statement><field_schema/><field_security_classification>

Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. ]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earths surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. Adding node contents to map with id: 158
	-<nid><value>158</value></nid>
	-<uuid><value>488583be-01c0-4c03-af8c-2c76184f5f1c</value></uuid><vid><value>386</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>ARG_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495003925</value></created><changed><value>1496113024</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496113024</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Reflectance Grid 25 v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>ARG25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat TM/ETM+ imagery over Australia for several decades and more recently Landsat OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery.<br />
To improve access to Australias archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012).<br />
The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ imagery to create the ARG25-V0.0 and ARG25-V0.1 products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes5 and processing complexities involved with production of this product. It is intended that the Landsat archives from 1987 will be incrementally incorporated into the ARG25 product and released as subsequent versions.<br />
Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:</p>

<ul>
	<li>surface reflectance;</li>
	<li>atmospheric condition;</li>
	<li>interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and</li>
	<li>land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.</li>
</ul>

<p>It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012).<br />
The ARG25 product delivers an estimate of surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artefacts of the imaging environment.<br />
Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time. This process is further simplified when the surface reflectance data conforms to a sensor agnostic nested grid, as envisaged for future versions of the ARG25 product.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in Australian land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The ARG25 collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background_and_recovery><field_catalogues><uri><![CDATA[http://eos.ga.gov.au/geonetwork/srv/eng/csw?service=CSW&request=GetCapabilities]]></uri><title>CSW</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>

It is the intention of GA that this suite of products will be available within a more general framework of nested grids. The grid cell sizes of products comprising this suite will be scalable to facilitate easy data comparison between different products. This format will greatly simplify comparison of image datasets acquired by different sensors at varying spatial scales.<br />
The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are effectively consistent over space and time, and will be instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
	-%!29%!
	-</field_feedback_contact><field_files/><field_hprm_references><value>D2013-175180</value></field_hprm_references><field_images><target_id>2</target_id><alt>Sample ARG25 image</alt><title></title><width>1001</width><height>1201</height><target_type>file</target_type><target_uuid>a1aeab84-6c9c-44ec-8a4d-3e25ba760d47</target_uuid><url>http://cmi.ga.gov.au/sites/default/files/2017-05/ARG25_Figure_1.jpg</url></field_images><field_ingestion_contact>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_maintenance><field_maintenance_contact>

	-%!28%!
	-</field_media_contact><field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</value><end_value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</end_value></field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><field_metadata_contact>
	-%!27%!
	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name><value>Australian Reflectance Grid 25 (ARG25)</value></field_nci_product_name><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>The ARG product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets for Australia.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Australian Reflectance Grid (ARG) is a suite of new generation EO products from GA. These standard data products deliver optical surface reflectance data across the Australian landmass and its coastal fringes. The resulting datasets are effectively sensor agnostic and future versions of products in this suite are intended to be readily comparable between scales.<br />
The first product in this suite is the ARG25, a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on Landsat imagery. A low resolution grid based on MODIS data is under development.<br />
The ARG25 is the first ARG product to be released by GA. It is based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m grid cells.<br />
Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.<br />
The ARG25 product is created using a physics-based coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.<br />
This product can be viewed as a data cube, with time as the third dimension. The surface reflectance data for each imaged date and time are stacked in chronological order, with Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI sources being interleaved as appropriate to their acquisition time. Interrogation of this data cube allows the time series for individual grid cells, as well as their heritage and data quality, to be extracted and compared.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_owner><field_principal_contact>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_principal_contact><field_processing_steps>
	-%!112%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!107%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!108%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!109%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_product_life_span><value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</value><end_value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</end_value></field_product_life_span><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</value><end_value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
	-%!26%!
	-</field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</value><end_value>2017-05-17T06:52:05</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SAcorrelation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queenslandnormalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Fromecorrelation (measured as r2) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.930.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types. Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.800.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earths surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Spectral Contiguity</li>
	<li>Per band saturation assessment</li>
	<li>Cloud detection</li>
	<li>Cloud shadow estimation</li>
	<li>Offshore (sea)</li>
	<li>Onshore (land)</li>
</ul>

<p>The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which dont meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type/><field_rights_statement><value><![CDATA[<p><span></span> Commonwealth of Australia (Geoscience Australia) 2015. Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_rights_statement><field_schema/><field_security_classification>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>ab8c8509-a220-4eba-91ef-3e201d119dec</value></uuid><vid><value>392</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>AGRI_2.5_0.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493953520</value></created><changed><value>1496390396</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496390396</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>23</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>fdc6b4da-48e9-48ec-9cc0-84f34c92634c</target_uuid><url>/user/23</url></revision_uid><revision_log><value>Added references, revised wording in some places. Added material to uses.</value></revision_log><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Absolute geometric accuracy: 5.6m CEP90.</p>

<p>Cloudy over some areas.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Geographic Reference Image</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The AGRI provides a consistent base image which is providing a foundation for future mapping and monitoring across Australia.</p>

<p>The ARGI is a resource for both users and providers of satellite imagery covering Australia in government agencies, research institutions and academia, the spatial information industry, and international satellite operators.</p>

<p>Ground Control Points from the AGRI have fed into satellite image processing systems of the United States Geological Survey and of the European Space Agency. Consequently, imagery from the Landsat satellites and from the Copernicus Sentinel satellites are accurately and consistently geo-registered across Australia.</p>

<p>Similarly, commercial satellite operators are understood to have used the AGRI to improve their product quality.</p>

<p>Reference image  image to image rectification, image chip source, quality control layer<br />
Basemap  feature revision and verification, reference layer</p>

<p>Sectors:<br />
Government  Commonwealth, State and Local<br />
Research institutions<br />
Spatial Information Industry<br />
International satellite operators</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Australian Geographic Reference Image (AGRI) is a consistent and accurate reference image for rectification of imagery from multiple sources at resolutions of 2.5 metres or less. The AGRI is needed because the emerging new satellites and other sources of imagery will generate increasing amounts of data. The AGRI can ensure that images from these sources are consistently and accurately registered to allow the maximum extraction of information.</p>

<p>During compilation more than 9560 satellite scenes, totalling over 6 terabytes, were used to produce eight mosaics, covering each of Australia's Universal Transverse Mercator map zones. These mosaics were then combined to produce a single mosaic covering the Australian continent. Intensity and contrast balancing were used to ensure visual consistency across the mosaic while maintaining the dynamic range of the image.</p>

<p>The AGRI was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, international collaboration, the Australian spatial information industry, and the leadership and capabilities of Geoscience Australia. Japan's Advanced Land Observing Satellite (ALOS) made possible the complete coverage of high quality imagery, which forms the foundation of the AGRI, as well as accurate data on the satellite orbit. Geoscience Australia was an international collaborator on the ALOS; handling data for the Oceania region. The Barista software, developed by the Cooperative Research Centre for Spatial Information, made the project feasible in terms of time, logistics, and cost. Barista reduced the image registration problem from correction of almost 10 000 scenes to correction of just 105 orbit segments (Lewis et al, 2011).</p>

<p>The expertise and capability of the Australian spatial information industry was used in the design of GIS databases to manage the survey data and to conduct the many field surveys to remote areas of Australia. The expertise and capabilities of Geoscience Australia staff in both Earth observation and geodesy were also essential inputs to the project (Lewis et al, 2011).</p>

<p>The AGRI mosaic and associated datasets are available to the public under the Creative Commons-Attribution licensing terms at cost of transfer from Geoscience Australia.</p>

<p>References</p>

<p>M. Ravanbakhsh, L.-W. Wang, C.S.Fraser, *, A. Lewis (2012) Generation of the Australian geographic reference image through long-strip ALOS PRISM orientation.<br />
DOI: 10.5194/isprsarchives-XXXIX-B1-225-2012</p>

<p>Adam Lewis, Lan-Wei Wang, Rohan Coghlan (2011) AGRI: The Australian Geographic Reference Image. Geoscience Australia. GeoCat# 72657</p>

<p><a href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Franz_Rottensteiner"><span>Franz Rottensteiner</span></a>, <span>Thomas Weser</span>, <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Adam_Lewis8"><span>Adam Lewis</span></a><span>, Clive Fraser (2010). </span>A Strip Adjustment Approach for Precise Georeferencing of ALOS Optical Imagery. <span><!-- /react-text --><span>IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing 47(12):4083 - 4091</span></span><span><!-- react-text: 106 -->&#160;&#160;<!-- /react-text --><!-- react-text: 107 -->January 2010. </span><span>DOI: 10.1109/TGRS.2009.2014366</span><span><!-- react-text: 111 -->&#160;&#160;<!-- /react-text --><span><!-- react-text: 113 -->Source: <!-- /react-text --><a href="https://www.researchgate.net/deref/http%3A%2F%2Fieeexplore.ieee.org%2Fxpl%2Ffreeabs_all.jsp%3Farnumber%3D4838853">IEEE Xplore</a></span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The data set is replicated at GA.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

The AGRI can ensure that images are consistently and accurately registered to allow the maximum extraction of information. The AGRI provides a consistent base image intended, at the time of production,&#160;to provide an important foundation for future mapping and monitoring across Australia. This is proving to be the case. The AGRI is a resource for both users and providers of satellite imagery covering Australia in government agencies, research institutions and academia, the spatial information industry, and international satellite operators.</p>

	-<uuid><value>ab8c8509-a220-4eba-91ef-3e201d119dec</value></uuid><vid><value>392</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>AGRI_2.5_0.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493953520</value></created><changed><value>1496390396</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496390396</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>23</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>fdc6b4da-48e9-48ec-9cc0-84f34c92634c</target_uuid><url>/user/23</url></revision_uid><revision_log><value>Added references, revised wording in some places. Added material to uses.</value></revision_log><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Absolute geometric accuracy: 5.6m CEP90.</p>

<p>Cloudy over some areas.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Geographic Reference Image</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The AGRI provides a consistent base image which is providing a foundation for future mapping and monitoring across Australia.</p>

<p>The ARGI is a resource for both users and providers of satellite imagery covering Australia in government agencies, research institutions and academia, the spatial information industry, and international satellite operators.</p>

<p>Ground Control Points from the AGRI have fed into satellite image processing systems of the United States Geological Survey and of the European Space Agency. Consequently, imagery from the Landsat satellites and from the Copernicus Sentinel satellites are accurately and consistently geo-registered across Australia.</p>

<p>Similarly, commercial satellite operators are understood to have used the AGRI to improve their product quality.</p>

<p>Reference image  image to image rectification, image chip source, quality control layer<br />
Basemap  feature revision and verification, reference layer</p>

<p>Sectors:<br />
Government  Commonwealth, State and Local<br />
Research institutions<br />
Spatial Information Industry<br />
International satellite operators</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Australian Geographic Reference Image (AGRI) is a consistent and accurate reference image for rectification of imagery from multiple sources at resolutions of 2.5 metres or less. The AGRI is needed because the emerging new satellites and other sources of imagery will generate increasing amounts of data. The AGRI can ensure that images from these sources are consistently and accurately registered to allow the maximum extraction of information.</p>

<p>During compilation more than 9560 satellite scenes, totalling over 6 terabytes, were used to produce eight mosaics, covering each of Australia's Universal Transverse Mercator map zones. These mosaics were then combined to produce a single mosaic covering the Australian continent. Intensity and contrast balancing were used to ensure visual consistency across the mosaic while maintaining the dynamic range of the image.</p>

<p>The AGRI was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, international collaboration, the Australian spatial information industry, and the leadership and capabilities of Geoscience Australia. Japan's Advanced Land Observing Satellite (ALOS) made possible the complete coverage of high quality imagery, which forms the foundation of the AGRI, as well as accurate data on the satellite orbit. Geoscience Australia was an international collaborator on the ALOS; handling data for the Oceania region. The Barista software, developed by the Cooperative Research Centre for Spatial Information, made the project feasible in terms of time, logistics, and cost. Barista reduced the image registration problem from correction of almost 10 000 scenes to correction of just 105 orbit segments (Lewis et al, 2011).</p>

<p>The expertise and capability of the Australian spatial information industry was used in the design of GIS databases to manage the survey data and to conduct the many field surveys to remote areas of Australia. The expertise and capabilities of Geoscience Australia staff in both Earth observation and geodesy were also essential inputs to the project (Lewis et al, 2011).</p>

<p>The AGRI mosaic and associated datasets are available to the public under the Creative Commons-Attribution licensing terms at cost of transfer from Geoscience Australia.</p>

<p>References</p>

<p>M. Ravanbakhsh, L.-W. Wang, C.S.Fraser, *, A. Lewis (2012) Generation of the Australian geographic reference image through long-strip ALOS PRISM orientation.<br />
DOI: 10.5194/isprsarchives-XXXIX-B1-225-2012</p>

<p>Adam Lewis, Lan-Wei Wang, Rohan Coghlan (2011) AGRI: The Australian Geographic Reference Image. Geoscience Australia. GeoCat# 72657</p>

<p><a href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Franz_Rottensteiner"><span>Franz Rottensteiner</span></a>, <span>Thomas Weser</span>, <a href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Adam_Lewis8"><span>Adam Lewis</span></a><span>, Clive Fraser (2010). </span>A Strip Adjustment Approach for Precise Georeferencing of ALOS Optical Imagery. <span><!-- /react-text --><span>IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing 47(12):4083 - 4091</span></span><span><!-- react-text: 106 -->&#160;&#160;<!-- /react-text --><!-- react-text: 107 -->January 2010. </span><span>DOI: 10.1109/TGRS.2009.2014366</span><span><!-- react-text: 111 -->&#160;&#160;<!-- /react-text --><span><!-- react-text: 113 -->Source: <!-- /react-text --><a href="https://www.researchgate.net/deref/http%3A%2F%2Fieeexplore.ieee.org%2Fxpl%2Ffreeabs_all.jsp%3Farnumber%3D4838853">IEEE Xplore</a></span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The data set is replicated at GA.</p>

The AGRI can ensure that images are consistently and accurately registered to allow the maximum extraction of information. The AGRI provides a consistent base image intended, at the time of production,&#160;to provide an important foundation for future mapping and monitoring across Australia. This is proving to be the case. Hence, terminology has been adopted for the product to reflect the highest modelled tide observed in a given cell (HOT) and the lowest modelled tide observed (LOT) (Figure 2). These measures are relative to Mean Sea Level, and have no consistent relationship to Lowest (LAT) and Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Intertidal Extents Model 25m v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The purpose of the ITEM v1.0 product is to assist in understanding the extent and elevation profile of the Australian intertidal zone. Examples of where this knowledge can contribute include environmental monitoring applications for migratory bird species, habitat mapping in coastal regions, hydrodynamic modelling, and geomorphology studies of features in the intertidal zone.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors><value>Stephen Sagar</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_authors><value>Biswajit Bala</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) product analyses GAs historic archive of satellite imagery to derive a model of the spatial extents of the intertidal zone throughout the tidal cycle. The model can assist in understanding the relative elevation profile of the intertidal zone, delineating exposed areas at differing tidal heights and stages.</p>

<p>The product differs from previous methods used to map the intertidal zone which have been predominately focused on analysing a small number of individual satellite images per location (e.g Ryu et al., 2002; Murray et al., 2012). By utilising a full 28 year time series of observations, the methodology enables us to overcome the requirement for clear, high quality observations acquired concurrent to the time of high and low tide.</p>

Hence, terminology has been adopted for the product to reflect the highest modelled tide observed in a given cell (HOT) and the lowest modelled tide observed (LOT) (Figure 2). These measures are relative to Mean Sea Level, and have no consistent relationship to Lowest (LAT) and Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Intertidal Extents Model 25m v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The purpose of the ITEM v1.0 product is to assist in understanding the extent and elevation profile of the Australian intertidal zone. Examples of where this knowledge can contribute include environmental monitoring applications for migratory bird species, habitat mapping in coastal regions, hydrodynamic modelling, and geomorphology studies of features in the intertidal zone.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors><value>Stephen Sagar</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_authors><value>Biswajit Bala</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) product analyses GAs historic archive of satellite imagery to derive a model of the spatial extents of the intertidal zone throughout the tidal cycle. The model can assist in understanding the relative elevation profile of the intertidal zone, delineating exposed areas at differing tidal heights and stages.</p>

<p>The product differs from previous methods used to map the intertidal zone which have been predominately focused on analysing a small number of individual satellite images per location (e.g Ryu et al., 2002; Murray et al., 2012). By utilising a full 28 year time series of observations, the methodology enables us to overcome the requirement for clear, high quality observations acquired concurrent to the time of high and low tide.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fk4/ITEM/catalog.html</uri><title>THREDDS</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>

J. Remote Sens. 17, 1425&#x2013;1432. doi:10.1080/01431169608948714</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Murray, N.J., Phinn, S.R., Clemens, R.S., Roelfsema, C.M., Fuller, R.A., 2012. Remote Sens. 4, 3417&#x2013;3426. doi:10.3390/rs4113417</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Ryu, J.-H., Won, J.-S., Min, K.D., 2002. Environ. 83, 442&#x2013;456. doi:10.1016/S0034-4257(02)00059-7</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Sagar, S., Roberts, D., Bala, B., Lymburner, L., 2017. Extracting the intertidal extent and topography of the Australian coastline from a 28 year time series of Landsat observations. Remote Sensing of Environment 195, 153&#x2013;169. doi:10.1016/j.rse.2017.04.009</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F64E5BA264</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F64E5BA264</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F47F34675D</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5760F5452D371</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/5760F5452D371</title><options/></field_doi><field_ecat_id><value>100600</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) consists of three datasets derived from the Landsat NBAR data managed in the Australian Geoscience Data Cube (AGDC) for the period 1987 to 2015.</p>

<p>The <strong>Coastal Cells shapefile (ITEM_CoastalCells.shp)</strong> identifies the location and extents of the 221 one degree by one degree AGDC cells used in the product, covering the mainland and Tasmanian coastline of the continent (Figure 1). The shapefile also includes information on the lowest (LOT) and highest (HOT) observed tides for the cell, and hence the observed tidal range (HOT-LOT), based on tidal modelling for the time of acquisition of each of the corresponding Landsat tile observations in the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes: </em></strong></p>

<p>AGDC Cell Identifier</p>

<p>Lowest Observed Tide (LOT)  The lowest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>Highest Observed Tide (HOT)  The highest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>The <strong>Relative Extents Model (ITEM_REL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> utilises the tidal information attributed to each tile observation to indicate the spatial extent of intertidal substratum exposed at percentile intervals of the observed tidal range for the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster: </em></strong></p>

<p>0  Always water<br />
1  Exposed at lowest 0-10% of the observed tidal range<br />
2  Exposed at 10-20% of the observed tidal range<br />
3  Exposed at 20-30% of the observed tidal range<br />
4  Exposed at 30-40% of the observed tidal range<br />
5  Exposed at 40-50% of the observed tidal range<br />
6  Exposed at 50-60% of the observed tidal range<br />
7  Exposed at 60-70% of the observed tidal range<br />
8  Exposed at 70-80% of the observed tidal range<br />
9 - Exposed at highest 80-100% of the observed tidal range (land)<br />
-999  No Data</p>

<p>The <strong>Confidence Layer (ITEM_CL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> reflects the confidence level of the Relative Extents Model, based on the distribution of classification metrics within each of the percentile intervals of the tidal range. The layer should be used to filter region/pixels in the model where the derived spatial extents may be adversely affected by data and modelling errors.</p>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster:</em></strong></p>

<p>0  Model is invalid. Indicates pixels where data quality and/or number of observations have resulted in no available observations in one or more of the percentile interval subsets.</p>

<p>-32767  No Data</p>

<p>All other values  The pixel-based average of the NDWI standard deviations calculated independently for each percentile interval of the observed tidal range (x 1000).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

Remote Sensing of Environment 195, 153&#x2013;169. doi:10.1016/j.rse.2017.04.009</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F64E5BA264</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F64E5BA264</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F47F34675D</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5760F5452D371</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/5760F5452D371</title><options/></field_doi><field_ecat_id><value>100600</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) consists of three datasets derived from the Landsat NBAR data managed in the Australian Geoscience Data Cube (AGDC) for the period 1987 to 2015.</p>

<p>The <strong>Coastal Cells shapefile (ITEM_CoastalCells.shp)</strong> identifies the location and extents of the 221 one degree by one degree AGDC cells used in the product, covering the mainland and Tasmanian coastline of the continent (Figure 1). The shapefile also includes information on the lowest (LOT) and highest (HOT) observed tides for the cell, and hence the observed tidal range (HOT-LOT), based on tidal modelling for the time of acquisition of each of the corresponding Landsat tile observations in the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes: </em></strong></p>

<p>AGDC Cell Identifier</p>

<p>Lowest Observed Tide (LOT)  The lowest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>Highest Observed Tide (HOT)  The highest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>The <strong>Relative Extents Model (ITEM_REL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> utilises the tidal information attributed to each tile observation to indicate the spatial extent of intertidal substratum exposed at percentile intervals of the observed tidal range for the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster: </em></strong></p>

<p>0  Always water<br />
1  Exposed at lowest 0-10% of the observed tidal range<br />
2  Exposed at 10-20% of the observed tidal range<br />
3  Exposed at 20-30% of the observed tidal range<br />
4  Exposed at 30-40% of the observed tidal range<br />
5  Exposed at 40-50% of the observed tidal range<br />
6  Exposed at 50-60% of the observed tidal range<br />
7  Exposed at 60-70% of the observed tidal range<br />
8  Exposed at 70-80% of the observed tidal range<br />
9 - Exposed at highest 80-100% of the observed tidal range (land)<br />
-999  No Data</p>

<p>The <strong>Confidence Layer (ITEM_CL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> reflects the confidence level of the Relative Extents Model, based on the distribution of classification metrics within each of the percentile intervals of the tidal range. The layer should be used to filter region/pixels in the model where the derived spatial extents may be adversely affected by data and modelling errors.</p>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster:</em></strong></p>

<p>0  Model is invalid. Indicates pixels where data quality and/or number of observations have resulted in no available observations in one or more of the percentile interval subsets.</p>

<p>-32767  No Data</p>

<p>All other values  The pixel-based average of the NDWI standard deviations calculated independently for each percentile interval of the observed tidal range (x 1000).</p>

No match node contents append: %!162%!
attempting match on: </field_processing_steps><field_product_life_span/><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity/><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</value><end_value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact/><field_qa_time_frame/><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>The Confidence layer is designed to assess the reliability of the Relative Extent Model. Within each tidal range percentile interval, the pixel-based standard deviation of the NDWI values for all tiles in the interval subset is calculated. The average standard deviation across all tidal range intervals is then calculated and retained as a quality indicator in this product layer.</p>

<p>The Confidence Layer reflects the pixel based consistency of the NDWI values within each subset of observations, based on the tidal range. Higher standard deviation values indicate water classification changes not based on the tidal cycle, and hence lower confidence in the extent model. Possible drivers of these changes include:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Inadequacies of the tidal model, due perhaps to complex coastal bathymetry or estuarine structures not captured in the model.</li>
	<li>Change in the structure and exposure of water/non-water features NOT driven by tidal variation. For example, movement of sand banks in estuaries, construction of man-made features (ports etc.).</li>
	<li>Terrestrial/Inland water features not influenced by the tidal cycle.</li>
</ol>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>
No match node contents append: </field_processing_steps><field_product_life_span/><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity/><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</value><end_value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact/><field_qa_time_frame/><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>The Confidence layer is designed to assess the reliability of the Relative Extent Model. Within each tidal range percentile interval, the pixel-based standard deviation of the NDWI values for all tiles in the interval subset is calculated. The average standard deviation across all tidal range intervals is then calculated and retained as a quality indicator in this product layer.</p>

<p>The Confidence Layer reflects the pixel based consistency of the NDWI values within each subset of observations, based on the tidal range. Higher standard deviation values indicate water classification changes not based on the tidal cycle, and hence lower confidence in the extent model. Possible drivers of these changes include:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Inadequacies of the tidal model, due perhaps to complex coastal bathymetry or estuarine structures not captured in the model.</li>
	<li>Change in the structure and exposure of water/non-water features NOT driven by tidal variation. For example, movement of sand banks in estuaries, construction of man-made features (ports etc.).</li>
	<li>Terrestrial/Inland water features not influenced by the tidal cycle.</li>
</ol>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>
