ITEM provides the extent and topography of the intertidal zone of Australia's coastline (excluding off-shore Territories). This information was collated using observations in the Landsat archive since 1987. ITEM can be a valuable complimentary dataset to both onshore LiDAR survey data and coarser offshore bathymetry data, enabling a more realistic representation of the land and ocean interface.</p>

ITEM provides the extent and topography of the intertidal zone of Australia's coastline (excluding off-shore Territories). This information was collated using observations in the Landsat archive since 1987. ITEM can be a valuable complimentary dataset to both onshore LiDAR survey data and coarser offshore bathymetry data, enabling a more realistic representation of the land and ocean interface.</p>

Adding node contents to map with id: 121
	-<nid><value>121</value></nid>
	-<uuid><value>a965e582-aac4-46e7-98a5-c7ea4736e88e</value></uuid><vid><value>395</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>ITEM_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493967314</value></created><changed><value>1496716080</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496716080</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Due the sun-synchronous nature of the various Landsat sensor observations; it is unlikely that the full physical extents of the tidal range in any cell will be observed. Hence, terminology has been adopted for the product to reflect the highest modelled tide observed in a given cell (HOT) and the lowest modelled tide observed (LOT) (Figure 2). These measures are relative to Mean Sea Level, and have no consistent relationship to Lowest (LAT) and Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Intertidal Extents Model 25m v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The purpose of the ITEM v1.0 product is to assist in understanding the extent and elevation profile of the Australian intertidal zone. Examples of where this knowledge can contribute include environmental monitoring applications for migratory bird species, habitat mapping in coastal regions, hydrodynamic modelling, and geomorphology studies of features in the intertidal zone.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors><value>Stephen Sagar</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_authors><value>Biswajit Bala</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) product analyses GAs historic archive of satellite imagery to derive a model of the spatial extents of the intertidal zone throughout the tidal cycle. The model can assist in understanding the relative elevation profile of the intertidal zone, delineating exposed areas at differing tidal heights and stages.</p>

<p>The product differs from previous methods used to map the intertidal zone which have been predominately focused on analysing a small number of individual satellite images per location (e.g Ryu et al., 2002; Murray et al., 2012). By utilising a full 28 year time series of observations, the methodology enables us to overcome the requirement for clear, high quality observations acquired concurrent to the time of high and low tide.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fk4/ITEM/catalog.html</uri><title>THREDDS</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_custodian><field_data_description/><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</value><end_value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources>
	-%!158%!
	-</field_data_sources><field_data_sources>
	-%!118%!
	-</field_data_sources><field_data_source_contact>
	-%!25%!
	-</field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer><uri>https://d28rz98at9flks.cloudfront.net/100464/100464_Quality.zip</uri><title>Intertidal Extents Model Confidence Layer </title><options/></field_data_transfer><field_data_transfer><uri>https://d28rz98at9flks.cloudfront.net/100481/100481_Shapefile.zip</uri><title>Intertidal Extents Model Coastal Cells shapefile</title><options/></field_data_transfer><field_data_transfer><uri>https://d28rz98at9flks.cloudfront.net/100482/100482_RelativeExtentsLayer.zip</uri><title>Intertidal Extents Model Relative Extents Model </title><options/></field_data_transfer><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents><value>McFeeters, S.K., 1996. The use of the Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI) in the delineation of open water features. Int. J. Remote Sens. 17, 1425&#x2013;1432. doi:10.1080/01431169608948714</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Murray, N.J., Phinn, S.R., Clemens, R.S., Roelfsema, C.M., Fuller, R.A., 2012. Continental Scale Mapping of Tidal Flats across East Asia Using the Landsat Archive. Remote Sens. 4, 3417&#x2013;3426. doi:10.3390/rs4113417</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Ryu, J.-H., Won, J.-S., Min, K.D., 2002. Waterline extraction from Landsat TM data in a tidal flat: A case study in Gomso Bay, Korea. Remote Sens. Environ. 83, 442&#x2013;456. doi:10.1016/S0034-4257(02)00059-7</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_documents><value>Sagar, S., Roberts, D., Bala, B., Lymburner, L., 2017. Extracting the intertidal extent and topography of the Australian coastline from a 28 year time series of Landsat observations. Remote Sensing of Environment 195, 153&#x2013;169. doi:10.1016/j.rse.2017.04.009</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F64E5BA264</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F64E5BA264</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>https://doi.org/10.4225/25/575F683E2A3AF</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/575F47F34675D</title><options/></field_doi><field_doi><uri>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5760F5452D371</uri><title>doi:10.4225/25/5760F5452D371</title><options/></field_doi><field_ecat_id><value>100600</value></field_ecat_id><field_estimated_progress/><field_expected_completion_date/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) consists of three datasets derived from the Landsat NBAR data managed in the Australian Geoscience Data Cube (AGDC) for the period 1987 to 2015.</p>

<p>The <strong>Coastal Cells shapefile (ITEM_CoastalCells.shp)</strong> identifies the location and extents of the 221 one degree by one degree AGDC cells used in the product, covering the mainland and Tasmanian coastline of the continent (Figure 1). The shapefile also includes information on the lowest (LOT) and highest (HOT) observed tides for the cell, and hence the observed tidal range (HOT-LOT), based on tidal modelling for the time of acquisition of each of the corresponding Landsat tile observations in the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes: </em></strong></p>

<p>AGDC Cell Identifier</p>

<p>Lowest Observed Tide (LOT)  The lowest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>Highest Observed Tide (HOT)  The highest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>The <strong>Relative Extents Model (ITEM_REL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> utilises the tidal information attributed to each tile observation to indicate the spatial extent of intertidal substratum exposed at percentile intervals of the observed tidal range for the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster: </em></strong></p>

<p>0  Always water<br />
1  Exposed at lowest 0-10% of the observed tidal range<br />
2  Exposed at 10-20% of the observed tidal range<br />
3  Exposed at 20-30% of the observed tidal range<br />
4  Exposed at 30-40% of the observed tidal range<br />
5  Exposed at 40-50% of the observed tidal range<br />
6  Exposed at 50-60% of the observed tidal range<br />
7  Exposed at 60-70% of the observed tidal range<br />
8  Exposed at 70-80% of the observed tidal range<br />
9 - Exposed at highest 80-100% of the observed tidal range (land)<br />
-999  No Data</p>

<p>The <strong>Confidence Layer (ITEM_CL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> reflects the confidence level of the Relative Extents Model, based on the distribution of classification metrics within each of the percentile intervals of the tidal range. The layer should be used to filter region/pixels in the model where the derived spatial extents may be adversely affected by data and modelling errors.</p>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster:</em></strong></p>

<p>0  Model is invalid. Indicates pixels where data quality and/or number of observations have resulted in no available observations in one or more of the percentile interval subsets.</p>

<p>-32767  No Data</p>

<p>All other values  The pixel-based average of the NDWI standard deviations calculated independently for each percentile interval of the observed tidal range (x 1000).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
	-%!29%!
	-</field_feedback_contact><field_files/><field_hprm_references><value>D2016 &#x2010; 70233</value></field_hprm_references><field_images><target_id>3</target_id><alt>Figure 1 &#x2013; Location and extents of the 221 AGDC coastal cells used in the Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0).</alt><title></title><width>1122</width><height>794</height><target_type>file</target_type><target_uuid>ef72f90b-2fe2-4fd0-8f48-ab7f9fc869a3</target_uuid><url>http://cmi.ga.gov.au/sites/default/files/2017-05/ITEM_Figure_1.png</url></field_images><field_images><target_id>4</target_id><alt>Figure 2 &#x2013; The concept of Lowest (LOT) and Highest (HOT) Observed Tide. Modelled tidal offsets for Landsat observations shown in relation to the full tidal model. Note how the observed tidal range (HOT-LOT) differs from the full tidal range.</alt><title></title><width>1194</width><height>457</height><target_type>file</target_type><target_uuid>a3207c75-dd88-4417-88a5-8f62fd8477b9</target_uuid><url>http://cmi.ga.gov.au/sites/default/files/2017-05/ITEM_Figure_2.png</url></field_images><field_ingestion_contact>

	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM) product is a national dataset of the exposed intertidal zone; the land between the observed highest and lowest tide.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) product is a national scale gridded dataset characterising the spatial extents of the exposed intertidal zone, at intervals of the observed tidal range. The current version utilises all Landsat observations (5, 7, and 8) for Australian coastal regions (excluding off-shore Territories) between 1987 and 2015 (inclusive).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>
	-%!113%!
	-</field_owner><field_principal_contact>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_principal_contact><field_processing_steps>
	-%!125%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!126%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!127%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!159%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!160%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!161%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_processing_steps>
	-%!162%!
	-</field_processing_steps><field_product_life_span/><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity/><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</value><end_value>2017-05-05T06:55:14</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact/><field_qa_time_frame/><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>The Confidence layer is designed to assess the reliability of the Relative Extent Model. Within each tidal range percentile interval, the pixel-based standard deviation of the NDWI values for all tiles in the interval subset is calculated. The average standard deviation across all tidal range intervals is then calculated and retained as a quality indicator in this product layer.</p>

<p>The Confidence Layer reflects the pixel based consistency of the NDWI values within each subset of observations, based on the tidal range. Higher standard deviation values indicate water classification changes not based on the tidal cycle, and hence lower confidence in the extent model. Possible drivers of these changes include:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Inadequacies of the tidal model, due perhaps to complex coastal bathymetry or estuarine structures not captured in the model.</li>
	<li>Change in the structure and exposure of water/non-water features NOT driven by tidal variation. For example, movement of sand banks in estuaries, construction of man-made features (ports etc.).</li>
	<li>Terrestrial/Inland water features not influenced by the tidal cycle.</li>
</ol>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>

	-</field_schema><field_security_classification>
	-%!12552%!
	-</field_security_classification><field_services><uri><![CDATA[http://geoserver.nci.org.au/geoserver/ITEM/wms?request=GetCapabilities&service=WMS]]></uri><title>WMS</title><options/></field_services><field_services><uri><![CDATA[http://geoserver.nci.org.au/geoserver/ITEM/wcs?request=GetCapabilities&service=WCS]]></uri><title>WCS</title><options/></field_services><field_simple_title><value>Intertidal Extents Model</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_subject_matter_experts/><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM) product is a national dataset of the exposed intertidal zone; the land between the observed highest and lowest tide. ITEM provides the extent and topography of the intertidal zone of Australia's coastline (excluding off-shore Territories). This information was collated using observations in the Landsat archive since 1987. ITEM can be a valuable complimentary dataset to both onshore LiDAR survey data and coarser offshore bathymetry data, enabling a more realistic representation of the land and ocean interface.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_update_frequency/><field_use_constraints/><field_version_number><value>1.0.0</value></field_version_number><field_websites><uri>http://eos.ga.gov.au</uri><title>http://eos.ga.gov.au</title><options/></field_websites>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">The field site data has been collected for a variety of purposes and is accurate to varying spatial and temporal resolutions; typically the primary field site data are no longer available. A process of translation between the field data collected and the dynamic land cover data was undertaken using expert knowledge.</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">Due to the unknown spatial, temporal and thematic accuracy of the field site data the assessment with the dynamic land cover dataset has been reported only for broad themes across all years.&#160;</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

			</td>
			<td style="border-width: 0px 1pt 1pt 0px; border-style: none solid solid none; border-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) windowtext windowtext rgb(0, 0, 0); width: 98.55pt;" width="131">
			<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt; padding: 0cm 5.4pt;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">5.22%</font></font></span></p>
			</td>
			<td style="border-width: 0px 1pt 1pt 0px; border-style: none solid solid none; border-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) windowtext windowtext rgb(0, 0, 0); width: 98.55pt;" width="131">
			<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt; padding: 0cm 5.4pt;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">4.69%</font></font></span></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="border-width: 0px 1pt 1pt; border-style: none solid solid; border-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) windowtext windowtext; width: 98.55pt;" width="131">
			<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt; padding: 0cm 5.4pt;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">Trees</font></font></span></p>
			</td>
			<td style="border-width: 0px 1pt 1pt 0px; border-style: none solid solid none; border-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) windowtext windowtext rgb(0, 0, 0); width: 98.55pt;" width="131">
			<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt; padding: 0cm 5.4pt;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">62.55%</font></font></span></p>
			</td>
			<td style="border-width: 0px 1pt 1pt 0px; border-style: none solid solid none; border-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) windowtext windowtext rgb(0, 0, 0); width: 98.55pt;" width="131">
			<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt; padding: 0cm 5.4pt;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">72.34%</font></font></span></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">The overall accuracy of DLCD assessed using the grouped themes is 81.5%.</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">The field data comparison demonstrates that for cover classes that are poorly represented by a greenness measure, the associated accuracy of the DLCD is very poor. However for cover classes with significant greenness, the grouped accuracy of DLCD is reasonably high. <font size="3">In addition, more dynamic classes such grasses and shrubs show a lower accuracy when assessing a single date field data point against the&#160;general class over a two year period.</font></font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">The complete error matrix, assessing the full 22 class DLCD against field data is available in an <a href="/sites/default/files/2017-06/DLCD%202.1%20Confusion%20Matrix.xlsx">attachment</a>. The full matrix highlights the disparity of the 250 m DLCD versus the field data, and shows those classes that are not characterisable using the EVI greeness measurements. The overall accuracy using the finer class structure is 31.1%.</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">Despite the large number of points in the comparison this comprises less than 0.01% of the land cover classification data. Users are encouraged to assess whether the dataset is fit for their purposes in their area of interest, and provide any feedback to earth.observation@ga.gov.au.</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">Additionally, the 250 metre pixel scale of the data will limit the use of this data set in studies that depend on the identification of small or detailed features within the landscape i.e. narrow strips of riparian vegetation or managed landscapes where the fields/paddocks are smaller than 250 x 250 metres. </font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font face="Calibri"><font color="#000000">The two year time frame for each map in the map series will limit the capacity to detect short lived changes in land cover such as low-intensity bushfires i.e. the canopy may recover within a two year period. </font><font color="#000000">The map series will only provide&#160;limited information for land covers that are difficult to discriminate using EVI such as sugar cane.</font></font></span></span></p>
]]></value><format>full_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Dynamic Land Cover Dataset 250 2.1.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>The primary purpose of the DLCDv2.1 product is to provide the Australian government with a standardised land cover dataset for understanding of&#160;and reporting on land cover change, including to better understand how managed landscapes have responded to droughts, floods and shifts in water allocations. An example application is use within the Australian Bureau of Statistics' Land Accounts.</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The product has many secondary uses. For example climate and weather modellers will be able use DLCDv2 to input land cover parameters into climate and weather models. Ecologists, decision makers and carbon modellers will be able to use DLCDv2 to assess how vegetation responds to disturbance including severe fires, floods, cyclones and land clearing activities. The DLCDv2 can also be used as a contextual layer for products such as the Atlas of Living Australia.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors><value>McIntyre, Alexis</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_authors><value>Tan, Peter</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_authors><value>Lymburner, Leo</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCDv2 is the second DLCD product released by GA. It is based on the MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) product MOD13Q1. For more information on MOD13Q1 see: <a href="https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1">https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1</a></p>

<p>The first version of the DLCD product suite (DLCDv1) was published in 2011 and was a single map based on 250 metre resolution MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) data acquired between April 2000 and April 2008. The DLCDv1 is described in detail at <a href="http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html">http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

The data was provided by Federal, State and Territory Government agencies and collected over the period 2001 to 2012 including data contributed from these sources:</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">The field site data has been collected for a variety of purposes and is accurate to varying spatial and temporal resolutions; typically the primary field site data are no longer available. A process of translation between the field data collected and the dynamic land cover data was undertaken using expert knowledge.</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">Due to the unknown spatial, temporal and thematic accuracy of the field site data the assessment with the dynamic land cover dataset has been reported only for broad themes across all years.&#160;</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">The overall accuracy of DLCD assessed using the grouped themes is 81.5%.</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">The field data comparison demonstrates that for cover classes that are poorly represented by a greenness measure, the associated accuracy of the DLCD is very poor. However for cover classes with significant greenness, the grouped accuracy of DLCD is reasonably high. <font size="3">In addition, more dynamic classes such grasses and shrubs show a lower accuracy when assessing a single date field data point against the&#160;general class over a two year period.</font></font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">The complete error matrix, assessing the full 22 class DLCD against field data is available in an <a href="/sites/default/files/2017-06/DLCD%202.1%20Confusion%20Matrix.xlsx">attachment</a>. The full matrix highlights the disparity of the 250 m DLCD versus the field data, and shows those classes that are not characterisable using the EVI greeness measurements. The overall accuracy using the finer class structure is 31.1%.</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">Despite the large number of points in the comparison this comprises less than 0.01% of the land cover classification data. Users are encouraged to assess whether the dataset is fit for their purposes in their area of interest, and provide any feedback to earth.observation@ga.gov.au.</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">Additionally, the 250 metre pixel scale of the data will limit the use of this data set in studies that depend on the identification of small or detailed features within the landscape i.e. narrow strips of riparian vegetation or managed landscapes where the fields/paddocks are smaller than 250 x 250 metres. </font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font face="Calibri"><font color="#000000">The two year time frame for each map in the map series will limit the capacity to detect short lived changes in land cover such as low-intensity bushfires i.e. the canopy may recover within a two year period. </font><font color="#000000">The map series will only provide&#160;limited information for land covers that are difficult to discriminate using EVI such as sugar cane.</font></font></span></span></p>
]]></value><format>full_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Dynamic Land Cover Dataset 250 2.1.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>The primary purpose of the DLCDv2.1 product is to provide the Australian government with a standardised land cover dataset for understanding of&#160;and reporting on land cover change, including to better understand how managed landscapes have responded to droughts, floods and shifts in water allocations. An example application is use within the Australian Bureau of Statistics' Land Accounts.</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The product has many secondary uses. For example climate and weather modellers will be able use DLCDv2 to input land cover parameters into climate and weather models. Ecologists, decision makers and carbon modellers will be able to use DLCDv2 to assess how vegetation responds to disturbance including severe fires, floods, cyclones and land clearing activities. The DLCDv2 can also be used as a contextual layer for products such as the Atlas of Living Australia.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors><value>McIntyre, Alexis</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_authors><value>Tan, Peter</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_authors><value>Lymburner, Leo</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCDv2 is the second DLCD product released by GA. It is based on the MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) product MOD13Q1. For more information on MOD13Q1 see: <a href="https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1">https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1</a></p>

<p>The first version of the DLCD product suite (DLCDv1) was published in 2011 and was a single map based on 250 metre resolution MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) data acquired between April 2000 and April 2008. The DLCDv1 is described in detail at <a href="http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html">http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

attempting match on: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title><value>dynamic_landcover</value></field_developer_title><field_distribution_entity>
No match node contents append: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title><value>dynamic_landcover</value></field_developer_title><field_distribution_entity>
attempting match on: %!113%!
No match node contents append: %!113%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents><value>Lymburner, L., Tan, P., Mueller, N., Thackway, R., Lewis, A., Thankappan. M., Randall, L., Islam, A., and Senarath, U. (2011). The Dynamic Land Cover Datset. 95pp. GA Record 2011/31, ISBN 978-1-921954-30-6, Geoscience Australia, Canberra.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress><value>90</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-06-30</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><font face="Calibri"><font size="3"><font color="#000000">The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset (DLCD) is a nationally consistent and thematically comprehensive land cover reference for Australia. In producing the DLDC, time series analysis techniques are used to classify each pixel based on the way it has behaved over a two year period. </font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3">Each map can be considered in isolation, or two maps from different intervals can be compared to identify the changes in land cover that have occurred over that time frame.</font></font></font></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><font face="Calibri"><font size="3"><font color="#000000">Each map has been generated by applying a </font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3">sophisticated time series analysis technique known as Dynamic Markov Chain modelling to two years of MODIS EVI data.</font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3"> </font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3">The outputs of the time series analysis are filtered using a class change constraint matrix, a terrain mask and MODIS</font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3"> </font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3">green albedo products. The maps contain 22 land cover classes as outlined in the table below. The class numbers for DLCDv2 are consistent with DLCDv1 which contained several additional classes. The RGB values listed in the table can be used for display of the dynamic land cover dataset.</font></font></font></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 3pt;">&#160;</p>

<div align="center">

<p>&#160;</p>
]]></value><format>full_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents><value>Lymburner, L., Tan, P., Mueller, N., Thackway, R., Lewis, A., Thankappan. M., Randall, L., Islam, A., and Senarath, U. (2011). The Dynamic Land Cover Datset. 95pp. GA Record 2011/31, ISBN 978-1-921954-30-6, Geoscience Australia, Canberra.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress><value>90</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-06-30</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><font face="Calibri"><font size="3"><font color="#000000">The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset (DLCD) is a nationally consistent and thematically comprehensive land cover reference for Australia. In producing the DLDC, time series analysis techniques are used to classify each pixel based on the way it has behaved over a two year period. </font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3">Each map can be considered in isolation, or two maps from different intervals can be compared to identify the changes in land cover that have occurred over that time frame.</font></font></font></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><font face="Calibri"><font size="3"><font color="#000000">Each map has been generated by applying a </font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3">sophisticated time series analysis technique known as Dynamic Markov Chain modelling to two years of MODIS EVI data.</font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3"> </font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3">The outputs of the time series analysis are filtered using a class change constraint matrix, a terrain mask and MODIS</font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3"> </font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3">green albedo products. The maps contain 22 land cover classes as outlined in the table below. The class numbers for DLCDv2 are consistent with DLCDv1 which contained several additional classes. The RGB values listed in the table can be used for display of the dynamic land cover dataset.</font></font></font></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 3pt;">&#160;</p>

<div align="center">
<table style="border: 1pt solid gray; border-image: none; border-collapse: collapse;" width="632">
	<tbody>
		<tr style="height: 4.7pt;">
			<td style="border: 1pt solid gray; border-image: none; width: 148.4pt;" width="198">
			<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt; padding: 0cm 5.4pt;"><span style="height: 4.7pt;"><b><span style="color: black;"><font face="Calibri">Common Name</font></span></b></span></p>
			</td>
			<td style="border-width: 1pt 1pt 1pt 0px; border-style: solid solid solid none; border-color: gray gray gray rgb(0, 0, 0); width: 187.4pt;" width="250">
			<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt; padding: 0cm 5.4pt;"><span style="height: 4.7pt;"><b><span style="color: black;"><font face="Calibri">ISO Class Descriptor</font></span></b></span></p>
			</td>
			<td style="border-width: 1pt 1pt 1pt 0px; border-style: solid solid solid none; border-color: gray gray gray rgb(0, 0, 0); width: 39.05pt;" width="52">
			<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt; padding: 0cm 5.4pt;"><span style="height: 4.7pt;"><b><span style="color: black;"><font face="Calibri">Class</font></span></b></span></p>
			</td>
			<td style="border-width: 1pt 1pt 1pt 0px; border-style: solid solid solid none; border-color: gray gray gray rgb(0, 0, 0); width: 33.05pt;" width="44">
			<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt; padding: 0cm 5.4pt;"><span style="height: 4.7pt;"><b><span style="color: black;"><font face="Calibri">R</font></span></b></span></p>
			</td>
			<td style="border-width: 1pt 1pt 1pt 0px; border-style: solid solid solid none; border-color: gray gray gray rgb(0, 0, 0); width: 33.05pt;" width="44">
			<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt; padding: 0cm 5.4pt;"><span style="height: 4.7pt;"><b><span style="color: black;"><font face="Calibri">G</font></span></b></span></p>
			</td>
			<td style="border-width: 1pt 1pt 1pt 0px; border-style: solid solid solid none; border-color: gray gray gray rgb(0, 0, 0); width: 33.05pt;" width="44">
			<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt; padding: 0cm 5.4pt;"><span style="height: 4.7pt;"><b><span style="color: black;"><font face="Calibri">B</font></span></b></span></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr style="height: 4.15pt;">
			<td style="border-width: 0px 1pt 1pt; border-style: none solid solid; border-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) gray gray; width: 148.4pt;" width="198">
			<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt; padding: 0cm 5.4pt;"><span style="height: 4.15pt;"><span style="color: black;"><font face="Calibri">No Data</font></span></span></p>
			</td>
			<td style="border-width: 0px 1pt 1pt 0px; border-style: none solid solid none; border-color: rgb(0, 0, 0) gray gray rgb(0, 0, 0); width: 187.4pt;" width="250">

No match node contents append: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>Dynamic Land Cover shows how Australian land cover is changing over time.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>

No match node contents append: %!24%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset uses a standard land cover classification to show the change in behaviour of land cover across Australia. The DLCD includes data for every 250m by 250m area on the ground,&#160;for the period 2001 to 2015. The DLDC provides a basis for reporting on change and trends in vegetation cover and extent. Information about land cover dynamics is essential to understanding and addressing a range of national challenges such as drought, salinity, water availability and ecosystem health.</p>

<p>The current release of the second version DLCDv2.1 (described in this document) presents land cover information for every 250m by 250m area of the country for each of the two year intervals listed in the table below. It consists of maps based on 2 years of MODIS EVI time-series data. The date ranges for each of the map series are:</p>

<ul>
	<li>January 2001-December 2002</li>
	<li>January 2002-December 2003</li>
	<li>January 2003-December 2004</li>
	<li>January 2004-December 2005</li>
	<li>January 2005-December 2006</li>
	<li>January 2006-December 2007</li>
	<li>January 2007-December 2008</li>
	<li>January 2008-December 2009</li>
	<li>January 2009-December 2010</li>
	<li>January 2010-December 2011</li>
	<li>January 2011-December 2012</li>
	<li>January 2012-December 2013</li>
	<li>January 2013-December 2014</li>
	<li>January 2014-December 2015</li>
</ul>

<p>DLCD can be used as an input for a wide range of environmental modelling applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Climate</li>
	<li>Wind and water erosion risk</li>
	<li>Evapotranspiration</li>
	<li>Carbon dynamics</li>
	<li>Land surface processes</li>
</ul>

<p>In conjunction with other data sources, the DLCD can be used to identify emerging patterns of land cover change and provide a spatial and historical context within which to interpret change.</p>

<p>The land cover classification scheme used conforms to the 2007 International Standards Organisation (ISO) land cover standard (19144-2). The dataset shows Australian land covers clustered into 22 classes. These reflect the structural character of vegetation, ranging from cultivated and managed land covers (crops and pastures) to natural land covers such as trees and grasslands.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

	-<uuid><value>3b82081b-a39d-468c-8d87-4e77b27f1109</value></uuid><vid><value>414</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>DLCD_250_2.1.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494291090</value></created><changed><value>1496819416</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496819416</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">The accuracy of the dataset has been assessed using over 30,000 field sites distributed across all states and territories of Australia. The data was provided by Federal, State and Territory Government agencies and collected over the period 2001 to 2012 including data contributed from these sources:</font></font></span></span></p>

<ul>
	<li>

	<p style="margin-top: 1em; margin-bottom: 1em;">&#160;</p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">The field site data has been collected for a variety of purposes and is accurate to varying spatial and temporal resolutions; typically the primary field site data are no longer available. A process of translation between the field data collected and the dynamic land cover data was undertaken using expert knowledge.</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">Due to the unknown spatial, temporal and thematic accuracy of the field site data the assessment with the dynamic land cover dataset has been reported only for broad themes across all years.&#160;</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<table style="border: 1pt solid windowtext; border-image: none; border-collapse: collapse;">
	<tbody>

		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">The overall accuracy of DLCD assessed using the grouped themes is 81.5%.</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">The field data comparison demonstrates that for cover classes that are poorly represented by a greenness measure, the associated accuracy of the DLCD is very poor. However for cover classes with significant greenness, the grouped accuracy of DLCD is reasonably high. <font size="3">In addition, more dynamic classes such grasses and shrubs show a lower accuracy when assessing a single date field data point against the&#160;general class over a two year period.</font></font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">The complete error matrix, assessing the full 22 class DLCD against field data is available in an <a href="/sites/default/files/2017-06/DLCD%202.1%20Confusion%20Matrix.xlsx">attachment</a>. The full matrix highlights the disparity of the 250 m DLCD versus the field data, and shows those classes that are not characterisable using the EVI greeness measurements. The overall accuracy using the finer class structure is 31.1%.</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">Despite the large number of points in the comparison this comprises less than 0.01% of the land cover classification data. Users are encouraged to assess whether the dataset is fit for their purposes in their area of interest, and provide any feedback to earth.observation@ga.gov.au.</font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font color="#000000"><font face="Calibri">Additionally, the 250 metre pixel scale of the data will limit the use of this data set in studies that depend on the identification of small or detailed features within the landscape i.e. narrow strips of riparian vegetation or managed landscapes where the fields/paddocks are smaller than 250 x 250 metres. </font></font></span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><span style="background: white;"><span style="punctuation-wrap: hanging;"><font face="Calibri"><font color="#000000">The two year time frame for each map in the map series will limit the capacity to detect short lived changes in land cover such as low-intensity bushfires i.e. the canopy may recover within a two year period. </font><font color="#000000">The map series will only provide&#160;limited information for land covers that are difficult to discriminate using EVI such as sugar cane.</font></font></span></span></p>
]]></value><format>full_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Dynamic Land Cover Dataset 250 2.1.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>The primary purpose of the DLCDv2.1 product is to provide the Australian government with a standardised land cover dataset for understanding of&#160;and reporting on land cover change, including to better understand how managed landscapes have responded to droughts, floods and shifts in water allocations. An example application is use within the Australian Bureau of Statistics' Land Accounts.</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The product has many secondary uses. For example climate and weather modellers will be able use DLCDv2 to input land cover parameters into climate and weather models. Ecologists, decision makers and carbon modellers will be able to use DLCDv2 to assess how vegetation responds to disturbance including severe fires, floods, cyclones and land clearing activities. The DLCDv2 can also be used as a contextual layer for products such as the Atlas of Living Australia.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors><value>McIntyre, Alexis</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_authors><value>Tan, Peter</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_authors><value>Lymburner, Leo</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCDv2 is the second DLCD product released by GA. It is based on the MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) product MOD13Q1. For more information on MOD13Q1 see: <a href="https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1">https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1</a></p>

<p>The first version of the DLCD product suite (DLCDv1) was published in 2011 and was a single map based on 250 metre resolution MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) data acquired between April 2000 and April 2008. The DLCDv1 is described in detail at <a href="http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html">http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>
	-%!28%!

	-%!113%!
	-</field_custodian><field_data_description><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span><span><strong><span><span>File naming convention: </span></span></strong></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span><span>DLCD_v2-1_MODIS_EVI_<em>timeslice_startdate_enddate</em>.tif</span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span><span>Eg: DLCD_V@-1_MODIS_EVI_1_20020101-20031231 represents the DLCD for the 2002-2003 period for all of Australia.</span></span></span></span></span></p>

	-%!113%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents><value>Lymburner, L., Tan, P., Mueller, N., Thackway, R., Lewis, A., Thankappan. M., Randall, L., Islam, A., and Senarath, U. (2011). The Dynamic Land Cover Datset. 95pp. GA Record 2011/31, ISBN 978-1-921954-30-6, Geoscience Australia, Canberra.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_estimated_progress><value>90</value></field_estimated_progress><field_expected_completion_date><value>2017-06-30</value></field_expected_completion_date><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><font face="Calibri"><font size="3"><font color="#000000">The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset (DLCD) is a nationally consistent and thematically comprehensive land cover reference for Australia. In producing the DLDC, time series analysis techniques are used to classify each pixel based on the way it has behaved over a two year period. </font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3">Each map can be considered in isolation, or two maps from different intervals can be compared to identify the changes in land cover that have occurred over that time frame.</font></font></font></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;">&#160;</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 0pt;"><font face="Calibri"><font size="3"><font color="#000000">Each map has been generated by applying a </font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3">sophisticated time series analysis technique known as Dynamic Markov Chain modelling to two years of MODIS EVI data.</font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3"> </font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3">The outputs of the time series analysis are filtered using a class change constraint matrix, a terrain mask and MODIS</font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3"> </font></font><font color="#000000"><font size="3">green albedo products. The maps contain 22 land cover classes as outlined in the table below. The class numbers for DLCDv2 are consistent with DLCDv1 which contained several additional classes. The RGB values listed in the table can be used for display of the dynamic land cover dataset.</font></font></font></p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 3pt;">&#160;</p>

<div align="center">
<table style="border: 1pt solid gray; border-image: none; border-collapse: collapse;" width="632">
	<tbody>

			</td>

	-%!27%!
	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>Dynamic Land Cover shows how Australian land cover is changing over time.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!24%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset uses a standard land cover classification to show the change in behaviour of land cover across Australia. The DLCD includes data for every 250m by 250m area on the ground,&#160;for the period 2001 to 2015. The DLDC provides a basis for reporting on change and trends in vegetation cover and extent. Information about land cover dynamics is essential to understanding and addressing a range of national challenges such as drought, salinity, water availability and ecosystem health.</p>

<p>The current release of the second version DLCDv2.1 (described in this document) presents land cover information for every 250m by 250m area of the country for each of the two year intervals listed in the table below. It consists of maps based on 2 years of MODIS EVI time-series data. The date ranges for each of the map series are:</p>

<ul>
	<li>January 2001-December 2002</li>
	<li>January 2002-December 2003</li>
	<li>January 2003-December 2004</li>
	<li>January 2004-December 2005</li>
	<li>January 2005-December 2006</li>
	<li>January 2006-December 2007</li>
	<li>January 2007-December 2008</li>
	<li>January 2008-December 2009</li>
	<li>January 2009-December 2010</li>
	<li>January 2010-December 2011</li>
	<li>January 2011-December 2012</li>
	<li>January 2012-December 2013</li>
	<li>January 2013-December 2014</li>
	<li>January 2014-December 2015</li>
</ul>

<p>DLCD can be used as an input for a wide range of environmental modelling applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Climate</li>
	<li>Wind and water erosion risk</li>
	<li>Evapotranspiration</li>
	<li>Carbon dynamics</li>
	<li>Land surface processes</li>
</ul>

<p>In conjunction with other data sources, the DLCD can be used to identify emerging patterns of land cover change and provide a spatial and historical context within which to interpret change.</p>

<p>The land cover classification scheme used conforms to the 2007 International Standards Organisation (ISO) land cover standard (19144-2). The dataset shows Australian land covers clustered into 22 classes. These reflect the structural character of vegetation, ranging from cultivated and managed land covers (crops and pastures) to natural land covers such as trees and grasslands.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_owner>

	-%!17%!
	-</field_subject_matter_experts><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset Version 2 is a suite of land cover information products from Geoscience Australia (GA). These information products deliver International Standards Organisation (ISO) compliant land cover maps across the Australian landmass. The datasets provide a consistent series of maps that show how Australian land cover is changing over time. The current version consists of 14 maps each based on 2 years of MODIS data. The 14 maps cover the period from January 2001 - December 2015.</p>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>47789407-f1aa-49c7-b406-71e239b6e648</value></uuid><vid><value>119</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Full pass/strip processing</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493874763</value></created><changed><value>1493874793</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493874793</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>'Full pass' or 'strip' processing rectifies a sequential strip of images taken during a single segment of a satellite?s orbit. the metadata for each separate scene are merged to produce a single, continuous set of orbit and attitude parameters, such that the entire strip of tens of images can be treated as a single image, even though the separate scenes are not actually merged. The merging of orbit data results in a considerable reduction in both the number of unknown orientation parameters and the number of control points required in the sensor orientation adjustment.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p>(See technical report and reference papers http://www.ga.gov.au/image_cache/GA20164.pdf)</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>f7149f28-9382-4a04-93b5-3e99187f8523</value></uuid><vid><value>120</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>BARISTA</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493874815</value></created><changed><value>1493874822</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493874822</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose/><field_software_proc_description/><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>ffbef4a9-441a-4544-af7f-97be9e260d97</value></uuid><vid><value>121</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Fractional Cover Processing</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493874839</value></created><changed><value>1493874887</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493874887</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent for any point in time in the Landsat archive since 1987. FC can potentially provide insight into areas of dry/dying vegetation and/or bare soil as well as allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code><uri>http://github.com/geoscienceaustralia/fc </uri><title></title><options/></field_source_code><field_version_number/>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>ffda822d-7ee8-465f-b362-398af7e94345</value></uuid><vid><value>122</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>NDVI Function</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493874916</value></created><changed><value>1493874937</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493874937</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>Live green plants absorb solar radiation in the photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) spectral region, which they use as a source of energy in the process of photosynthesis. Leaf cells have also evolved to reflect, scatter and re-emit solar radiation in the near-infrared spectral region. The pigment in plant leaves, chlorophyll, strongly absorbs visible light (from 0.4 to 0.7 micrometres) for use in photosynthesis. The cell structure of the leaves, on the other hand, strongly reflects near-infrared light (from 0.7 to 1.1 micrometres). Hence, live green plants appear relatively dark in the PAR and relatively bright in the near-infrared.<br />
By contrast, clouds and snow tend to be rather bright in the red (as well as other visible wavelengths) and quite dark in the near-infrared.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p>The Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is calculated as follows:</p>

<p>(NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED)</p>

<p>where RED and NIR stand for the spectral reflectance measurements acquired in the red and near-infrared regions, respectively.</p>

<p>NDVI values range between -1 and +1, and have been scaled by 10000 to be stored as integers between -10000 and +10000.</p>

<p>Negative values of NDVI (values between 0 and -1) usually correspond to non vegetation targets such as water. Values close to zero (-0.1 to 0.1) generally correspond to barren areas of rock, sand, or snow. Low, positive values usually represent shrub and grassland (approximately 0.2 to 0.4), while high values are indicative of healthy crops or dense vegetation such as temperate and tropical rainforests (values approaching 1).</p>

<p>First described in Tucker (1979) the NDVI has been widely used as a vegetation index to characterise the amount of vegetation on the Earths surface. The study by Carlson and Ripley (1997) is widely cited and describes the relationship between NDVI, fractional vegetation cover and leaf area index.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>0ff1b543-a236-4f4a-83a5-321c19433643</value></uuid><vid><value>123</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Geometric Median</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493874960</value></created><changed><value>1493874976</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493874976</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose/><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p>See Roberts et al (2017).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>1862cc6d-5fb6-49c4-ac86-904dd60a5c89</value></uuid><vid><value>126</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Determine values for six base atmospheric parameters across each image scene</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493875031</value></created><changed><value>1493875047</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493875047</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose/><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<ol>
	<li>Divide scene into quarters and select the nine unique points which form the corners of these quadrants</li>
	<li>Compute the six parameters across optical spectrum at each of the nine points using a Radiative Transfer Model (Modtran 5) and atmospheric state data</li>
	<li>Accumulate values for the six parameters at each of the nine points to correspond to Landsat bands using Landsat spectral response function</li>
	<li>Interpolate accumulated values for the six parameters across image scene using the bilinear method.</li>
</ol>

Hence, terminology has been adopted for the product to reflect the highest modelled tide observed in a given cell (HOT) and the lowest modelled tide observed (LOT) (Figure 2). These measures are relative to Mean Sea Level, and have no consistent relationship to Lowest (LAT) and Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT).</span></p>
