Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>0fa9046e-baf9-489d-9db1-09349496b755</value></uuid><vid><value>235</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>raster_schema</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>7de3bcec-2e33-4e88-94c6-f7eb7847a1a8</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>AGDC Standard Raster Schema</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495410728</value></created><changed><value>1495432985</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495432985</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_cell_size_x/><field_cell_size_y/><field_coordinate_reference_syste>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>ae6cf9c4-ea1b-4bb1-a84f-efd0c66c4656</value></uuid><vid><value>240</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Water Observations from Space Detection Algorithm 1.2</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495434983</value></created><changed><value>1495435207</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495435207</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>The water detection algorithm used to detect water from each observed pixel is based on a statistical regression tree analysis of a set of normalised difference indices and corrected band values. The regression is based on a set of water and non-water samples created by visual interpretation of 20 Landsat scenes from across Australia. The sample locations, indicated below, ensure that the logistic regression is based on the full geographic range of conditions experienced in Australia.</p>

<p>The regression analysis determined a set of best indices and bands for the analysis and the associated thresholds in each component to derive a final classification tree, producing a water/non-water classification for pixel in the Data Cube. The final water classification for each pixel is modified by Pixel Quality (see associated PQ product information) and terrain.<br />
Once the water algorithm has completed its process, the water detection for a pixel through time is combined to produce a total number of water observations for each pixel. This is compared to a total number of clear observations for the same pixel, derived from the PQ analysis. The ratio is expressed as a percentage water recurrence.</p>

<p>Confidence that a pixel depicted as having had water detected at some time is calculated by a Confidence Layer. The layer is computed by combining a set of confidence factors using a weighted sum approach, with the weightings derived by logistic regression.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description/><field_source_code/><field_version_number><value>1.2</value></field_version_number>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>e8c34358-8cb2-49b8-b7a7-d78862d6487b</value></uuid><vid><value>264</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Fractional Cover Algorithm 1.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495502673</value></created><changed><value>1495502806</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495502806</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p><span>Fractional Cover provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent.<span>&#160; </span>It is generated using the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and described in Scarth et al. (2010).</span></p>

<p>Fractional cover data &#160;can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition.<span><span> This information could enable </span></span>policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>The fractional cover unmixing algorthim uses the spectral signature for a picture element (pixel) to break it up into three parts or fractions. This is based on field work identifying the spectral characteristics of each of the fractions. The three fractions are green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare soil. The green fraction includes leaves and grass, the non-photosynthetic includes branches, dry grass and dead leaf litter, and the bare soil fraction includes bare soil or rock.</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The method used to generate this data was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and implemented by Geoscience Australia over the Landsat archive which has been pre-processed to surface reflectance (ARG25). The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction  the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis, <em>Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</em>, viewed 4 January 2011, </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland, <em>Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</em>, viewed 4 January 2011, </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://data.auscover.org.au/xwiki/bin/view/Product+pages/Landsat+Fractional+Cover">http://data.auscover.org.au/xwiki/bin/view/Product+pages/Landsat+Fractional+Cover</a></span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number><value>1.0</value></field_version_number>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>f48f22df-8540-48c0-a824-cbbe93ec67fa</value></uuid><vid><value>272</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Dynamic Land Cover Algorithm</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495506358</value></created><changed><value>1495506676</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495506676</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images><target_id>15</target_id><alt>DLCD Processing Workflow</alt><title></title><width>480</width><height>646</height><target_type>file</target_type><target_uuid>b442e3d9-ad83-45fd-9b40-987cea1a77fe</target_uuid><url>http://cmi.ga.gov.au/sites/default/files/2017-05/DLCD1_Flowchart.jpg</url></field_images><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose/><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCD classification methodology and process along with major algorithms used are described in detail in the National Dynamic Land Cover Dataset - Technical Report (Lymburner et al, 2011).</p>

<p>The DLCD is based on an analysis of a 16-day EVI composite collected at 250 metre resolution using the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) satellite for the period 2000 to 2008.</p>

<p>The MODIS time series for each pixel was analysed using an innovative technique which reduced each time series into 12 coefficients based on the statistical, phenological and seasonal characteristics of each pixel.<br />
These coefficients were then clustered using a support vector clustering algorithm and the resultant classes were labelled using agreed National data supplied from catchment scale land use mapping and the National Vegetation Information System (NVIS).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number><value>1.0</value></field_version_number>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe's Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-1 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>b4199cca-436a-4e6f-9609-edc23b2c91ff</value></uuid><vid><value>340</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>a889e941-fb41-4d04-aa76-0d33f0033059</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Generating Time Series for DLCD</value></title><uid><target_id>27</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>e7b560a4-0a39-4070-a52f-e2491bdb182a</target_uuid><url>/user/27</url></uid><created><value>1495692335</value></created><changed><value>1495692335</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495692335</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>27</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>e7b560a4-0a39-4070-a52f-e2491bdb182a</target_uuid><url>/user/27</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_process_description><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>The MOD13Q1 data for each 16 day interval were concatenated into a data cube to enable retrieval of a time series of EVI values for an individual pixel.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_process_description>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>c1326637-262b-4429-9b6e-c5ee2bba321a</value></uuid><vid><value>341</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>a889e941-fb41-4d04-aa76-0d33f0033059</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Time series noise removal</value></title><uid><target_id>27</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>e7b560a4-0a39-4070-a52f-e2491bdb182a</target_uuid><url>/user/27</url></uid><created><value>1495692387</value></created><changed><value>1495692387</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495692387</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>27</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>e7b560a4-0a39-4070-a52f-e2491bdb182a</target_uuid><url>/user/27</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_process_description><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>The EVI data contain occasional spikes and dips that do not represent biophysical changes and are not captured by the data quality flags. These anomalous points were removed using the spike removal algorithm outlined in Lymburner et al. (2011)</span></span></p>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>08154d8b-cb3c-4516-956d-c020b98ed026</value></uuid><vid><value>342</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>a889e941-fb41-4d04-aa76-0d33f0033059</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>DLCD Time Series Analysis</value></title><uid><target_id>27</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>e7b560a4-0a39-4070-a52f-e2491bdb182a</target_uuid><url>/user/27</url></uid><created><value>1495692431</value></created><changed><value>1495692431</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495692431</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>27</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>e7b560a4-0a39-4070-a52f-e2491bdb182a</target_uuid><url>/user/27</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_process_description><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>The MODIS EVI data cube is analysed to characterise the time series trends for each pixel. This process represents the time series in a form that allows it to be classified more easily. The initial characterisation of the time series data involves three steps: </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>(1) Piece-wise Linear Segmentation</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The time series segmentation algorithm approximates a time series using a series of piece-wise linear segments. Each segment is characteristic of a sequence of environmental behaviour that typifies the associated land cover class. </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>(2) Sub-sequence Discretization </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>Each segment is then detailed by three values describing its starting value, slope and length to form a vector input to the classification process.</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>(3) Sequence Labelling</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The sequences are then clustered into groups of like behaviour, and each group then assigned a behaviour label. A time series is thus transformed from a large collection of varying values to a smaller set of behaviour types, joined as a kind of DNA string representing the pixel through time. </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>(4) Markov modelling</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The DNA string provides an initial class which is then modelled as a dynamic Markov Chain to estimate the likelihood that a particular land cover class would occur after any other land cover class. </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>(5) Bayesian classification</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The final class is then assigned using a Bayesian classifier.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_process_description>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>1f3a29cf-efbd-42b0-9682-fb185f8a277f</value></uuid><vid><value>347</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>46cc945d-a7c1-44a4-9031-91383046fc6e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>DLCD classification (Lymburner et al., 2011)</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495773965</value></created><changed><value>1495774700</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1495774700</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_images/><field_input/><field_output/><field_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p><span><span>The DLCD classification algorithm provides a basis for reporting on change and trends in vegetation cover and extent. Information about land cover dynamics is essential to understanding and addressing a range of national challenges such as drought, salinity, water availability and ecosystem health.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_purpose><field_software_proc_description><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCD analysis<span><span><span> uses an innovative technique which reduces each time series into 12 coefficients based on the statistical, phenological and seasonal characteristics of each pixel. These coefficients were then clustered using a support vector clustering algorithm and the resultant classes were labelled using agreed National data supplied from catchment scale land use mapping and the National Vegetation Information System (NVIS). </span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>The DLCD classification methodology and process along with major algorithms used are described in detail in the National Dynamic Land Cover Dataset - Technical Report (</span></span></span><span><span><span>Ly</span></span></span><span><span><span>mburner et al, 2011).</span></span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_proc_description><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>d6e93d27-9777-42df-910c-e8740e2bd2cd</value></uuid><vid><value>352</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>raster_schema</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>7de3bcec-2e33-4e88-94c6-f7eb7847a1a8</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>MOD13Q1 Raster Schema</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1496015114</value></created><changed><value>1496015246</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496015246</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><path/><field_cell_size_x><value>0.002349</value></field_cell_size_x><field_cell_size_y><value>0.002349</value></field_cell_size_y><field_coordinate_reference_syste>

This has application in emergency management and risk assessment.<br />
The product has many secondary uses. For example the WO_25_2.1.5 product provides an indication on the permanence of surface water in the Australian landscape by showing where water is observed rarely in comparison to where it is often observed. This has application in water management and mapping. WO_25_2.1.5 has also been used for wetland analyses, water connectivity and surface-ground water relationships.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Water Observations from Space product (WO_25_2.1.5) is a key component of the National Flood Risk Information Portal (NFRIP), developed by Geoscience Australia (GA). The objective of Water Observations from Space is to analyse GA's historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past.</p>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>af76fe11-1985-4015-965d-21757841ddf8</value></uuid><vid><value>360</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>WO_25_1.1.2</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495433829</value></created><changed><value>1496111892</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496111892</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Water Observations from Space (WOfS) 25m 1.2</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The primary purpose of the WOfS product is to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. This has application in emergency management and risk assessment.<br />
It is anticipated that WOfS will have many secondary uses. For example the WOfS product provides an indication on the permanence of surface water in the Australian landscape by showing where water is observed rarely in comparison to where it is often observed. This has application in water management and mapping.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Water Observations from Space product (WOfS) is a key component of the National Flood Risk Information Portal (NFRIP)2, being developed by Geoscience Australia (GA). The objective of WOfS is to analyse GAs historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past.</p>

<p>WOfS is being developed in parallel with the National Flood Studies Database system which will provide Flood Study documentation and reports to a wide range of users. Both systems will be delivered via the internet through the NFRIP portal.</p>

<p>Satellite imagery has been used to map floods around the world for several years. Organisations such as the Colorado Flood Observatory in the USA and several state-based agencies in Australia regularly provide satellite-based flood extents for major flood events. GA developed a flood mapping methodology in 2008-2009 that was extensively used for the major Australian flood events since 2010, providing emergency service agencies with regional flood extent information.</p>

<p>The Phase 1 outputs from the NFRIP were delivered to the public in November 2012, including a proof of concept of WOfS. This displayed surface water extents for three study areas, including the original derived extents and the cumulative summary product. Subsequent stakeholder feedback has shown that the most desirable information is the summary product, providing and understanding of the long term dynamics of surface water.</p>

<p>The Phase 2 outputs from the NFRIP (release in April 2014), include this WOfS product, which will be accessible to the public as a web service from the NFRIP.</p>

<p><em><strong>Confidence Level</strong></em></p>

<p>Reviews of prototype products identified the need to indicate the level of confidence for the surface water observations. The confidence level will help the user to distinguish between unusual but valid water detections (such as flood plains which might only be observed as water once in the 15 year interval) and false positives which can be caused, for instance, by steep shady slopes.</p>

<p>The confidence level was determined through a multiple logistic regression of water observations against several factors that would either support or contra-indicate the finding of water being present at the site.</p>

<p>The factors comprise:</p>

<p><strong>MrVBF</strong>, a multi-resolution valley bottom flatness product (Gallant et al., 2012) derived from SRTM as part of the Terrestrial Ecosystems Research Network. Surface water pixels identified in valley bottoms were more likely to be positively detected.</p>

<p><strong>Slope</strong> derived from SRTM Digital Surface Models. Water pixels on a slope were considered less plausible than those on a flat surface.</p>

<p><strong>MODIS Open Water Likelihood (OWL)</strong> (Ticehurst et al, 2010) provides a plausibility based an independent water detection algorithm employing the MODIS sensor. If both detection algorithms agree on the presence of a surface water pixel, there is a greater plausibility that the detection is correct.</p>

<p><strong>Australian Hydrological Geospatial Fabric (Geofabric)</strong> is a GIS of hydrological features derived from manually interpreted topographic map grids. If known hydrologic features (pixels) from GeoFabric coincide with detected water pixels, the plausibility of detection is greater.</p>

<p><strong>P</strong>, the number of observations of water as a fraction of the number of clear observations of the target pixel. P is high for more permanent water bodies.</p>

<p><strong>Built-Up areas</strong> indicating areas of dense urban development. In such areas the water detection algorithm struggles to cope with the deep shadows cast by multi-story buildings and the generally noisy spectral response created by structures. The Built-Up layer is derived from the Ausralian Bureau of Statistics ASGS 2011 dataset, for urban centres of populations of 100 000 and over.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>f32cfa9c-2bf2-4207-be44-44f532518d9d</value></uuid><vid><value>361</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>WO-STATS_25_2.1.5</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494309943</value></created><changed><value>1496111975</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496111975</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>in_development</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Please refer to the SR-N_25_2.0.0 Product Description (GA, 2013) for the accuracy and limitations of the atmospheric, BRDF and topographic shading processing sequence. Please refer to Mueller et al. 2016 for details on accuracy and limitations.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australias satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Water Observations from Space Statistics 25m 2.1.5</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The primary purpose of the WO_2.1.5 and WO_STATS_2.1.5 products is to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. This has application in emergency management and risk assessment.<br />
The product has many secondary uses. For example the products provide an indication of the permanence of surface water in the Australian landscape by showing where water is observed rarely in comparison to where it is often observed. This has application in water management and mapping. The products have also been used for wetland analyses, water connectivity and surface-ground water relationships.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors><value>Norman Mueller</value><format>basic_html</format></field_authors><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Water Observations from Space product (WO_2.1.5) is a key component of the National Flood Risk Information Portal (NFRIP), developed by Geoscience Australia (GA). The objective of Water Observations from Space is to analyse GA's historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. The collection of many hundred thousand WOFLs that make up WO_2.1.5 are too cumbersome to display easily. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides the mechanism to present and deliver WO_2.1.5 in an easily digestible form, and provides understanding of water in the landscape.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>
root found
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>a77c8d53-0e29-4819-83ce-3fb1c48ff74b</value></uuid><vid><value>362</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>SR_MEDOID_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494306917</value></created><changed><value>1496112005</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112005</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>

<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>

<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25 Medoid v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:</p>

<ul>
	<li>surface reflectance;</li>
	<li>atmospheric condition;</li>
	<li>interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and</li>
	<li>land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.</li>
</ul>

<p>It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
root found
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>bcf969df-6213-4e5c-86d4-64e3b53de64a</value></uuid><vid><value>363</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>SR_GEOMEDIAN_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494306216</value></created><changed><value>1496112033</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112033</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>reviewed</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>

<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>

<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25m Geomedian 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geomedian provides an annual reflectance composite for any area of interest within the area covered by the AGDC. It provides a cloud-free overview of the middle surface reflectance value for each year and can be used in further analyses such as Tasselled Cap, Principal Components Analysis and Normalised Difference Indices.</p>

<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia's archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:</p>

<ul>
	<li>surface reflectance;</li>
	<li>atmospheric condition;</li>
	<li>interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and</li>
	<li>land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.</li>
</ul>

<p>It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

The longer compositing period may make this product unsuitable for studies that are focused on short lived phenomena.</p>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>7b05e0b3-38ed-44dd-bd5e-1250fe12d00f</value></uuid><vid><value>367</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Sentinel Hotspots</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495494880</value></created><changed><value>1496112193</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112193</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<ul>
	<li><span>False positives are possible (showing a Hotspot without an underlying cause).</span></li>
	<li><span>False negatives are possible (failing to show a Hotspot, despite a heated land surface, fire etc.).</span></li>
	<li><span>Hotspots may indicate phenomena other than fires when locations are identified as hot for some other reason, such as black soil, gas fires, industry and hot rocks.</span></li>
	<li><span>Not all fires will be detected as Hotspots. If no satellite has passed over the fire, or if smoke, cloud, distance or topography prevent the instruments from sensing the fire, or if the fire is too small or too cool to produce enough heat, or if there is some other technical failure, no Hotspot will be identified.</span></li>
	<li><span>The location of the Hotspot on a map is approximate only (as a guide, within 1.5 km of the centre of the observation).</span></li>
	<li><span><span>Hotspot locations represent an <em>area around the point</em> , dependent on the sensor and the satellite position. With current sensors, this is typically more than one square kilometre.</span></span></li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Sentinel Hotspots</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p><span>Hotspots are useful for detecting possible active fires in some circumstances. Taken as an ensemble, the Hotspots provide an overview of fire activity in Australia and capture the pattern of actual fires across the Australian continent through time.</span></p>

<p><span><span>Emergency management agencies use the Hotspots as one of many operational data feeds to inform their broad situational awareness of, and at times tactical response to, fires.</span></span></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background/><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>
root found
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>eb44806b-a9bc-49eb-8ac3-2ba2c0f13324</value></uuid><vid><value>368</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_COUNT_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1494300836</value></created><changed><value>1496112250</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112250</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>reviewed</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality Count 25m 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsats 5, 7 and 8.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
root found
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>3db22d26-cd94-4b11-8108-74f84edf6346</value></uuid><vid><value>369</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493954905</value></created><changed><value>1496112357</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112357</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>in_development</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality 25 v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsats 5, 7 and 8.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>None</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation</p>

This information can also be used to normalise observation counts of particular phenomena. For example what percentage of time did a pixel meet a particular criteria during a particular year.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The different sensor designs of Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+, and Landsat 8 OLI all have different sensor saturation characteristics. The PQ25 layer enables users to exclude observations from a given band where the pixels are saturated (exceed the dynamic range of the sensor). The per-band saturation information in PQ allows users to exclude pixels where their specific band of interest is saturated.</p>

<p>The PQ 25 layer uses two industry standard cloud/cloud shadow detection algorithms to flag pixels that potentially contain cloud and allows the user to generate masks based on either algorithm or both algorithms.</p>

<p>The PQ25-STATS product is a summary of all of the individual PQ_25 layers.</p>

Hence, terminology has been adopted for the product to reflect the highest modelled tide observed in a given cell (HOT) and the lowest modelled tide observed (LOT) (Figure 2). These measures are relative to Mean Sea Level, and have no consistent relationship to Lowest (LAT) and Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Intertidal Extents Model 25m v. 1.1.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The purpose of the ITEM v1.1 product is to assist in understanding the extent and elevation profile of the Australian intertidal zone. Examples of where this knowledge can contribute include environmental monitoring applications for migratory bird species, habitat mapping in coastal regions, hydrodynamic modelling, and geomorphology studies of features in the intertidal zone.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.1) product analyses GAs historic archive of satellite imagery to derive a model of the spatial extents of the intertidal zone throughout the tidal cycle. The model can assist in understanding the relative elevation profile of the intertidal zone, delineating exposed areas at differing tidal heights and stages.</p>

<p>The product differs from previous methods used to map the intertidal zone which have been predominately focused on analysing a small number of individual satellite images per location (e.g Ryu et al., 2002; Murray et al., 2012). By utilising a full 28 year time series of observations, the methodology enables us to overcome the requirement for clear, high quality observations acquired concurrent to the time of high and low tide.</p>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>cc2b37b8-e1f4-454b-a1be-09f72814c5a2</value></uuid><vid><value>380</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>FC_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1493962627</value></created><changed><value>1496112795</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112795</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>in_development</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Based on the comparison with the field data the FC product has an overall Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 11.8%. The error margins vary for the three different layers: green RMSE: 11.0%, non-green RMSE: 17.4% and bare RMSE: 12.5%.</p>

<p>The effect of soil moisture may impact the accuracy of the FC product, and the similarity between some bare soil endmembers and non-photosynthetic vegetation endmembers can lead to model instability. Pixels that show poor model stability are flagged in the model error band as a value of 2, and can be omitted from further analysis if necessary.</p>

<p>FC products have no water masking applied, so erroneous values for green vegetation over the water may appear. These should be ignored and can be masked out by applying the Water Observations (WO) layer.</p>

<p>Occasionally the sum of the three components is not equal to 100%. Differences are usually small and are not rounded in order to preserve what may be useful seasonal indicators.</p>

<p>Landsat 8 OLI has different relative spectral response curves to the Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+ sensors. As a consequence the absolute values for fractional cover estimated from unadjusted Landsat 8 OLI data using the current algorithm may be inaccurate. The magnitude of this impact is described in more detail in Flood (2014).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25 v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environemental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australias longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australias partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a consistent classification which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>

<p>The effect of soil moisture may impact the accuracy of the FC25 product, and the similarity between some bare soil endmembers and non-photosynthetic vegetation endmembers can lead to model instability.&#160; Pixels that show poor model stability are flagged in Band 4 (the mask band) as a value of 2, and can be omitted from further analysis if necessary.</p>

While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS provides a consistent summary of fractional cover which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>

root found
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>af966359-eb9b-4a45-803f-7606020f23b3</value></uuid><vid><value>384</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>DLCD_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495503595</value></created><changed><value>1496112952</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496112952</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Limitation statement to cover (where relevant):</p>

<ul>
	<li>data accuracy (as defined in Section 4.5);</li>
	<li>data source mentioning resolution, frequency and reliability (without duplicating other information in Section B);</li>
	<li>obstructions to observations.</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Dynamic Land Cover Dataset 25 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>DLCD can be used as an input for modelling:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Groundwater recharge and discharge</li>
	<li>Climate</li>
	<li>Wind and water erosion risk</li>
	<li>Evapotranspiration</li>
	<li>Carbon dynamics</li>
	<li>Land surface processes</li>
	<li>Inundation</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>In 2009 the National Committee for Land Use and Management Information identified the need for land cover information to facilitate change detection and improve natural resource management.</p>

<p>Existing land cover datasets are composites of State and Territory datasets which have been developed to meet specific legislative needs. This leads to thematic mismatches between different datasets and limits the capacity for meaningful change detection.</p>

<p>Nationally consistent and thematically comprehensive land cover information is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include sustainable farming practices, management of water resources, air quality, soil erosion and forests, as well as emergency management and urban planning.</p>

<p>The DLCD is based on an analysis of a 16-day EVI composite collected at 250 metre resolution using the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) satellite for the period 2000 to 2008.</p>

<p>The MODIS time series for each pixel was analysed using an innovative technique which reduced each time series into 12 coefficients based on the statistical, phenological and seasonal characteristics of each pixel. These coefficients were then clustered using a support vector clustering algorithm and the resultant classes were labelled using agreed National data supplied from catchment scale land use mapping and the National Vegetation Information System (NVIS).</p>

<p>The DLCD classification methodology and process along with major algorithms used are described in detail in the National Dynamic Land Cover Dataset - Technical Report (Lymburner et al, 2011).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_coverage_content_type>
root found
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>488583be-01c0-4c03-af8c-2c76184f5f1c</value></uuid><vid><value>386</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>0ca00771-b5c4-47ce-9aef-0c32af21ab58</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>ARG_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1495003925</value></created><changed><value>1496113024</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1496113024</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>4c43e4bf-484f-434f-a5f2-53d69fd58d97</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Reflectance Grid 25 v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>ARG25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_authors/><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat TM/ETM+ imagery over Australia for several decades and more recently Landsat OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery.<br />
To improve access to Australias archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012).<br />
The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ imagery to create the ARG25-V0.0 and ARG25-V0.1 products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes5 and processing complexities involved with production of this product. It is intended that the Landsat archives from 1987 will be incrementally incorporated into the ARG25 product and released as subsequent versions.<br />
Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:</p>

<ul>
	<li>surface reflectance;</li>
	<li>atmospheric condition;</li>
	<li>interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and</li>
	<li>land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.</li>
</ul>

<p>It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012).<br />
The ARG25 product delivers an estimate of surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artefacts of the imaging environment.<br />
Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time. This process is further simplified when the surface reflectance data conforms to a sensor agnostic nested grid, as envisaged for future versions of the ARG25 product.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in Australian land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_background_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The ARG25 collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
